tags: ['series premiere', 'season premiere', 'steam bath', 'telephone call', 'water tower', 'chain', 'cigar', 'cigar box', 'listening device', 'fence', 'pilot episode', 'black and white episode', 'splashed with water', 'luger', 'manicure', 'counterfeit currency', 'camera shot of feet', 'submarine', 'antenna', 'dog licking face', 'chateaubriand', 'prussian helmet', 'coffee pot', 'tailor', 'german shepherd', 'exchanging clothes', 'year 1942', 'tv series pilot']
synopsis_with_character_names:
This is the series premiere, the only one in black-and-white.

At the start, German Sergeant Schultz, the head guard at the camp, gets the men out of the barracks and starts counting them. When he gets to British Corporal Newkirk, number 4, Newkirk faints and falls into Schultz. While this is going on, American Sergeant Olson runs to the fence, lifts up a portion of the inner fence which acts as a gate, goes to the outer fence, lifts up a portion of the outer fence, and leaves camp. Schultz keeps talking at the prisoners. At one point, Schultz loses his helmet; one of the prisoners grabs it and passes it down the line of prisoners without Schultz seeing it. Schultz eventually gets his helmet back.

Olson, now outside the camp, finds American Lieutenant Carter, who dug his way out of another camp. Olson tells Carter that he will get him into camp.

Schultz, after getting his helmet back, finished the count of the prisoners; there is 1 prisoner missing. Colonel Klink goes to Hogan, talking with him about distracting Schultz for an escape. The 5 dogs in the kennel get let out.

Outside the fence, Olson is with Carter, talks to the dogs like they are friends. He tells the dogs 'Not Yet', and the dogs walk off. The dogs then find Carter, and Carter puts his hands up.

Later, in the barracks, Hogan asks Carter about an individual named McNair, who supposedly was with Carter's old outfit; Carter does not know him. Hogan asks Carter some other questions, to be sure that he is not a spy. While they are talking, Russian prisoner Vladimir, the local tailor, is putting civilian clothes on Carter in preparation for his escape. Hogan tells Newkirk that the football game is off; Vladmir is disappointed as he was going to play fullback. Newkirk then pulls some magic tricks on Carter while he is standing there. Hogan then says that he is short of tenors in the camp glee club. Carter asks Hogan about Olson, what does he do when he is outside; Hogan says that he doesn't know. American Staff Sergeant Kinchloe comes in and says that Klink wants to see Hogan.

Hogan goes to Klink's office. In the outer office, Klink's secretary Helga thanks Hogan for the nylons, giving him a sly smile. Hogan goes into Klink's office, and tosses his hat onto the spike of Klink's pickelhelb, a WW-I type spiked helmet that Klink has on his desk. Klink gets mad and gives Hogan his hat back. Hogan tries to get a cigar from Klink's cigar box on his desk, but Klink objects and locks the box. Klink talks to Hogan about the 'escape' last night. Klink gives Hogan his speech about 'no one escapes from Camp 13'. Hogan asks Klink how many men would he need to guard the prisoners if they stopped trying to escape? He tells Klink that a captain could run the place. Klink asks Hogan which one of his men he has been talking to - Karl, Fritz, Schultz? When Hogan winces at the name 'Schultz', Klink knows he is the one. Klink says that he is from the old Prussian school. Because of the attempted escape, the entire camp will be punished. Hogan asks Klink to look out the window. As he does this, Hogan slips the hinge out of the cigar box, takes come cigars, puts them in his inside pocket, and slips the hinge back. Klink says that there will be no football game today. Hogan puts one of the cigars in his mouth and asks Klink for a light; Klink lights the cigar, and Hogan leaves.

There is another new prisoner, Technical Sergeant Wagner. Hogan asks him about McNair and Ellingsworth; Wagner does not know them. He then asks about Major Campbell; Wagner 'knows' Campbell. Hogan and Wagner laugh about a story regarding Campbell. This marks him as a phony as Campbell is not a real man in his outfit, Hogan was just testing him. Hogan tells Newkirk to pass the word that nobody talks to Wagner.

Kinch sets up the coffee pot in Hogan's office, which is actually a listening device for a bug that has been planted in Klink's office. He says that they have to stop making coffee in that coffee pot. French Corporal LeBeau brings in some food. Hogan, Kinch, Newkirk, Carter, and LeBeau are listening in to the conversation in Klink's office. They hear Wagner talking on the phone; he identifies himself as Lieutenant Wagner to German Colonel Burkhalter on the other end of the phone. Wagner says that this is an embarkation point for escapees. Listening in, Hogan asks the others who talked? Carter says it was him; he was asleep and didn't get the word not to talk to Wagner. Hogan wants to eat.

Wagner tells Klink about the operation. Kinch says that Wagner will tell Burkhalter about the whole operation. Hogan smiles, and wants to tell Wagner about everything; and he says that the Germans somehow will not believe him.

Later, Hogan blindfolds Wagner, takes him to the doghouse entrance to the tunnel in the dog kennel; LeBeau says that this is under the water tower. Hogan has Wagner pull a chain, handing him the links as he pulls, thinking he is opening up a tunnel entrance under the water tower. Hogan, LeBeau, and Wagner go below. Hogan shows Wagner the 'mint', some printing presses where they print phony German money. Wagner asks if he has problems passing the counterfeit money off, Hogan says that in the real stuff, the ink tends to run. Wagner then quietly grabs a handful of money and stuffs it in his picket; he thinks that nobody sees him, but Hogan does. Hogan then shows Wagner the production line where they make souvenir cigar lighters in the shape of German Luger pistols. Wagner then quietly takes one of these lighters; again, Hogan sees him. Hogan tells Wagner about Oscar Schnitzer, the dog man. He says that there are no dogs in the truck, but it is a phonograph record playing barking dogs. Hogan shows Wagner the steam room with several prisoners taking a steam bath; then the barber shop, where they give escapees haircuts and manicures, with Helga as the manicurist. Hogan then says that he has to call the submarine. Kinch, on the radio, pumps a cylinder that raises the radio antenna that is built into the flagpole. The submarine 'Mama Bear' calls Hogan 'Goldilocks'. Hogan tells them to pick up the packages 3 hours earlier than scheduled.

The next day, at roll call, Hogan meets with Colonel Burkhalter. Wagner comes out and accuses Hogan about the operation he is running under Klink's nose. Wagner says that he has a sample of money that they printed; he can't find it. Newkirk winks at Hogan, implying that Newkirk quietly picked his pocket of the money, and did other things while Wagner didn't know it. Wagner talks about the souvenir lighters. Burkhalter asks for a cigar; Klink does not have one, but Hogan gives him one (one of Klink's that he stole earlier). Wagner goes to give him a light, but the pistol fires a shot instead, blowing the end off of the cigar. Burkhalter is agitated. He asks Wagner to show him the entrance to the tunnel; Wagner says that it is under the water tower. They go to the water tower, Wagner pulls the chain, and water falls onto Burkhalter. The dog truck comes in; Wagner says that there are no dogs, just a record, so he opens the back door of the truck. The dogs jump out and start running around. During the commotion, Hogan puts Carter in the truck and closes the door. Burkhalter says to arrest Wagner, and give him some time on the eastern front.

As all this is ending, Schultz finishes counting the prisoners; 15, all present. Klink looks at Schultz and says 'Did I ask you?' Schultz takes the men tack into the barracks. Hogan is last; he waits for Schultz to go in, then stays outside and closes the door behind Schultz. After a couple of seconds, Schultz comes out and shoos Hogan back in the barracks.

description: Learning that the German army is manufacturing an improved Tiger tank, Hogan and his men are determined to steal one, so they can disassemble it and make blueprints for the Allies.
tags: ['tank', 'first kiss', 'underground agent', "woman wears a man's uniform", 'ropes', 'secret panel', 'roll call', 'speech', 'staff car', 'motorcycle', 'dog', 'disassembly', 'throwing orders on the ground', 'assembly bell', 'riot', 'phony prison camp escape', 'tiger tank', 'goodbye kiss', 'romantic kiss', 'efficiency', 'wolf whistle', 'tailor', 'character says heil hitler', 'impersonating an enemy soldier']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Klink is in front of the assembled prisoners in front of their barracks, giving them a speech. He tells them that things go well for the Third Reich. New weapons pour out of the factories. He just came back from visiting a Panzer division in the area. They have a new Tiger tank that will crush the resistance. Soon the war will be over. Hogan asks Klink where the Panzer division is; Klink does not say.

After the assembly, back in the barracks, Hogan tells the men of an idea. They are going to steal a German tank, take it apart, and send the blueprints to England. Some of the men think this is a crazy idea. Hogan says that he came up with the idea, the rest is detail.

Later, in another building (the recreation hall), some of the prisoners are pulling ropes attached to the ceiling. They are attached to a side wall which will open when the ropes are pulled a certain way. A lookout at the door says that a guard is coming; then says that it is only Schultz. Schultz comes in and asks what is happening. Hogan tells Schultz that they are doing some remodeling; Hogan wants to have a view of the delousing station. How else can you get the tank in? Newkirk is dressed up as a Gestapo Lieutenant. At first, he fools Schultz, then Schultz recognizes him. Schultz asks Hogan what if the Gestapo would uncover what is going on here? Hogan tells Schultz that Newkirk is going to steal a tank. Schultz does not believe him.

Hogan goes to Klink's office; Klink says he is busy with paperwork. Hogan protests the interrogation by a Gestapo officer. Corporal Langenscheidt comes in and says that a Gestapo lieutenant is there. Klink says to let the Gestapo out.

Later, back in the barracks, Hogan tells the men the plans to grab the tank. LeBeau will escape after Newkirk brings the tank in. He will make contact with French Underground agent Tiger, change clothes, and bring him into camp. Just then, the assembly bell rings; Hogan says that it is 31 seconds early.

At roll call in front of the barracks, there are 14 present, 1 missing. Klink does not have time to ask about the missing prisoner when a tank comes in the gate. Newkirk, in a German uniform, is in the top ring of the tank; (the driver compartment is separate from the gunnery area; it does not show who is driving the tank). Newkirk, in a German accent, asks about rebellions prisoners; he sees none. He asks Klink why he requested a tank. Newkirk throws 'orders' down, Schultz picks them up, and gives them to Klink. As Klink starts to read the papers, Hogan tells Klink that 1 prisoner has escaped. Klink says to sound the alarm and let out the dogs. Schultz sends everybody back into the barracks; Hogan signals the men to go. Newkirk drives the tank around the area. Some of the prisoners open the side of a building, the tank goes in, and the men close the side of the building back up. Schultz sees this happen, but he just stands there with his mouth open and does nothing. When the tank gets inside, the men start swarming around the tank. Newkirk says that he just wanted an oil change.

Later, back in the barracks, there is a knock on the tunnel entrance to the barracks. LeBeau comes up the tunnel. Hogan asks LeBeau where is Tiger? LeBeau says that it just would not work out, changing clothes. Tiger is below, waiting to come up. He signals Tiger up. Tiger, a beautiful blonde, comes up from the tunnel; the men give her wolf whistles. Hogan did not realize that Tiger was a woman. Hogan asks where to put her up; Newkirk volunteers to share his cubicle.

Later, Newkirk is measuring Tiger for new clothes. Tiger talks to Hogan about a diversion. Tiger says that the tank is in pieces; Hogan says that it will be put back together. Schultz comes in. He says that Klink is boiling mad over the escape that is not an escape. After talking to Hogan for a few seconds, Schultz sees Tiger. He tells Hogan that this time, they went too far; then he says that he sees nothing.

Hogan goes to Klink's office. He sits down, but Klink says 'On your feet'. Klink says that his men were out all night looking for the prisoner that did not escape. There will be punishment for all prisoners: The recreation hall will be padlocked for 2 weeks. Klink says that a Tiger tank came in, and wants to know where it is; Hogan asks which gate it went out of. Just then, Klink gets a call from General Hofstader of the Panzer division that the tank came from. Hofstader wants to know where the tank is. Klink says that the tank will be found. The tank did not leave the camp; he will search the prisoners. Hogan says that it will show up.

In the barracks, Klink tells Hogan that Hofstader will be coming for the tank. Hogan says to give the tank back.

In Hogan's office, Tiger is in an American uniform. LeBeau and Tiger kiss twice on the cheek, French style. Tiger then apologizes to Hogan if she made his plans difficult. Tiger says that she volunteered, after hearing about the operation. She was curious about the man in charge. Just then, a bell rings - roll call. Hogan tells Tiger that it is roll call. They pause for a moment. Kinch comes in and says 'Roll call'. Hogan and Tiger seem to ignore Kinch for a few seconds, and Hogan leaves.

General Hofstader and two officers come into camp in a staff car led by a motorcycle. Hofstader tells Klink that he released a tank because of a prisoner riot. He sees no riot, and he sees no tank. All he sees is a colonel (Klink) about to become a corporal. Klink says that he will search the prisoners. Hofstader is mad, and says that they are talking about a tank, not a toy dump truck. Schultz goes down the line, counting the prisoners. When he gets to Newkirk's spot, Tiger is there. Schultz wants to know what she is doing there, and where is Newkirk. Hogan says that Newkirk will be there any time now.

At that moment, Newkirk is in the recreation hall on top of the tank. He reaches in the top of the tank, turns it on, and the tank rolls off. The tank breaks through the side of the building and starts going through the camp. The Germans give chase after the tank. Tiger grabs Hogan and kisses him. The tank breaks through the closed front gate, and Hofstader's staff car and a motorcycle go after it.

At the end, in Klink's office, Hogan is seen using Klink's pickelhelb helmet to break nuts, picking the helmet up by the point and smashing the nuts on Klink's desk. Klink says that strange occurrences have been happening. He asks Hogan for an explanation. Hogan says that Gestapo is doing it. Klink's efficiency is showing them up, and they are getting jealous. Hogan suggests setting up an escape, nothing big, just 15 to 20 men. Klink says that doing that is treason.

description: Hogan concocts a Kommandant of the Year award to distract Klink so a new Nazi rocket being stored protectively at Stalag 13 can be sabotaged.
tags: ['grape', 'scroll', 'impersonating a german officer', 'military aide', 'tattered uniform', 'sabotage', 'rocket', 'diversion', 'award', 'disguise', 'explosion', 'makeshift periscope', 'motorcycle', 'rocket launching', 'speech', 'thompson sub machine gun', 'scientist', 'commando', 'german shepherd', 'alarm', 'walkie talkie', 'schnapps', 'medal', 'antenna', 'submarine', 'coffee pot', 'hidden microphone', 'periscope', 'motorcycle with a sidecar', 'secret weapon']
synopsis_with_character_names:
With his new German rocket housed at Stalag 13, Major Hauser and his staff arrive and get out of the staff car.

Schultz, having caught Carter outside after final roll call, returns him to Barracks 2. Carter says he was only out to buy some beer from town, promising to be back by June, July at the latest.

A motorcycle with a sidecar leading a truck with something on it comes into camp. Hogan comes along, Carter reports that something big has been brought into camp, and Schultz, having been called a goon, exits.

Hogan pulls up the makeshift sink periscope (made from plumbing pipes and a food can that emerges from the rain barrel outside) to have a look. Schultz is nearby, so Hogan has to be careful looking. It's a big item, bigger than a breadbox and bigger than a piano, and Hogan figures it's in camp as Allied bombers would never attack a STALAG housed with their fellow soldiers.

Carter suggests they find out what the big item is and, if important enough, have the Allies bomb their camp anyway. Hogan takes him over to the front door, opens it, and orders Carter out. Carter says he might get shot. "That's right," says Hogan. Socially clueless Carter considers following these orders, but his mates pull him in and close the door.

Klink and Hauser are in Klink's office. Klink reads orders from General Burkhalter putting the camp at Major Hauser's disposal. Hauser wants Klink's assurance of absolute security at the camp. Klink says that the secret will not go beyond these walls, unaware that the microphone in the picture of Adolf Hitler on the wall that he stands next to is real, and the conversation is being listened to.

Hogan and his men stand around the coffee pot / listening device in Hogan's quarters, hearing every word from Klink's office. Hogan asks for more volume, but Kinch can't comply as the men have been using the coffee pot for making coffee, clogging the amplifier.

Hauser reveals that the big item is a new type of V-bomb with a volatile explosive to be taken to the coast for launching against England, keeping it safe at STALAG 13 for two days till its new launchpad is ready. Hauser's report to Burkhalter will speak favorably of Klink's cooperation; Klink reminds him that his name is spelled with a K.

Hogan takes Kinch down to the tunnel to contact their submarine. Kinch pumps the antenna handle, which raises their antenna from inside the flagpole flying the Nazi flag atop Klink's office.

Hogan (as Goldilocks) calls for the sub (Mama Bear). Hogan says that 'Miss Muffet' has a 'tuffet', and asks permission to destroy the rocket, to make the 'tuffet' go boom; but Mama Bear orders him to sit tight and call back in twelve hours.

LeBeau and Newkirk report they can't get near the heavily guarded rocket to check it out. Carter suggests tunneling under it through their wine cellar. LeBeau strongly objects, as this action would disturb their stored Chateau LaFite from its rest, chiding Americans for their low brow preference for hot dogs and beer.

Kinch delivers a message from the sub, telling them to expect a four-man team's arrival (Dr. Schneider, a scientist, with three commandos) to inspect the V-bomb, dropping in at 9:00PM. Newkirk asks how they get the men in. The men believe it'll be tough with Klink's raised security measures, for which Klink, jokingly, should receive a medal. This gives Hogan an idea: give Klink a medal and a scroll as Kommandant of the Year. Hogan asks what the metal shop is working on. Kinch replies that they are producing hand grenade paperweights (every third one live to give Gestapo men a real bang in their mail). Hogan has them stop these for a while to fashion an ornate medal with a German eagle clutching the throat of an Allied prisoner - "but friendly" - accompanied by a big, fancy, baroque scroll with cupids.

Kinch leaves to confirm the drop point. Carter leaves to order up the medal and scroll. Hogan instructs LeBeau to work up fake orders from General Burkhalter. LeBeau wonders how they can deliver these orders to Klink, to which Hogan points out Newkirk's reliably nimble pickpocket fingers (capable even if wearing boxing gloves). To demonstrate, Newkirk relieves LeBeau of a coin.

Later, a soldier arrives with the camp mail. LeBeau collides against him with a full trash barrel. Newkirk helps the soldier up and chides LeBeau for his clumsiness. (Unseen, the faux-Burkhalter document is passed.)

Schultz announces Hogan's request to see Klink. Klink blows off the request; Schultz says it's "urgent." Klink asks which colonel actually runs the camp, he or Hogan, adding that he sometimes wonders. Schultz merrily concurs, which rouses Klink's anger and prompts him to threaten sending Schultz to the Russian front. "Boy, are YOU running the camp," says Schultz. Sourly, Klink agrees to see Hogan.

Hogan says he's come with a complaint. Klink, presuming all prisoner complaints are trivial, sarcastically asks if the prisoners aren't sufficiently entertained or want more wine and caviar with the food they take from German mouths; to which Hogan replies that the commandant is funny enough and that he's particularly fond of caviar, which the commandant might send from the Russian front. Klink, now alarmed, thinks Hogan might have heard something, but it's just a lead-in to ask about the big thing in the yard.

Hogan takes out a copy of the Geneva Convention from his pocket. Reading from the Geneva Convention, Hogan reminds Klink of the illegality of subjecting POWs to unusual danger, tearing out and spiking that page onto Klink's Prussian helmet. Klink says he'll decide what constitutes danger and dismisses Hogan. While this discussion is going on, Hogan quietly puts the phone orders and letter on Klink's desk.

Before Hogan leaves, Klink finds the phony Burkhalter dispatch. STALAG 13 is one of the top 10 prison camps, and Klink is getting an award for Kommandant of the Year. He calls Hogan back. He reads that Colonel Schneider will arrive with his staff to present a medal and a scroll. Klink does not recall there being a Colonel Schneider on Burkhalter's staff. Hogan reminds Klink that Schneider is a very common German name and asks if his men can be allowed to parade. Granted.

Hogan talks Klink into preparing an acceptance speech, which Klink has given no thought to and wants to keep short, but Hogan talks him into preparing something of some length, such as 10 minutes, advising to leave out the ugly incident with the Munich Police.

Hogan's flattery has Klink feeling so good that Klink offers to share his schnapps in celebration. What does the Geneva book say to that?, he asks; to which Hogan looks in his Geneva convention book and replies "Only the good stuff," whereby Klink switches to his best bottle.

Hogan preps LeBeau for meeting the drop team. LeBeau deplores the unimaginative use of Big Bad Wolf and Little Red Riding Hood as identification codes. Hogan says if he wanted to be a writer he should have joined Special Services.

Outside the fence, LeBeau's walkie-talkie can't reach the drop team. From his own walkie-talkie, Goldilocks (Hogan) asks Big Bad Wolf (LeBeau) what's wrong. LeBeau can't find the recently-dropped men, and requests help, so Hogan sends Carter to tell Schultz that one of the men has gone over the wire.

Carter exits the barracks and calls for Shultz. He says that a man is missing. The tower guard swings a light on him and Schultz runs in, catching up his rifle in Carter's jacket. Schultz wants Carter to quiet down before he wakes everybody up. Carter asks why Schulz doesn't want the credit for discovering there's a missing man. Thinking about it, Schultz happily shouts that a prisoner has gone over the wire.

Alarm rings. German shepherds are released that quickly find LeBeau, who asks the friendly canines what took them so long. LeBeau tells them to track down the drop team. The dogs sit reluctantly. LeBeau says he's ashamed of them. Guilt-ridden, they turn and find the drop team.

The commandos wonder what to do about their damaged walkie-talkie, to which Doctor Schneider points out he had little to do with them at Caltech.

The commandos hear the dogs. The dogs and LeBeau arrive. Passwords are exchanged. LeBeau hears of their problems, that the wind blew them away from point M-14. LeBeau gives a notebook to a commando, and promptly begins taking their measurements, saying they'll be entering the camp in German uniforms tomorrow.

Mission accomplished, LeBeau returns with the dogs to the fence where he shouts his surrender and shames the amiable dogs into appropriate aggressive barking by calling them pussycats.

Next day. A staff car drives in carrying the drop team, now in German uniforms. Klink greets them warmly and invites them inside. Colonel Schneider introduces the commandos and Captain Hackenburg, Lieutenant Bauer, and Lieutenant Schmittburg. Hogan looks on, and LeBeau says Schneider's collar could do with a little more work.

Klink, Schneider, and other assemble on the platform for the award presentation. Later at the award ceremony, Hogan is in complete control of crowd reactions (which swing abruptly from enthusiastic applause and wild cheering to complete silence). He is standing behind Klink so Klink can not see his hand signals. Klink receives his medal and scroll, and starts his acceptance speech.

While Klink is speaking, Schneider sneaks unnoticed beneath the rocket canopy. Hogan means to join him but Schultz catches him. Hogan admits his aim, to sneak in and see the rocket, to which Schultz, exasperated, replies that he sees nothing, nothing.

Under the canopy, Hogan's arrival startles Schneider, busily photographing the controls. Hogan has the bomb, set to go off in a few minutes; Schneider shows where to place it to trigger the rocket's blast off. Hogan exits.

Catching Klink at the end of his speech, Hogan encourages him to say more and milk the moment.

As Schneider exits, his coat catches under the canopy. This gives Major Hauser time to notice him and come forward. In finally freeing his coat, Schneider strikes Hauser in the face. It would seem the jig is up, but Schneider keeps talking, admiring the major's rocket and deflecting the awkward moment by saying that Klink is a lousy speech-maker. Schneider tells Hauser that he worked on an original model. Hauser agrees about Klink and, proud of his rocket, invites Schneider back under the canopy for a personal tour. Schneider dares not refuse, even with the bomb set to explode any minute.

Klink launches into another personal story that feels right for the occasion.

As Schneider fears for his life, Hauser points out some of his many implemented safeguards against accidental firing. Schneider slips out as Hauser begins to demonstrate how the rocket can not be fired. He even puts the switch in the 'remote' position and pushes 'fire', the rocket should not fire. Just as Hauser presses the firing button "in complete safety," the bomb explodes and the rocket launches.

Klink, having dropped to the ground, asks what happened. Hogan says one of his rockets is missing. Hauser, soot-faced and in torn clothes, staggers from the rocket transport and declares a catastrophe. Klink agrees - his medal has disappeared. Hogan says that they will make him a new one.

Back in his office with Hogan, Klink, his camp's reputation destroyed, frets over the direness of Hauser's report to Burkhalter in Berlin. Schultz enters with news, but Klink is entirely taken up by the rocket's loss. Klink is afraid of being sent to the Russian front. Hogan suggests they claim Hauser was drunk and eager to fire his rocket at England. Though far-fetched, Klink agrees that it could pass.

Finally paying attention to Schultz, Klink takes the Berlin report from his hand. Terrible news. The rocket landed in the Hamburg Airfield, destroying half of it. Klink leaves to see if Major Hauser has a better lie than Hogan's to explain it.

Left alone together, Schultz pronounces Hogan's destruction of the airport as naughty-naughty. Hogan's glibly replies that his aim is terrible when in a hurry.

description: Hogan must reverse course when efforts to make Klink look competent before the Nazi Inspector General get the Kommandant promoted with a transfer to Berlin.
tags: ['promotion', 'inspection', 'reference to napoleon', 'stolen engine', 'impersonating an enemy soldier', 'secret radio', 'inspector', 'falling into a hole', 'german shepherd', 'dog licking face', 'explosion', 'radio']
synopsis_with_character_names:
With three minutes left before roll call, Hogan goes over plans for blowing up an ammunition train: Explosions set off in camp divert the guards, after which Newkirk reports POW Olsen missing. Olsen escapes in the dog truck with the dogs sent out to look for Olsen. Olsen will blow up the train with dynamite stored near the tracks. All events to begin by Hogan tipping his cap.

Hogan further admonishes his men against making things too complicated by ad libbing their parts. Keep it simple. A simple, diversion, a simple escape, and a simple explosion.

Kinchloe enters, announcing a guard coming. Hogan rolls up the map hanging from the bunk bed and rolls down the drawing of a girl. Schultz enters as if walking in upon Hogan lecturing his men on women, which he explains as a once-every-six-months army regulation. Schultz disbelieves this. Hogan asks if he wants to know what's really going on, and Schultz says no.

Schultz rousts everyone out for roll call - all but Hogan, whom the Kommandant wants to see. To Kinch and Carter, Hogan changes his signal from tipping his cap to merely coming out if Klink's office.

Klink tells Hogan of the immanent visit to the camp of Inspector General von Platzen, the Inspector General of the Armies of the Third Reich. Hogan wonders why he wasn't previously informed. Klink speculates that Hogan would like to see him replaced by a less strict, less vigilant, less efficient kommandant, disbelieving Hogan's statement that he would do anything to keep Klink around.

Klink warns that, during the inspection visit, he will keep his eyes on Hogan. Klink tells Hogan not to try anything.

Cpl. Langenscheidt enters to announce the arrival of General von Platzen. The news shatters the fragile confidence of Kommandant Klink, who begins to worry deeply of the visit's outcome.

Klink (with Hogan nearby) greets von Platzen in the outer office. Von Platzen's eye is immediately drawn to secretary Helga's beauty. Klink introduces Hogan, to whom von Platzen eventually turns his attention.

Hogan complains about the food, which pleases Von Platzen. If POW "Bogan" didn't complain about the food, he'd immediately know something was wrong with the camp.

With his eye straying back to Helga, von Platzen suggests they go outside and inspect the staff later. "Grogan," knowing his exit will set off his team's plans, tries unsuccessfully to remain indoors.

Stepping outside, Hogan tries warning off his men from the plan, but none catch his meaning and set off the arranged events. As Schultz counts off the men, Carter sets off his bombs, and Olsen heads for the dog truck. All drop to the ground, and von Platzen declares they're under attack from barbaric B-17s now bombing prison camps. Klink declares it the fault of German leaders claiming German soil sacred. Hogan declares it a thunderstorm.

As Olsen hides in the dog truck, Newkirk asks Carter about any more of his "firecrackers," to which Carter says just one more. Newkirk declares you'd think there was a war on. He then gets to Schultz to say he thinks there's a man missing. Schultz, flat on the ground for protection, says "Who cares?!"

Schultz finally announces a prisoner missing. Klink calls for an alarm and the release of the dogs, chiding soldiers laying on the ground behind him (as he was) for being cowards.

As the dog truck begins to leave camp, Hogan opens the back and pulls Olsen out. Olsen doesn't understand, and Hogan merely says it's a complicated war before a German shepherd guard dog comes up and licks his face.

Back in Klink's office, von Platzen reviews the facts while also noticing Klink's cigars. Hogan strikes a match against Klink's Prussian helmet and lights von Platzen's cigar.

Ready for dictation, Helga asks if she should take down everything. Von Platzen says she can mainly just sit there looking pretty, to which Hogan responds "Thanks, I will."

Von Platzen asks for an explanation from Klink, then from Hogan. Klink declares the events a plot to discredit him, calling Hogan a man who'd like to see Klink removed. Olsen has been locked up for thirty days and the entire camp punished for three weeks without exercise privileges. Barracks are being torn apart and searched for further explosives. "Doogan" says that this was a legitimate escape attempt, and declares Klink an inhuman beast and the events perpetrated by men tortured beyond their limits of endurance.

Von Platzen finds it a strange coincidence that all this should have occurred during his visit, to which Hogan admits it was due to a slip up in their intelligence (a rare touch of honesty before the Germans). Von Platzen commends Hogan for his grandstand gesture in foiling the escape, though it would make him a fink to his own men.

In review of STALAG 13's history, von Platzen finds it had been a miserable camp until Klink's arrival. Other camps have suffered wholesale escapes while STALAG 13 went escape-free. Von Platzen tells Klink that his record is under review in Berlin. Klink has 20 years in grade, longer than anyone; his efficiency is one degree above miserable - until he came to STALAG 13. Klink, suspecting he'll be fired from his post, asks if he will be retained. "No," says von Platzen. He is to be promoted and moved to Berlin where he will be put in charge of all prison camps, having finally found his niche. He wants Klink to bring along his 'personal staff', meaning Helga. Hogan is floored. Von Platzen admits it was Hogan's hostility and fear that finally convinced the Inspector General of this as the right move. Hogan says that sometimes he talks too much.

Returning to the barrack humbled, Hogan admits his own guilt in over-embellishment, for which he earlier chided the men. He says that he is sorry, and made Klink look too good. The new plan: make Klink look bad but keep it small. He sends LeBeau (who'd like to either explode or set fire to Klink's office) down tunnel #4 to put Plan Alpha into action. To the rest, wing it.

With Schultz, von Platzen and two guards, Klink attends one last inspection of the barracks. The prisoners line up in front of some bunks. Nimble-fingered Newkirk moves first, laying hands upon the inspector over a loose button in order to lift his monocle and set it in Klink's hand, leaving von Platzen aghast at Klink's petty thievery. As Hogan begins an explanation, he signals Kinch to turn on a radio, which relays a British news broadcast. Klinch quietly flips a switch under a bunk.

Klink turns on Schultz about the radio's location. In abject fear, Schultz stammers that no one told him about it. Klink tells Schultz to find the radio. As guards begin a search, Klink, trying to intimidate, asks Hogan where the voice comes from. Presenting a thoughtful look, Hogan says, "From the accent, I'd say England."

At a signal, Kinch clicks off the radio.

Displeased, von Platzen confronts Klink about the explosions on arrival, a funny kommandant, and prisoners tuned into the BBC. Hogan brightens to Klink's sarcastic suggestion that he begin giving the prisoners weekend passes to London. Klink promises that Schultz will find the radio if he has to tear apart the barracks with his teeth. In suggesting they leave before he finds his wallet missing, von Platzen finds his wallet missing, which Klink discovers in his own breast pocket. Angered, von Platzen declares that the Nazis don't need pickpockets running their prison camps.

As von Platzen exits, Hogan takes the opportunity to finally congratulate Klink on his promotion.

All exit.

As Klink, von Platzen, and three of von Platzen's aides cross the yard, the prisoners enjoy LeBeau's efforts in carrying out Plan Alpha, watching von Platzen himself walk right into a collapsing hole. "A tunnel!" he shouts.

Hogan joins them to admit it's his tunnel. Klink declares he'll trace it to its origin and lock up the men he finds for at least six months, to which Hogan says it comes from Klink's headquarters where it just seemed easier.

Von Platzen gets mad at Klink and promises to write up this "black page" of a camp when he returns to Berlin. As the inspector retreats to Klink's headquarters, Hogan tells Klink he certainly hopes this won't stand in the way of his promotion.

Soon thereafter, Hogan is astonished to learn that Carter, going too far, took the engine from von Platzen's car. What made Carter think about taking the motor? Because it was there. Fearing for Klink and thinking fast, Hogan orders Carter and LeBeau into German uniforms and sends Kinch to requisition another staff car.

Klink begs von Platzen to stay another day, to which von Platzen admits if he did he'd have Klink shot. Apparently there is nothing Klink can do to assuage the inspector's anger.

Engaging the inspector's staff car sets off an explosion and a smoke bomb, sending the Germans to hit the ground. Von Platzen thinks Klink is trying to kill him, to which Klink says he couldn't be more fond of the inspector even if he was Klink's own brother. He orders the fearful Schultz to investigate the motor immediately. Relieved, Schultz finds only a smoke bomb but also reports the motor missing; he says 'What motor?'

Von Platzen asks Klink if he's competent enough to arrest himself before professional men can be reached to do it. He calls for another staff car and will hear nothing further from Klink. A staff car arrives. To further distance himself from his STALAG 13 experiences, the Inspector only wants to be taken to the railroad station where he can return to Berlin by train. Peering into the car, Schultz spots Carter and LeBeau in the front seat, Carter driving, both dressed as German soldiers. He winces and looks away.

As the inspector is driven off to the depot, Hogan approaches Klink and merrily says, "Looks like you're one of us now."

In Klink's office, Hogan pilfers a few cigars from Klink's cigar box, as Klink, at the window, finds himself beyond hating him and sadly accepts the end of his career. Hogan cites Napoleon facing times when all seemed lost while hanging onto a star of destiny, encouraging Klink to do the same and think of a miracle where his "star" might carry him through. What miracle should Klink concentrate upon? Hogan suggests believing in a train blowing up. Klink says he believes. Hogan checks his watch and recommends he say it again. Klink "believes" again, then finds it ridiculous right before an explosion rocks the area. Klink's confidence returns now that no negative report on him will reach Berlin.

Scene fades with Klink's hand tucked into the front of his coat, Bonaparte fashion.

At the end, the men are in the barracks, Schultz comes in and tells Hogan that Klink wants him to find the radio. Hogan tells Kinch to help. Kinch opens a footlocker and shows some radios and a bunch of watches. Schultz picks a radio. Hogan asks Schultz for $26 dollars, just $10 above cost. He asks Schultz 'Do you want us to make money?' Schultz starts counting out the money.

description: Hogan's efforts to help a German baroness to escape are thwarted by Klink, who has arranged for the transfer of a British prisoner who is senior to Colonel Hogan.
tags: ['outranked', 'escape', 'baroness', 'airplane', 'wire cutter', 'single engine airplane', 'playing timpani', 'head bandage', 'digging a tunnel', 'hit on the head', 'music episode', 'diversion', 'wagner ride of the valkyries']
synopsis_with_character_names:
This is the first appearance of Colonel (Group Captain) Crittenden in the series. Col. Klink has Crittenden transferred from STALAG 18; Crittenden supposedly outranks Hogan by date of rank.

At the start, the dog truck comes into camp at night. A woman gets out of the truck. This is Baroness Lily von Schlichter (played by Louise Troy, a future Mrs. Werner Klemperer) who wants to defect. LeBeau has to get the dog out of the dog house so he can lift it up; he takes the baroness down into the tunnel. Lily says that she will never get out, as her picture is all over Germany. Hogan says that he will get her out by plane, they are building one. Lily asks if she is safe here; LeBeau smiles at her and says not if he can help it.

In Klink's office, Hogan and Klink are talking. Klink wants to tell a joke, about being at a racetrack and betting on 8 in a row. Klink then says that since Hogan came to STALAG 13, strange things have been happening. Recently, a plane was shot down but the pilot was not found. There is a German defector in the area that has not been found, and trains are blowing up. Klink suggests that Hogan is bad luck. Klink tells Corporal Langenscheidt to being in Colonel Crittenden. Crittenden has been in STALAG 18, and Klink had him transferred here. He says that Crittenden has 12 years seniority by date of rank on Hogan, so Hogan is no longer the senior prisoner of war officer in this camp. Crittenden comes in and talks with Hogan and Klink. He asks about morning calisthenics and parade; Hogan says that there are no morning exercises or parades. Crittenden is disappointed.

Hogan goes back to the barracks. In his office, Hogan is packing up his things and tells the men about what is going on. Crittenden has arrived, and Hogan is no longer the senior officer there. Carter says that they can ignore Crittenden; Hogan says that that is wrong. Just then, Crittenden comes in. Hogan tries to introduce the men, but Crittenden stops him. Crittenden says that there are no calisthenics or parades, so the men are getting flabby. Crittenden says that he made 11 escape attempts, and was caught every time. Hogan gives Crittenden a hypothetical situation, briefly describing what is going on at the camp. Crittenden says that he would hand over information to the Germans. After some more discussion, Crittenden leave, Carter and Newkirk go with him.

In another building, Hogan talks to Lily in the plane. He tells her that he found Lieutenant Harris and plane parts, and are putting the plane back together. Lily says that this is a fantastic operation. Hogan tells her that Crittenden is now in charge. Just then, they hear digging. Hogan hears it and says that it might be one of us. Crittenden breaks through the wall, sees the plane and Lily. Hogan then drops a wrench on Crittenden's head, and Crittenden gets knocked out.

Shortly later, outside, Newkirk is putting bandages on Crittenden's head. Newkirk says that the whole tunnel caved in. Crittenden, now awake, says that he saw some things; Hogan says that it was a mirage. Hogan says that Crittenden saw a plane and a woman; Crittenden surprisingly says yes. Crittenden says that we need a diversion; musical instruments.

Hogan convinces Klink to have a Camp Orchestra. Schultz comes to Hogan's office; Hogan is shown two playing kettle drums. Schultz says that a female spy is walking around the camp. Schultz caught Lily. Lily tells Hogan that the Gestapo put her in a cell underground and she did not like where she was. Hogan wants to put her in a tunnel. Hogan then looks out the office door, and sees Crittenden coming. Hogan tries to hide lily; he turns her around and puts his cap on her. Crittenden comes in and starts talking to Hogan. Crittenden sees Lily and take her cap off. Crittenden says that they could be shot; he says that prisoners must try to escape, but in all other manners cooperate with the Germans. Lily tells Crittenden that she is fighting for the same cause. Crittenden wants to turn her in; after some convincing from Hogan, he gives her 24 hours.

In a tent in camp, the men are finishing up work on the plane. The construction noise is covered up by an 'orchestra practicing', actually a record player turned up loud playing "Flight of the Valkyrie". Klink is in his office listening, and pretending to 'direct' the orchestra. He says that he will be carried off to Valhalla. Helga asks Klink if he is volunteering for active duty. Sgt. Schultz, while standing guard, acts out the music. He goes inside the tent, sees the phonograph next to Kinchloe, sees the plane, and sees Lily. Hogan tells Schultz that Crittenden is in charge. Where is he? Hogan does not know.

The music stops; Crittenden, Newkirk, and Carter are at the fence, about to break out.

In the tent, Baroness Lily kisses Hogan good-bye and gets in the plane. The plane starts up.

At the fence, Crittenden cuts some fence wire, and the fence section falls down. The plane revs its engine, the tent opens, and Crittenden goes outside the camp. Crittenden wants Newkirk and Carter to escape with him, but now that Crittenden is outside the fence, Hogan is now senior officer again, and they would rather stay. Newkirk tells Crittenden to get out of the way, as this is now a landing strip. Crittenden sees the plane coming and gets out of the way. Then the plane, with Baroness Lily and the pilot (a shot-down pilot Hogan is sending back to England) fly off. Hogan waves. The plane that flies out looks superficially like a single-engined B-25 with 2 tail fins.

In Klink's office, Klink says that he hears a motor, looks out the window, goes outside, and tells Schultz to start shooting. The plane gets away.

At the end, Hogan and Klink are in Klink's office. Klink asks for an explanation. Hogan says to ask Crittenden. Klink put Crittenden in the cooler. Hogan says that there have been no escapes; he and Klink make quite a team. Klink transfers Crittenden back to STALAG 18. He asks Hogan if Crittenden was responsible. Hogan says that they both had to lose him, he was bad luck.

description: When a British commando unit is captured before they can blow up a crucial German ammo dump, Hogan and his men attempt to finish the job.
tags: ['heidenheim germany', 'shackelitis', 'commando', 'fire', 'bunk', 'bucket of dirt', 'burgermeister', 'kiss', 'girlfriend', 'candle', 'flame', 'singing', 'frere jacques', 'santa claus', 'christmas tree', 'christmas present', 'new england', 'chain', 'sweaty face', 'playing chess', 'ammunition depot', 'time bomb', 'champagne', 'general', 'wine cellar', 'disguised as santa claus']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, the prisoners are lined up in front of the barracks, and Schultz is taking roll call. Klink asks Hogan how many prisoners there are supposed to be. Hogan says 15. Klink says correction, 16. There is a new prisoner. There was a commando raid on a nearby ammunition depot, and the commandos were captured; one of the seven was sent to STALAG 13. While Klink walks down the line of prisoners talking about escaping from STALAG 13, Hogan slaps Klink on the back with a dirty hand, leaving an oil mark on Klink's uniform. Schultz says that he shouldn't do that to the Kommandant. Hogan responds that the Germans won't give them a roller towel.

Shortly later, Hogan and the new prisoner, RAF Sergeant Walters with an arm in a sling, are walking in the compound talking about the raid. They were raiding the headquarters of General Schmidt. There is going to be an offensive someplace, but they don't know where. Walters tells Hogan that they set the timers, put the other charges in place; but they were not able to finish the job. Just connect the wires. Walters talks about German General Schmidt, the commander of the ammunition depot. Walters also tells Hogan that the other commandos were sent to Kleinfeldt prison camp.

Hogan goes to Klink's office, and leads Klink on to something he knows. He tries to leave, but Klink stops him. mentions a rumor that they are closing the camp. Klink denies the rumor. They why did they only send him one commando (and one with a broken wing), and sent the others to another camp. Hogan convinces Klink to make a phone call to get the other commandos. Klink calls headquarters, wants the other 6, he will send a truck. Hogan gives Klink a scarf as a gift. Klink says that he has one just like it; it actually is his scarf that Hogan took from the coat rack, and is giving it back to him.

That night, Hogan and Carter in black commando garb go to the ammo depot in a side tarpaulin of a truck that is rolled up. Hogan finds the timer in a wine storage room, turns it on, and sets it to 20 minutes. They hear General Schmidt and a fraulein (not named in the show but appears in the credits as 'Fraulein') talking in the next room. They run out of wine, so Schmidt goes to the back room to get some more wine. Hogan sees him coming and gives a full wine bottle to Carter, telling him to do the honors. The General comes in the room, and after some near misses, Carter knocks out Schmidt. The fraulein hears a noise, and goes to the back room. Hogan grabs her and gives her a big kiss, saying auf weidersehn, making her think he is Schmidt. She can not see well as the lights in the room are off. She then picks her coat up and leaves through the front door. Before they leave, Hogan wants to take Schmidt prisoner, and take him with them while he is still unconscious. If the Germans have an American prisoner, why can't the American prisoners have a German prisoner?

The next day, a truck comes into STALAG 13 with the 6 commandos that Klink requested. Hogan and Newkirk are also in the truck, unbeknownst to the driver. Hogan comes out of the truck in a formal smoking jacket. Hogan asks Schultz how many prisoners; Schultz says 6. Hogan tells Schultz that there should be 7 prisoners, not 6. He tells Schultz at first that he is missing a prisoner; then he 'finds' the prisoner in the back of the truck. He quickly writes down the name 'Finnegan' on the prisoner list and changes the number from 6 to 7.

Hogan goes to Klink's office, Klink has the sheet of hew prisoners. Hogan looks at the list and gasps. He says that there is an escape artist on the list. At first, he does not want to say who he is, leading Klink on. Then he points to the name 'Finnegan' on the list. Just then, General Schmidt, in a prisoner's uniform, comes to Klink's office, angry that they think he is a prisoner. Hogan says that he recognizes him. Hogan silently suggests to Klink, by pointing, that Schmidt is the escape artist. Schmidt insists that he is indeed General Schmidt. Klink says that Schmidt was blown up with the ammo depot. Hogan then says that he really is General Schmidt. After some discussion, Klink calls the guard, and has him hauled out of the room. The guard pushes Schmidt out of the room backwards with his sub-machine gun.

Later, Hogan talks to Schmidt while walking in the compound. Hogan says that he believes that he is Schmidt, and insults Klink for not believing it. Hogan wants to get a message out to Schmidt's staff; Schmidt is puzzled on how he can do that. How? Bribe a guard. Schmidt, thinking that something is going on, says that he can not get a message out for 5 days. Schmidt walks off, and Newkirk comes by to talk to Hogan. Hogan says that Schmidt will not tell him anything and that Schmidt will not talk to save his life; or will he? Hogan tells Newkirk that we have a job for the Mighty Hogan Art Players.

Later, In the barracks, Hogan tells Schmidt that he recognized him from his picture; but his neck is fuller. Schmidt is playing a chess game with himself; he plays a black move, then turns the board around and plays white. Hogan asks Schmidt if his neck is always that thick. Hogan is giving him a set up for a disease he is trying to convince Schmidt that he has. Hogan says that two prisoners, Kelly and Johnson, went just like that last week, snapping his fingers. Schmidt asks Hogan what he wants. Hogan says that Germany is winning the war, and that he wants to be the burgermeister of Cleveland after the war. Schmidt says no Cleveland. Hogan says that Schmidt has symptoms, fever, burning up. As he says this, he kicks the wall, and a board with lit candles slides under the bunk that Schmidt is in. Newkirk dresses in cold weather gear and offers Schmidt hot soup. Newkirk calls for Hogan saying that Schmidt is perspiring. Hogan asks for more blankets, as Schmidt may have 'shackelitis'. Newkirk gets a blanket, and while putting it on Schmidt, other prisoners put chains on Schmidt's legs under the blanket, hiding them so Schmidt can not see them. LeBeau comes in acting fearfully, talking about the two prisoners that were lost last week, and now him. Hogan talks about chills and shakes, and hooks up the bunk to rods in the other room. Newkirk and Kinchloe move the bunk back and forth slowly with the rods, making Schmidt think he is shaking. The candles put the bedding on fire; Hogan says that Schmidt's fever is so hot it set the bedding on fire. LeBeau brings in a large box, implying that it is a coffin. Hogan says not yet, and LeBeau wheels it back out. Hogan wants Schmidt for a name to notify; Schmidt says not yet.

Hogan and Kinch are in the tunnel, with Kinch talking on the radio to London. They are preparing for the attack, but need to know where it is going to be. Hogan says that Schmidt is about to crack, and prepare for 'Operation Reindeer'. Kinch calls London, as Goldilocks calling Papa Bear.

Then, with Schmidt still in bed sweating, the men come in singing Jingles Bells like it is Christmas. Schmidt says that Christmas is 3 months away. Hogan implies that Schmidt will not last that long. Schultz comes in dressed as Santa Claus. Newkirk gives Schmidt a magazine, but Hogan says that there is no point in starting serials. Hogan and the men then sing 'Good King Wenceslas'. Schmidt then breaks, and says to send a message to Major Umbly in Heidelheim. The men start singing 'Heidelheim' to the tune of 'Frere Jacques'. Schmidt asks if the message will get through; Hogan says that the message will get through. Schmidt asks Hogan how he can thank him; Hogan says to throw in Cincinnati (referring to when he asked Schmidt to be burgermeister of Cleveland).

At the end, two prisoners to escape come up through the tunnel; they are to take the place of Walters and 'Finnegan'. Walters and Schmidt are dressed up in civilian clothes, waiting to go down the tunnel. Walters is to take Schmidt with him. They are to go to London, where Schmidt will wait out the war in a prison camp. As they go down the tunnel under the bunk, Hogan tells Schmidt to look more German and not to talk. Hogan tells Schmidt to act like a real German, which for him should be easy.

description: In order to steal enough explosives to blow up a difficult bridge, Hogan's men paint anti-Nazi graffiti on the camp's ammo building.
tags: ['time bomb', 'roll call', 'paint color sampler', 'reference to tommy dorsey', 'reference to jimmy dorsey', 'reference to the andrews sisters', 'reference to bing crosby', 'heckling', 'checkpoint', 'episode title spoken by character', 'braunstadt', 'tunnel', 'graffiti', 'bridge', 'motorcycle with a sidecar', 'painting', 'picking lock', 'erlenmeyer flask', 'condenser', 'aerial bombardment', 'arrow', 'consolidated b 24 liberator', 'motorcycle', 'explosion']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Schultz finishes an evening roll call; all 15 men present. Klink thanks Hogan for requesting a special roll call to deter a few "hot heads" from enacting an escape. Hogan walks around to the other side of Klink, forcing Klink to turn so that he does not see the ranks of prisoners. Hogan gives his men an "at ease." While talking further with Klink, Hogan checks his watch and tells his men to "Smoke 'em if you have 'em." The men spread out and light up with their lighters.

From the air, two Allied bomber pilots spot the lighters of the smoking men, who form a perfect arrow for them to follow and bomb the Adolf Hitler Bridge.

At next morning's roll call, Klink announces the Allied airplanes' latest yet mostly unsuccessful attempt to bomb the Adolf Hitler Bridge. The men cheer the attempt and boo its failure.

As Klink gloats over the superiority of German defenses, Carter heckles back "We'll get the bridge next time, Fritz, baby!" Klink puts a halt to the "American insolence" and orders the heckler to take two steps forward. All of Hogan's men take two steps forward. Schultz says not all should have stepped forward and says to step back. They all step back. Schultz says that's wrong, and the men step forward again. Hogan wishes Schultz would make up his mind, Newkirk calls it a lovely day for a walk anyway, and Carter says they should've packed a lunch.

Unamused, Klink punishes everyone by closing the recreation hall for a week. Hogan calls depriving his men access to their Tommy Dorsey records a cruel, inhuman, sadistic punishment. In response, Klink orders the hall closed for two weeks, instead.

In Hogan's private quarters, the men discuss the failure of the bombers, which should have worked. Since the incident has made Klink "nasty happy," Hogan decides they should make him "nasty unhappy" and knock out the bridge themselves.

Disregarding the problem of delivery for now, Hogan looks into the problem of explosives. Carter reports they only have a can of lighter fluid and three firecrackers left over from when they celebrated Chinese New Year (claiming LeBeau was part Chinese). LeBeau recalls making a pot of chow mein from sauerkraut. Hogan recoils at the memory.

According to Carter, the easiest bomb to make would be from gas, maybe chlorine gas from ammonia and bleach. Kinch says the Germans keep those chemicals in their kitchen for cleaning. Hogan sends Newkirk to volunteer for kitchen duty, and sends Kinch to help Carter setup a bomb factory in tunnel Number 3. LeBeau asks what he can do, and Hogan say he's holding him in reserve. If all else fails, LeBeau can try poisoning the bridge with another batch of sauerkraut chow mein.

As Carter begins the delicate mix of chemicals in the tunnel, Hogan exits with Kinch, but just as they turn a corner, the chemicals explode. Coming 'round the corner, Carter, dirtied, declares that the chemical mix is pretty unstable. Kinch worries about Klink rushing in to investigate the source of their noise, but Hogan thinks he can cover it and tells Carter to keep working.

At roadside, LeBeau hangs a freshly made sign over an existing one, saying "Danger, Blasting Area, New construction, Proceed cautiously."

In the tunnel, Carter's chemicals begin to hiss. He backs away quickly. The batch explodes. At roadside, LeBeau steadies himself against the sign post before rushing back to camp.

Helga has Klink sign several papers. Klink declares there'd be no war without requisitions.

Schultz enters and, upon confronting Helga, flirtatiously greets her with "Wie gehts, baby." His face quickly drops its smile when he sees Klink in the room. Helga exits.

Klink wants to hear about the prisoners' reaction to his closing the recreation hall, pleased when Schultz tells of their unhappiness at being separated from their Tommy Dorsey records. Among the usual name-calling against Colonel Klink, Schultz reports a new one spoken by Hogan about his parents being baboons. Schultz, amused by this newest slander and ready to relay the rest of Hogan's comments, fails to note Klink's sudden indignation. Klink is immediately disinterested in hearing more, to which Schultz, to protect himself, attests that he did not listen.

In the tunnel, Carter's latest mixture, handled with long tongs, bubbles and hisses. Klink and Schultz hear the blast as the office shakes.

Anticipating an increase in escape activity during this disciplinary period, Klink instructs Schultz to make spot checks on all barracks and look for signs of tunnel digging.

Another explosion shakes the office.

Klink, having earlier called Berlin about the explosions, believes they're connected to a top secret project, since Berlin claims no knowledge of them. Schultz decried being told of this as a secret, since he is such a blabbermouth, and chuckles at Berlin, saying "Those devils - always up to something." Klink reminds him that he's talking about headquarters, and Schultz apologizes.

Klink tells Schultz to claim ignorance if prisoners ask about the explosions. Schultz says he's very good at being ignorant, and Klink agrees.

Klink dismisses Schultz, another explosion rocks the office, and Hitler's picture falls from the wall.

Another explosion rocks the barracks and flattens LeBeau's soufflé into a cake. Kinch hears tapping and shushes the guys. Carter's in trouble. They rush to open a footlocker and pull Carter, dazed and shaken, up through it. "Hello, Mom," he greets Hogan.

Hogan asks LeBeau for water, and LeBeau drinks it, claiming he's nervous. Kinch says to give it to Carter, and LeBeau splashes the remaining water into Carter's face. Carter says he's okay, but in trying to stand falls forward (caught by Kinch). He looks at LeBeau (thinking it's Hogan) to say he's fine and just needs a couple more shots to nail the bomb recipe. Another couple of shots and none of 'em will be around anymore, says Hogan. LeBeau asks if he should make some chow mein.

Newkirk announces guards coming. Carter is quickly lifted into bed and the footlocker put right. The men hustle into casual positions, with Kinch and Newkirk at the table playing cards.

Schultz enters and notices Carter looking terrible. Claiming he's sick, LeBeau feeds Carter from a bowl as another prisoner wipes at Carter's soiled face. Schultz says they'll take him to the hospital, at which Hogan signals Newkirk.

Newkirk quickly waltzes Schultz into a game of poker and they begin to play. Schultz' subordinate announces everything checks out. Displeased with his cards, Schultz throws them down and exits.

Hogan says they still have to figure how to make more ammunition. Carter says he's still willing to try, and Hogan asks him who's side he's on.

Newkirk says it's a pity they don't have five hundred of the few bullets he just proudly pinched from Schultz, saying they'd make a lovely bomb and that he needed to stay in practice or lose his nimble-fingered edge.

Hogan's new idea from looking at the bullets: Blow up the Adolf Hitler Bridge with the Nazi's own ammunition. He pulls down a map of the camp from a bunk to show where they can tunnel up from Tunnel #3 to get into the ammo shed. Carter, recovering his senses by now, delivers the bad news that the last explosion caved in fifty feet of that needed tunnel to get there, which Kinch projects will take them a month of digging to get through.

Undeterred, Hogan asks Newkirk if he can pick a lock (which Newkirk claims is an insulting question) and asks LeBeau for the rest of his sign-painting paint to "paint Klink into a corner."

Later (or the next day), Schultz, astonished, spots graffiti on the ammo shed: "Hess is a mess, Himmler is a rat fink, Goering is a fat rat fink, Klink is bucking for rat fink." He's amused at the last one but catches himself and runs to report it.

While the graffiti appalls Klink, Hogan blows it off as just a boyish prank brought on by men being denied their Tommy Dorsey records. Hogan chides Klink over getting upset over a small matter that won't take but a couple of hour for his guards to paint over. His men?? Klink orders Hogan's men to paint over those slogans at once (just what Hogan wanted).

Klink orders Schultz to get paint and brushes for Hogan's men right away. As Hogan protests against Klink ordering his men to paint the building, ignoring "all the rules of civilized warfare," he simultaneously instructs Schultz to get a large tarp and long ladders. Klink finally cuts him off, demanding silence against having the men paint the building throughout the entire war - in chains.

With the tarp in place over the doorway and Schulz looking on, Hogan orders Newkirk to paint the door trim. Under the tarp, Newkirk quickly picks the lock and enters. As Newkirk starts draining the shells of their gunpowder, Hogan orders LeBeau to start work on the door.

Newkirk reports it'll take some time to complete the job. Hogan acknowledges. Newkirk asks Schultz' permission to visit the "up" for a minute. Granted. As LeBeau works on draining more bullets, Hogan tells Kinch to water down the paint as they need more time.

Schultz notes the "heavy traffic" involved with this painting project (prisoners to and froing with stolen gunpowder). Hogan blames it in on his men needing to clear their heads of paint fumes. As LeBeau passes by back to the ammo shed, Schultz wishes he had "a drug store on THIS corner."

Later, with graffiti still showing through, Klink sees that the building isn't finished and orders Hogan to do it right.

Later still, Klink returns to see that the POWs have now indeed covered up the slogans but with pink paint. Klink threatens to consider turning over the men to the Gestapo, while Hogan finds the war a bit drab and in need of some color. "Paint it again!" Klink shouts. Hogan summons Carter, who carries a board with color samples. Carter recommends Blue Lagoon, while Schultz says his wife prefers Shocking Burgundy. Hogan expresses his interest in Chartreuse, which Carter finds sadly typical of an officer. "Just paint it as all the other buildings," shouts Klink and exits. Hogan says he has no imagination.

Carter has all of the powder in a box that he tapes up. Now Hogan has his bomb, which Carter says will go boom from the set timer. At LeBeau's inquiry, Hogan explains they'll deliver the bomb to the bridge via the division messenger, who drops by every day on his motorcycle to pick up mail. Tomorrow he'll have their "extra package." The timing can be determined by the distance to the bridge and Germany's strict orders against all rear echelon drivers exceeding a forty mph speed limit.

The courier arrives and enters the office building. LeBeau mounts his motorbike while Newkirk unbuttons the cover on its sidecar and walks off. The courier returns with a pouch and a large food can and asks what Louie is doing. He pulls LeBeau off his bike, and Louie keeps him distracted in an argument while Newkirk and Carter slip their box into his sidecar. Newkirk then buttons the tarp on the sidecar. With their task complete, LeBeau apologizes and the courier drives away.

The men are pleased until Schultz comes out of the office and complains about the man charging ten marks to make a special side trip to Dusseldorf to deliver a pound of coffee to his wife. Worried, the men return to barracks.

Kinch and Hogan are talking about the route the messenger takes. Newkirk says that he talked with Schultz, and he says that there are 3 checkpoints on the route, numbers 5, 7, and 9. They figure that they need to have checkpoint #9 contacted to dissuade the courier from any detour to Dusseldorf and keep him on schedule. Hogan orders them to start sweating about it and heads to Klink's office.

As the courier drives along his route, Klink reacts to Hogan's announcement of his men bribing the courier. Klink calls in Helga to write down their forthcoming conversation precisely. Schultz and Hogan both try to help Helga with her chair, and Klink clears his throat so that they'll get down to business.

Hogan's tale: His men gave the courier money to pick up some of Klink's favorite wine in Dusseldorf, figuring the bribe ... the "gift" would soften Klink's heart toward restoring access to their Tommy Dorsey records. "They keep saying there's a lot of human being left in Colonel Klink." Klink calls them fools, and Hogan says he told them they were wrong.

Klink threatens to throw them in the cooler for life - even after the war - and even if Germany loses.

Klink orders Schultz to arrest the courier the moment he next sets foot in camp. Hogan congratulates Klink for being the most secure officer he's ever met. If the courier lingers in Dusseldorf to drink a little and boast of his deal with the prisoners, risking being overheard by the Gestapo and getting Klink sent to the Russian front, Hogan admires Klink's nerve. Klink gets on the phone right away.

As he speaks, Hogan guides him toward contacting Sentry Post #9. Schultz says goodbye to his pound of coffee, then tells Helga not to bother writing that down. Klink tells Schultz to stop muttering and tells Hogan he'll personally smash the POWs' Tommy Dorsey records before their eyes - and Jimmy Dorsey's, and the Andrew Sisters' albums, too.

Having contacted Post #9 (and still guided by Hogan), Klink orders the sentry to tell the courier to keep to his regular route, then to call back and confirm it. He further threatens to have them both court marshaled, shot, and sent to the Russian front if his orders aren't carried out.

Hanging up, he recalls having heard someone (Hogan saying "to Braunshardt across the bridge"). Hogan claims to have said nothing, so the Colonel blames Schultz for muttering again.

Now they wait to hear back from the sentry, to be followed by Klink throwing the guilty prisoners in the cooler with his own hands.

The messenger drives up to the sentry post, and the sentry flags him down with a 'Halt' sign. The messenger points one way, and the sentry points another way. The sentry succeeds at sending the courier away from Dusseldorf and phones back.

Klink emerges from his office with Hogan and Schultz and threatens to additionally smash any Bing Crosby records if he finds them, too.

The center span of the Adolf Hitler Bridge blows up.

Schultz declares it the worst of recent explosions. Klink wishes they'd finish with the construction work, as he's getting sick of it. Hogan declares it's probably the last one. Klink asks how he would know that, and Hogan calls it a wild guess.

Standing before another roll call, Klink reports the bridge destroyed and asks for volunteers in its reconstruction. The prisoners jeer at this but Hogan volunteers the services of his men, provided the recreation hall is reopened and all past offenses are excused. Request granted and men are dismissed.

The men angrily surround Hogan over being volunteered. Hogan calmly tells them they'll rebuild the bridge with a very special feature that'll make it unique in the world - its own built-in bomb. They all happily walk along.

description: Hogan wants to get a peek at the documents that a visiting general has.
tags: ['picking a lock', 'military secret plans', 'staff car', 'm4 sherman tank', 'phony holiday', 'speaking russian', 'prussian helmet', 'magnifying glass', 'eye patch', 'playing violin', 'combination lock', 'padlock', 'dinner party', 'briefcase']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, a staff car is entering the camp. An S.S. General, General von Kaplow, with a briefcase attached by handcuffs, goes to Klink's office.

British Flight Lieutenants Ritchie and Donner come up through the tunnel. They say that they were shot down and bailed out. Schultz chases the men who are in the compound back into the barracks. When asked why, Schultz knows nothing. Carter says that a colonel came into camp; Schultz says that it is not a colonel, it is General von Kaplow. Hogan wonders why a German general with a briefcase would stop here. The two Flight Lieutenants want to get back to England; they have a cricket match with another organization in a few days. Hogan goes to see Klink about what is going on. Hogan tells LeBeau to get out his best recipes' the best way to a big mouth is through his stomach.

In Klink's office, von Kaplow has a patch over his right eye. He tells Klink that he is staying here. He gives him little information about his mission.

While this conversation is going on, Hogan comes into Klink's outer office. Hogan kisses Helga; she says that Hogan just wants information, and Hogan seems to agree. Hogan then goes into Klink's office and asks for favors. He says that this is 'Repeal of Prohibition Day', and suggests a dinner in Klink's quarters. He sees von Kaplow and invites von Kaplow to dinner.

At the dinner in Klink's quarters, von Kaplow sits next to Helga, and makes some subtle, and not so subtle, passes at her. While serving the dinner, Newkirk breaks a glass. Hogan tells him to pick up the pieces. Newkirk needs to go under the table to do the clean-up. While he is there, he tries to get to the briefcase. Helga's leg is in the way, so he places his hand on her leg. She does not like it, and thinks that von Kaplow did it; she moves it out of the way. Hogan asks Klink for music; Helga suggests that Klink play the violin. Klink picks up his violin and starts playing, badly. Schultz, back in the kitchen, thinks somebody is teasing a cat. Meanwhile, Newkirk picks the lock on the briefcase and takes papers out of it. He takes the papers to the kitchen where LeBeau photographs them; Newkirk holds them up and takes them off one at a time while LeBeau takes the pictures. Klink starts playing a Russian dance song on the violin, again, not so well. Newkirk comes back in to do a 'final cleanup', and goes under the table again. He puts the papers back in the briefcase and closes it up.

Later in the barracks, Hogan looks at the film of the papers. He needs to get them to England. He has a plan to get the pictures to England and to get the two pilots out at the same time. Hogan asks for 2 German officer uniforms, special services, and a phony movie camera.

Later, Hogan is in the barracks teaching Russian language lessons to the prisoners. He starts with 'tovarich', written on a shade that he pulls down from a bunk, which means 'friend' in Russian. He has them repeat 'tovarich'. Schultz comes in during the session. Hogan convinces Schultz that the Russians are coming; no need to go to the Russian front as the Russian front is coming here. Schultz mentions a radio. Hogan says that Hamburg is a shambles and Berlin is in ruins. Hogan then pulls down another shade with 'da' and 'nyet', which mean 'yes' and 'no' in Russian. Hogan has the men practice 'da' and 'nyet'; Schultz, in the back, practices along with them.

Later, Hogan dictates a letter to Kinchloe regarding Schultz being a good guard, to be sent around for the prisoners to sign. Schultz is there watching and listening; he likes the letter.

Schultz goes to Klink outside his office and tells him Hamburg is a shambles, and Berlin is in ruins he then tells Klink about the letter, Klink says that Schultz is a traitor. Schultz asks for Klink's signature on the letter.

Later, Klink turns on his radio. Kinch, impersonating a German announcer, says to tune in at 2100 hours. Newkirk, impersonating Hitler over the radio, tries to convince Klink that Germany is losing the war. If he has heard rumors that Hamburg is a shambles and Berlin is in ruins, don't believe them even if they are true. He ends the broadcast with 'Keep smiling'. Klink turns the radio off, and asks Hogan how Hitler can tell them to keep smiling. After some discussion, Hogan refers to their rescue from the camp. He says that a Sherman tank will come through the gates, with its peashooter pointed right at Klink's monocle. Out jumps a second lieutenant, 19 years old, 6 foot 4, high-school senior from Wichita, Kansas, who says to Klink 'Sir, you are my prisoner'. Either Klink surrenders the camp, or he shoots. Hogan tells Klink that he won't be going to the Russian front, the Russian front is coming here.

Later, the two flight lieutenants are in German officer uniforms, 'taking pictures' of STALAG 13 with the fake movie camera. They say that they are taking pictures of all prisoner of war camps for the archives. Hogan talks Klink into doing it. Klink tells them to proceed. They start taking various pictures, starting with Hogan and Klink drinking beers with Helga as a waitress. Klink wants other shots. They take a scene where Hogan is reviewing German guards. Klink wants one more shot. Just then, von Kaplow comes back into camp, returning from Berlin. He tells Klink that Berlin is fine. Klink stops the men with the camera taking pictures, and wants to destroy the film. Klink tries to open the camera case, but Hogan stops him. Hogan grabs the camera by the stand, turns it upside down, and dunks it in a nearby barrel of water. He tells Klink to get rid of them. Klink tells Schultz to get them a car. Klink says that he has decided not to play in the camp orchestra but he will do a solo over the loudspeaker. Hogan says to wait until the general leaves, and he does not want a mass escape while he is here. Klink gets mad; Hogan walks off.

At the end Hogan goes to Klink's office, Klink and Schultz are there. Klink says that he is missing his violin. Hogan brings the violin, quickly puts it in its case, and slams the lid. Klink takes it away. Schultz asks Hogan why he had to find it, as Klink will play it. Hogan says that if he does, he will have to blow into it, and shows Schultz the violin strings that he kept.

description: Hogan convinces Kommandant Klink that the heavy water being stored at Stalag 13 is a youth potion.
tags: ['barrel', 'fire hose', 'kiss', 'truck', 'salute', 'bombing raid', 'blanket', 'tarpaulin', 'window', 'heavy water', 'winking', 'sprayed with water', 'jumping out window', 'smoke bomb', 'reference to marie antoinette', 'reference to king louis xvi']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, a German truck is driving down a road. A bombing raid happens, the truck stops, and the 2 people in the truck, Captain Mueller and Sergeant Steinfeld, get out. Mueller looks at a map trying to find a place to go to get out of the bombing area. STALAG 13 is nearby, so he decides to head there; the Allies would never bomb a prisoner of war camp.

Hogan and Helga are in Klink's outer office, just outside of Klink's door, kissing. Klink opens the door, and asks what is happening. Hogan says that Helga is guarding the door. Klink says that she is part of a highly-trained machine. Hogan says that he must have trouble getting parts for that machine. Hogan goes into Klink's office to talk. Just as he starts, Schultz is at the door. A Captain Mueller is here to see Klink on an urgent matter. Mueller comes in; Klink throws Hogan and Schultz out. After they leave, Mueller tells Klink that they are on an urgent mission with important cargo from Norway; he says he does not know what is in the truck. He says that it is 'water'; Klink and Mueller laugh.

Hogan, Newkirk, Carter, and Kinchloe are in the barracks looking out a window at the truck, wondering what it is carrying. They close the window; Schultz comes in asking for shave lotion. Hogan gets him a bottle; he will give it to Schultz if Schultz tells him what is in the truck. Schultz at first knows nothing; then he says that it is a barrel of water from Norway. How does he know? The driver told him. Schultz leaves. Hogan is asked if he believes him. Hogan says 'Schultz yes, the driver no'.

Hogan and Kinch go to the back of the truck to put up a 'No Smoking' sign. Hogan convinces the guard that there is nitroglycerin in the truck, and smoking will set it off. The guard lets them put up the sign. Just as they leave, Newkirk comes up and lights a cigarette. The guard tells him to put it out, pointing to the sign. Newkirk feigns that he can't read it. Newkirk and the guard get into an argument, which was the intent all along. While they are arguing, Carter sneaks in the front of the truck, lifts the tarpaulin cover, and goes into the back.
