He sees a wood barrel marked 'wasser'. He takes a sample of it and puts it into a canteen, and leaves. Klink comes up, wanting to know what the argument is about. Klink is smoking a cigarette at the end of a cigarette holder. The guard slaps it out of his mouth, and says 'no smoking'. Klink gets mad at this. Hogan says that if this place blows up, he will never talk to Klink again.

Shortly later in the barracks, the men are talking about what the stuff is. Carter looks at it in a glass, and says that it is odorless and colorless. He then tastes it, and says that it is water.

Just then, Kinch comes up from the tunnel and says that he is on the radio to a submarine. Hogan tells the sub that they have a barrel of 'water' at their place, a truck is taking it to 'Adolf's village' from 'Viking's village'. and asks what to do with it. The sub says that it is heavy water to be used for nuclear experiments. Hogan is to destroy the barrel of heavy water. After talking with the sub, Hogan says that either they destroy the barrel. or they will be over a barrel.

Hogan goes to Klink's office. Helga blocks the door and gives him a smile. Hogan kisses Helga. Klink opens the office door, and sees Helga 'blocking' Hogan from getting in again. Hogan goes into Klink's office and apologizes for the war. Hogan tells Klink that the water is from a fountain of youth spa in Norway. King Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette went there. King Louis got his hair back - he had to add an extra barber to his staff.

Klink goes to the truck to supposedly check on the water. He goes into the back of the truck, sees the barrel, takes a drink, and leaves.

The next day, Hogan goes to Klink's office. He gives Klink a strange look, and tells Klink that he appears to have more hair and looks youthful. Klink says that this morning he has had dandruff, which he has not had in a long time. Hogan asks Klink if he got to the water barrel. Klink says that if it is supposed to go to Berlin, then it goes to Berlin.

That night, Klink goes to the truck; Schultz is guarding it, but he is sleeping. Klink wakes him up. Klink wants to take the barrel of water and replace it. Schultz does not like the idea. Klink talks to Schultz more, and suggests a promotion to Uber-sergeant. Klink and Schultz go into the back of the truck; Klink tells Schultz that it is from a Norway fountain of youth. Schultz refers to a Corporal Schneider. Just then, Mueller comes by, and does not see Schultz guarding the truck. He calls for Schultz. Klink and Schultz come out of the back of the truck. Klink tells Mueller that he knows about the special water; Mueller wants to know where he got the information from. Klink says from Hogan. Mueller is surprised. Klink then goes on and says that it is from a spa in Norway. Mueller tells Klink that somebody is making a fool out of him, and tells him that this is special water for use in nuclear experiments - it is heavy water.

In the barracks, Hogan is talking to the men. He says that the truck leaves tomorrow, and the barrel can't be on it. He has an idea. He tells the men to do some things, and he tells Scotty (LeBeau's replacement for this show) to make a new barrel.

Later, Carter and Newkirk are playing catch in the compound outside of Klink's office. For one throw, Carter throws a smoke bomb into the window at the far left of the building, which is supposedly Klink's office. The smoke bomb goes off, and Klink panics, thinking that there is a fire.

While this is going on, Hogan convinces the guard/driver of the truck to move the truck; if it catches fire, it could explode. He backs it up against the wall of a barracks. Kinch and Scotty pull down a rope, that opens up a part of the wall and turns it into a ramp. They take the barrel of heavy water out of the truck, and replace it with a barrel of regular water, and close the wall..

While this is going on, Newkirk and Carter grab a fire hose and start spraying water on the 'fire'. Klink is looking out the window, and he gets sprayed with the hose. Newkirk tells Klink to jump out the window (which is on the ground floor), and that he will catch him in a blanket that he and Carter are holding. Just as Klink jumps, Newkirk moves closer to Carter to talk with him, and Klink jumps on the ground and falls over.

Mueller comes over and asks what happened. After some discussion, Mueller pats Hogan on the back, and says that he may have shortened the war. Hogan says that he is not surprised.

At the end, Hogan and Helga are in Klink's office by Klink's office door, kissing again. Klink comes out, and Helga quickly puts Hogan in an arm lock with his right arm behind his back. Helga lets Hogan go, and Hogan goes into Klink's office. Klink says that he went along with Hogan. Klink tells Hogan about the water being 'heavy water'. Hogan says that he does not want to stand in the way of Klink gloating about his victories. Hogan then looks at Klink, and tells him that maybe heavy water DOES grow hair. He then leaves. After he leaves, Klink looks at himself in a hand mirror that was on his desk.

description: Using the microphone that Klink has installed in the barracks, Hogan tricks Klink into contacting an underground member.
tags: ['fence gate', 'reference to lili marlene', 'dance', 'vacuum cleaner', 'stepping on foot', 'script', 'dancing', 'hidden microphone']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Hogan tells the men that London will transmit in 2 minutes. Schultz will come for a bed check; he tells LeBeau 'You know what to do'. LeBeau takes food outside to Schultz. While Schultz is eyeing the food, the message comes in. They have lost contact from Willie; get a message to stop the weapons drop. Hogan says that he will go himself, and asks Newkirk for civilian clothes.

Next day, Klink has an assembly of the prisoners. Hogan asks to have work on a project outside of camp, with a secret reason of sneaking off for a bit. Klink says that the wire will be electrified. Hogan says that they will be guarding equipment, they have to get out some other way.

As the men go back into the barracks, a guard comes out of the barracks, Hogan is suspicious. Hogan and the men look for bugs that he may have planted. Kinchloe finds 1, LeBeau finds 1, Newkirk finds 1, all in Hogan's office. Hogan wants to use them to their advantage.

Later, the men, each holding a script, comes to Hogan's office. In the script, the men have an idea for an escape. Hogan, as part of the script, says 'No'. Schultz comes in, returns some plates to LeBeau, and insults Klink. Hogan shows Schultz the microphone in the lamp. Schultz tries to backtrack what he just said, and butter Klink up a bit.

After this is done, Klink calls General Burkhalter regarding Hogan, he talks about a pro-German attitude Hogan has. Burkhalter tells Klink to make Hogan comfortable.

Klink orders Schultz to put things in the barracks that would make Hogan more comfortable and happy, fore Germany-related items. One of the things is a picture of Hitler; Hogan asks for it to be autographed.

Hogan tells Klink that his name is really Hoganmuller, and he is German. Hogan asks Klink to go to the Hauserhof Hotel in nearby Hammelburg for dinner, but Klink says no. Hogan leaves Klink's office, asking for crumpets for breakfast on the way out.

Later in Hogan's office, the men are talking through a script to the hidden microphone. They are singing 'Roll Out the Barrel', reading the script, and Hogan is talking about the Norden. Hogan gives possible details of the Norden; he says that as a captain he tested the Norden. Klink is listening, but he can not hear many of the details over the singing. He thinks that Hogan is talking about the Norden bomb-sight. Klink calls Burkhalter regarding the Norden bomb-sight and Hogan's supposed knowledge of it. He asks Burkhalter to come to STALAG 13, saying he has a surprise.

Burkhalter comes to STALAG 13. Just inside the gates, he stops Burkhalter's staff car to show him 'escape proof gates'. The gates then open and close on Burkhalter's staff car. Schultz can't operate the gates correctly. Burkhalter does not look kindly on this. Burkhalter says that he will have a Major Klopfer, an engineer, come to STALAG 13. He wants to have the major see Hogan's description of the Norden.

Burkhalter tells Klink to arrange a party at a hotel. He tells Klink to have Hogan wear a German uniform. This is actually what Hogan wanted all along.

At the hotel, Burkhalter, Klink, Hogan, and some women are at a table eating dinner. Burkhalter asks for more champagne. Hogan gives a code phrase to the waiter 'Do you know Lili Marlene?' He did not get the right response from the waiter, so he knows that this waiter is not his contact. Klink asks a girl at the table, Gretechen, for a dance; she says no. Hogan then asks her for a dance, and she does. After dancing for a minute, Klink cuts in, Hogan sits down. Klink supposedly steps on her foot; she just gives this as a excuse not to dance with Klink. Hogan dances with Gretchen, Klink with another girl. Gretchen would rather dance with Hogan than Klink. While dancing, Hogan and Gretchen dance up to the bar. He asks the bartender 'Do you know Lili Marlene?' He does not get the right answer. Hogan then sees another waiter who is stumbling around, thinking that he may be the contact. Hogan kisses Gretchen, and excuses himself to see an 'old friend'. Hogan asks this waiter 'Do you know Lili Marlene?' This waiter gives the correct answer, and drops the tray with glasses and other things on it. As Hogan helps pick them up, he gives the waiter a cigarette pack. The waiter takes it, and is still nervous.

The next day, Hogan, Klink, Burkhalter, and Major Klopfer are in Klink's office. Hogan is drawing the Norden on a blackboard with chalk. After every item that he draws, Klopfer takes some pictures of the drawing. Hogan draws, the top; then draws the power supply at the bottom. He then connects the two with a line and adds a dust-bag. Klopfer says that he is drawing a vacuum cleaner. Hogan says that he tested the Norden vacuum cleaner. Burkhalter is mad at Klink; a vacuum cleaner is not a bomb-sight.

At the end, Schultz has men take things out of Hogan's office that he put there previously. Schultz tells Klink it is all done. As Klink is leaving, Hogan tells Klink to take the microphone, and rips it from the lamp. He says that he might talk about Gretchen in his sleep. Klink gives him a frustrated look.

description: After Klink finds Sergeant Schultz drunk he gets a tough new replacement.
tags: ['beer', 'flashlight', 'signalling', 'pit trap', 'motorcycle', 'wire cutters', 'card trick', 'sprayed with water', 'practical joke', 'motorcycle with a sidecar', 'drunken man', 'drinking on duty', 'short circuit', 'wheelbarrow', 'reference to the lone ranger', 'texan']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, LeBeau is outside the camp, signaling someone with a flashlight. He gets a signal back. He makes contact with Captain Jeb Winslow of the 413th Fighter Squadron who has been shot down nearby. Winslow starts to describe his being shot down when LeBeau stops him to take him back to camp. LeBeau says "C'est la guerre" to one of Winslow's remarks; Winslow replies "That's French"; LeBeau replies in a phony French-accented southern accent "I reckon so, stranger".

Later, Winslow comes up into the barracks through the entrance under the bunk. He is much taller than any of the others, including Hogan. He has the cowboy look, as well as attitude. Hogan asks him if he came on a horse. Winslow asks how soon he will be going home. Just then, Kinchloe comes up the tunnel and reports that the radio is broken and needs parts; he can not fix it right now. Hogan says that he needs one volunteer to go to town, to get parts from the Underground. Newkirk was volunteered by Hogan; Hogan tells him that he has a toothache, and puts come cotton balls in Newkirk's mouth.

Hogan goes to Klink's office with Newkirk, complaining that Newkirk has a bad tooth. It is because of the sawdust the Germans put in the prisoner's bread. Hogan wants to have Newkirk go to a dentist in town. Klink reluctantly agrees to write up a pass for Newkirk to see the dentist, with Schultz guarding him. Schultz remarks that he can't stand the sight of blood. Klink asks how Schultz got in the German Army; Hogan says that he lied about his weight.

Later, Newkirk and Schultz are at a bar, getting drinks. Newkirk gets Schultz are large beer. Newkirk points behind Schultz regarding something, and Schultz turns around and looks. While he is looking at something and sees nothing, Newkirk dumps some whiskey in Schultz's drink. Later, Schultz appears to be drunk, drinking out of his helmet. Newkirk says to Schultz that it is time to go, that Newkirk has been to the dentist (while Schultz was supposedly drunk), and the swelling is gone. Schultz is so drunk that Newkirk brings him back to camp in a wheelbarrow. Klink meets them as they are about to come in the gate. He asks them what took so long. Klink sees that Schultz is drunk. Klink tells Schultz to walk a post outside the wire as punishment, and he will keep walking the post until the sergeant from headquarters comes to replace him. Then Schultz will be transferred to another command; implying but not stating directly the Russian front. Hogan arrives and butts in on the conversation. Klink and two guards walk off, leaving Schultz with Newkirk and Hogan. Schultz says 'Ach du leiber' in a drunken manner.

The next day, Schultz is seen walking a post outside the wire. Newkirk asks Hogan if Klink will really transfer him out. Just then, someone comes in the gate. A sergeant gets out in front of Klink's office, comes to attention, salutes Klink, and says 'Sergeant Krebs reporting for duty, sir'. Klink returns the salute. Hogan and the men are watching this. Hogan tells Carter to try out this new guy. Carter goes up to Klink, and calls him 'buddy' and starts to walk off. Krebs then immediately tells him to halt, tells Carter to come to attention, and says that this is no way to talk to the Kommandant. Krebs has shown that he is a strong military type. Hogan does not like this; they will need to get rid of Krebs and have Schultz stay.

Later, Hogan comes up through the tunnel into the barracks and says that it will be 3 days before they can send any radio transmissions. Winslow is a bit disappointed. Hogan says that he wants to get rid of Krebs. Schultz comes to the barracks, tired, and asks LeBeau for some of his foot powder. Carter tells Schultz that if they transfer him someplace close, he may be able to see his wife more often. Schultz says that the Russian front sound good, compared to that. Winslow comes up behind Schultz and gives Schultz a light, without Schultz realizing who he is at first. Then Schultz realizes that he is not one of their prisoners. Schultz says that if he turns Winslow in, Klink might tear up his transfer papers. Hogan tells Schultz that he is up the creek. He says that the papers have been signed, but not left the camp. Hogan then shows him some papers that were taken from Klink's desk.

Later, outside, Carter is talking to Krebs. He tells Krebs about a radio in the barracks, and gives Krebs the radio. He tells Krebs that Klink will love him for this. Krebs takes the radio and smiles. Krebs takes the radio to Klink. Klink looks at it a bit and turns it on. The radio squirts Klink in the face with a small stream of water. Klink is not amused.

Later, in the compound, Kinch is standing by the barracks and sees Krebs coming. He then gets down on his hands and knees, and starts shouting into the ground, like there is a tunnel there. Krebs comes up behind Kinch, supposedly without Kinch seeing him. Kinch shouts, supposedly to Hogan in the tunnel below, and if he can hear him, the tunnel is too close to the surface. Krebs hears all of this and leaves, supposedly without Kinch seeing him.

Krebs then takes Klink to the supposed 'tunnel' location. He says that it is right about at this location, Klink steps on the location, and falls in.

In the barracks, Hogan says that Winslow goes out tonight. Hogan says that Krebs listens by the barracks to get information, and they will put on a show for him later.

That evening, in the barracks by an outer wall, Newkirk, Carter, and LeBeau put on an act with the intention that Krebs overhear them. They keep saying 'Tomorrow night, from here'. Krebs hears them saying this several times.

The next day, Krebs approaches Carter. Carter apologizes for the radio; Krebs seems to accept the apology and brushes it off. He asks Carter if there is something on for tonight. Carter does not want to give him any information, but says if he doesn't seem him anymore, it has been nice knowing him, and they shake hands. Carter leaves, and Krebs walks off.

At the end, Hogan is in the barracks talking with the men about Winslow's escape. He tells Winslow to wait for the alarm to go off, then leave. Winslow goes down into the tunnel. Krebs comes into the barracks. Newkirk starts playing card tricks to distract Krebs and keep him there for a few minutes. Newkirk tells Krebs to take a card, any card, look at it, and put it back. While Krebs is being distracted, Hogan, Carter, and LeBeau go out a barrack's window and sneak to the wire. Carter cuts the wire. Schultz comes up and wants to know what is going on. Hogan tells Schultz that he wants to help Schultz. Schultz at first does not want to turn them in. So LeBeau starts shouting. The searchlights turn on him, and the alarm sounds. Krebs is in the barracks, hears the alarm, and says that there is an escape. He runs out of the barracks.

Klink rides up to the escape site by the wire in a motorcycle sidecar.

Newkirk shakes hands with Winslow, and Winslow says 'See you in Fort Worth'.

Krebs comes to the escape site after Klink arrives and the men have been captured. Krebs reports that there has been an escape. Klink sarcastically thanks Krebs, relieves him of duty, and transfers him out. He restores Schultz to duty as sergeant of the guard. Klink then says that Carter and LeBeau will get 2 weeks in the cooler, and Hogan is confined to barracks. Schultz tells Hogan, Newkirk, and LeBeau to get back into camp, point his rifle at them. Hogan says 'How quickly they forget'.

description: Corporal LeBeau pretends to be a visiting French scientist while Hogan smuggles out the real one.
tags: ['russian front', 'emulsion', 'chemical experiment', 'ceramic vase', 'norwegian flag', 'rifles', 'helmet', 'riding crop', 'stairs', 'guard dog', 'truck', 'french scientist', 'explosion', 'doghouse', 'slapped in the face', 'rant', 'motorcycle with a sidecar', 'desk bell', 'laboratory', 'condenser', 'pipe smoking', 'prussian helmet', 'playing blackjack', 'periscope']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, German guards are closing the outside shutters on the barracks windows. Schultz and another guard enter the barracks and Schultz says that Colonel Klink ordered that all prisoners are to stay away from the windows and doors. After Schultz leaves, Hogan looks outside through the sink periscope. He sees a civilian escorted by 2 officers, going to a building that they had been cleaning out for the last week. Hogan wants to know who it is. LeBeau offers to go out and find out. Hogan says that he has a better idea. He thinks that Schultz might know. He tells LeBeau to tell Schultz that there is a seat at the blackjack table; he then tells Newkirk to start the blackjack game.

Shortly later, Schultz is playing blackjack in the barracks with Newkirk, LeBeau, Kinchloe, and 3 un-named prisoners; and is not doing well. So far, he has lost 300 Marks. In a following hand, he wants to bet 25 Marks on the cuff as he is out of cash. Newkirk and the others object as he has lost so much so far. Schultz wants credit, but Hogan won't give it to him. Hogan says he will give him the credit if he tells him who the civilian is. Schultz refuses. Hogan tries to blackmail Schultz, saying that he will report him to Klink for gambling with the prisoners. Just then, Carter enters the barracks, and pretends to know who the civilian is. This gets Schultz to say that he is a captured French scientist, Henri DuBois, brought here for scientific experiments. After he provides the information, his blackjack hand mysteriously ends up at 21.

Later, Hogan gets a message from London with information on DuBois. He is a synthetic fuel expert and possible collaborator. Hogan's orders are to either turn him to the allies' side, or eliminate him and his work. Hogan goes to Klink's office complaining about the situation. He tells Klink that LeBeau refused to work for DuBois, and essentially convinces Klink to have LeBeau help in the laboratory that was set up earlier. Klink then calls LeBeau in the office. Hogan empties his pipe into Klink's helmet on the desk. LeBeau comes in and starts gives his name, rank, and serial number; he starts giving his serial number as H124978, but stutters and forgets the full number. Klink orders LeBeau to assist DuBois.

LeBeau then goes to the lab building, and tells DuBois that he is here to assist, on the orders of Col. Klink. DuBois says that he did not ask for an assistant, but reluctantly accepts because it is the Kommandant's orders. After some talking, LeBeau grabs DuBois and calls him a collaborator. DuBois says that he has no choice, as the Germans are holding his daughter hostage at a hotel in town. They were captured as France fell, and had no choice but to cooperate. DuBois says that he has been making useless experiments since then, and he has run out of ideas. LeBeau suggests they make crepe suzettes; DuBois laughs. LeBeau apparently tells Hogan about this.

Soon after, Hogan and Newkirk go to the hotel in town dressed as Gestapo officers, Hogan as General von Himmelburger, and Newkirk as his aide 'Putzi'. Hogan acts mad, and asks what is going on. He wants to have the girl Marie DuBois given to him, but the officers there refuse. One officer says that he needs written orders. He threatens to have one officer shot, one sent to the Russian front, and the man at the desk court-martialed, shot, and sent to the Russian front. Hogan then trashes the hotel lobby, clearing the counter with his riding crop, breaking glasses, kicking and smashing a ceramic vase, knocking over a row of rifles that were stacked, and hitting a corporal guard on the helmet with his riding crop. He then leaves the room. Newkirk pretends to be disturbed by it, and says so. Hogan demands that the girl be brought to him in 5 minutes, or everybody will be sent to the Russian front, including the hotel itself. He then leaves the hotel. He and Newkirk wait outside. Newkirk asks what happens if they don't bring her out; Hogan says THEY might end up at the Russian front. The German officers bring Marie DuBois out. They get in a motorcycle with a sidecar, with Hogan in the sidecar and Marie in his lap; he says he is taking her for questioning.

Later that night, back in camp, LeBeau and Professor DuBois come out of the barracks, dodging the searchlights, and run to the dog truck, which is parked right outside the gate of the dog pen. LeBeau tells DuBois that they change the dogs so they don't get friendly with the prisoners. DuBois gets in the truck with the dogs, LeBeau says they will not hurt him. DuBois kisses LeBeau French style, twice; LeBeau pushes him away the third time. LeBeau then goes down the doghouse tunnel entrance. The truck takes DuBois outside the fence, where he gets out and meets Marie in the woods. Newkirk is with them, still in Gestapo uniform. He tells them that they need to 'get cracking'; they do not understand what he means. They then leave for the rendezvous with the sub.

Kinchloe gets a message from the submarine that they will pick up 2 packages, 1 large and 1 small, in 24 hours at location Y-14. Hogan goes to Klink's quarters with LeBeau telling him that DuBois has escaped. Hogan helps Klink on with his bathrobe, and tells Klink 'Nice bathrobe'. Klink is worried, in that his no escape record has been broken. Klink, Hogan, and LeBeau go into Klink's office. A Dr. Altman, a German scientist, will be coming by tomorrow to see DuBois. Hogan convinces Klink to have LeBeau impersonate DuBois for the visit. Klink says that if anything goes wrong, Hogan will be held responsible, and will take the consequences. Hogan tells LeBeau that if anything goes wrong, Hogan will be held responsible, and LeBeau says that he will take the consequences. Back in the barracks, Hogan tells Carter to teach LeBeau some chemistry, as Carter owned a drugstore in Muncie, Indiana, before the war. Carter does not know anything about chemistry, but has a handbook of pharmacy that he has been carrying for 2 years; Carter wants to take a pharmacy exam after the war.

The next day, Professor Hans Altman and his escort Capt. Kurtz come to STALAG 13 to see DuBois. They go to the lab, where LeBeau introduces himself as DuBois, and Newkirk as Monsieur LeBeau, his assistant. Newkirk gives a 'bonjour' in a phony French accent, mixed with an English accent. LeBeau puts the pharmacy book in an open drawer where he can look at it, but it is hard for the others to see. Newkirk gives them drinks to relax; he gives Kurtz a heavy drink, with the intention of getting him drunk, which he eventually does. Altman asks how it is going, and LeBeau starts reading from a book. He refers to an emulsion, and Altman is astounded as he has not thought of that before. Altman thinks that is a good idea, and asks if he uses positive or negative ions. LeBeau deflects the question by asking if they teach anything in Berlin. Altman asks LeBeau/DuBois if he got chemicals to mix, and they have more discussions. LeBeau mentions that the concoction can also clear sinuses. LeBeau goes through steps: Make accurate measurements, select the proper vessel, and wash hands.

Meanwhile, down in the tunnel, Hogan calls the sub asking them to advise when packages have been picked up.

LeBeau says that he mixed two chemicals that cleared nasal congestion. The escorting officer is getting noticeably drunk by this time. Altman says that they have saved hundreds of hours, he thinks.

Hogan gets a message that the packages have been picked up by the sub. Carter then goes to the lab, and tells LeBeau/DuBois that the 2 packages have arrived. LeBeau says not a moment too soon. Altman and Kurtz leave, leaving the professor to his work; Kurtz staggering out. Newkirk congratulates LeBeau. Altman then comes back and opens the door, and asks for some leftover emulsion, as he has nasal congestion, then leaves. LeBeau says 'This is a crazy war.'

At the end, Carter leaves the laboratory building, and nods to LeBeau. Lebeau then walks to Kinch, and gives him a nod; Kinch then goes to Newkirk, and gives him a nod. Newkirk then walks on a bench by a window of Klink's office that Hogan is looking out of. Klink says that they got away with LeBeau impersonating DuBois for one day, but that Altman will be back tomorrow for further conversations with DuBois. Hogan says not to worry, as DuBois was killed in an explosion in the lab. Klink looks puzzled, as he has heard no explosion. Klink asks 'When?' Hogan looks at his watch and counts down from five. Just then, they hear an explosion. Klink looks at Hogan and seems to wonder how Hogan knew about it in advance. Hogan asks Klink 'Any questions?'

description: Hogan sneaks out of camp to a local German Hofbrau House to get the details of a nearby German army unit.
tags: ['blackmail', 'hofbrau', 'waiter', 'german currency', 'chef', 'telephone call', 'impersonating a german officer', 'schnapps', 'scarf', 'overcoat', 'counterfeit currency', 'falling off roof', 'binoculars', 'character name in episode title']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, LeBeau and Newkirk are on a roof looking at something. Carter is in a guard tower, also looking at something with binoculars; the guard turns around and catches him, and takes the binoculars. LeBeau falls off the roof, and is caught by Schultz. Kinchloe has tapped Klink's phone line; a Captain Milheiser from the Adolf Hitler Division called. Newkirk sees a vehicle column; Carter sees a panzer column. Back in the barracks, they talk about what happened. Newkirk and Kinch re-enact Klink's phone call, Newkirk impersonating Klink.

In Klink's office, Schultz is reading an inventory of food. Klink tells Schultz to find 500 wooden plates. Helga comes in and says that two officers from the Adolf Hitler Division are here to see Klink. The two officers, Captain Milheiser and Lieutenant Schmidt, come in and sit down. Schmidt says that he is the chair of the charity organization 'Beautify Berchtesgarten'. He asks Klink for monetary help; he says that he got Klink's name from the artillery. Milheiser shows Klink two lists, one white and one black; those who have given and those who have not given. Schultz says a list of 5000 plates, he says '5000'; Klink says '5000?' Milheiser puts Klink down for 5000 Marks, by the first of the month.

Down in the tunnel, Hogan gets a message asking for information on the Adolf Hitler Division; where they are going and other information.

At Hilda's Hofbrau, by a crossroads, Hogan goes into the place as a Luftwaffe officer, Major Hoople. He asks to sit down with two officers; they happen to be Captain Milheiser and Lieutenant Schmidt. They ask Hogan about the Luftwaffe uniform, as there are not Luftwaffe units in the area. Hogan/Hoople refers to STALAG 13. They talk about Klink for a bit; Milheiser says that Klink is jelly, Hogan/Hoople agrees. Hogan tries to get information as to where they are going; he talks about conditions in a cold weather area and having to defrost toothpaste with a blowtorch. Milheiser does not say where they are going, but let us say they are not moving west. Hogan/Hoople gives a toast to long woolen underwear; the other 2 drink with him. Milheiser then talks about the 'Beautify Berchtesgarten' fund. Hogan/Hoople gives them some money. Schmidt asks where he got the new bills; Hogan/Hoople says that he has men make them up. They all laugh.

Back at camp, Hogan gives Kinch a message to send, that the Adolf Hitler Division may be heading to the Russian front; will confirm and provide more information.

Back at Hilda's Hofbrau, Newkirk and Carter are waiters and LeBeau is a cook. Hogan is there again as a major. Carter and Newkirk are getting information; Newkirk says that an officer mentioned big guns to his girlfriend, and Carter saw skis in a backpack. Hogan tells them to stay with it. Schultz comes in and sits down. Newkirk gets nervous, and sits with a soldier and a woman. Schultz asks for cheese and beer from the waiter, who is Carter. Carter tries to walk away, but Schultz stops him. Then Schultz see, Carter, then Newkirk and LeBeau. Hogan comes up to Schultz; Schultz asks why they are here. Hogan refers to Hilda, a widow with 8 children. She can't get much help, and he gives her a sob story. Schultz wants them to go back to camp. Hogan blackmails Schultz; he says that he will have to tell Klink that they escaped on his watch. Schultz tells him to being the beer and food outside; it is easier for him to know nothing. They apparently stay for a while.

It is now the first of the month, Milheiser and Schmidt come to Klink asking for the money for the fund. Milheiser tells Klink to be at Hilda's Hofbrau that evening with the money. When they leave, Klink asks Schultz to get 5000 marks. Klink is resigned to go to Hilda's and confess that he does not have the money.

Schultz tells Hogan about Klink going to Hilda's Hofbrau. Hogan is surprised and worried; the men left for Hilda's an hour ago. He tells Schultz to stall Klink, that he will think of something.

In Klink's quarters, Klink starts to leave, while Schultz tries to stall him. Klink says that he may not come back. They will get a new kommandant. Schultz asks what he can do to help; Klink tells Schultz he can help out to have himself transferred to another camp. Schultz puts a coat and scarf on Klink, and Klink leaves.

At Hilda's Hofbrau, Hogan and Hilda are sitting at a table, talking. Hogan wants to take the prisoners back to camp early. Klink comes in, not seen by Hogan. Carter picks up a phone, and says 'Phone call for Major Hoople'. Hogan is puzzled, but goes to the phone. Newkirk, Carter, and LeBeau duck behind the bar, and point out Klink. Hogan thinks fast. He can't get them out the back door, as there is no back door; so he marches them out the front door. As he is doing that, Milheiser sees Hogan/Hoople, and calls him over. Klink sees him, and wants to know what is going on. Hogan/Hoople says that he is taking a work detail back to camp. Klink calls him 'Hogan'; Hogan says that that is his first name, 'Hogan Hoople'. When Klink mentions that he was not able to go to the bank to get the money, Hogan/Hoople says that Klink sent him to the bank. Hogan/Hoople gives Milheiser 5000 Marks; Klink looks surprised. Milheiser asks Hogan/Hoople to stay for a beer; Hogan/Hoople says that he has a prisoner of war camp to run. Klink looks disgusted at what he said.

At the end, Klink, Hogan, and Schultz are in Klink's office. Klink says that Hogan will get 30 days in the cooler for what he did. Schultz is to get court-martialled. Hogan says that they worked at Hilda's Hofbrau to get the 5000 Marks. Schultz was standing guard outside. Klink is somewhat placated by the excuse. Hogan and Schultz leave. Schultz asks Hogan how he got the money. Hogan says that it was made by native craftsmen. Schultz, thinking that the money may be counterfeit (which it was), says Milheiser and Schmidt could spend the rest of the war in chains. Hogan says that we can only hope, and walks off.

description: The Germans want to safely build a synthetic fuel plant in Stalag 13, but Hogan convinces them that there is oil beneath the camp.
tags: ['oil', 'dirty face', 'synthetic fuel', 'nickname', 'moving', 'autograph', 'safe', 'mention of french riviera', 'tunnel', 'water tower', 'radio', 'solitary confinement', 'national economy', 'bombing mission', 'boeing b 17 flying fortress', 'archive footage', 'leaflet', 'distraction', 'locked in a safe', 'character name in episode title']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, General Burkhalter comes to STALAG with Fritz Bowman of I.G. Bowman Industries. Hogan does not recognize him; he wants to know what is going on. Hogan tells LeBeau to get to listening post 3. LeBeau goes to Klink's office and starts a commotion with Carter, Newkirk, and Kinchloe. During the commotion, Newkirk opens the safe and puts LeBeau inside, then closes the door. Corporal Langenscheidt is guarding them and tells them to stop the commotion. Klink then comes back to the office and tells Helga that they are not to be disturbed. Burkhalter, Klink, and Bowman go inside Klink's office, this is a top secret matter. Burkhalter says that the allies will not bomb a POW camp. They are going to put a synthetic fuel plant at STALAG 13. Burkhalter tells Klink that the prisoners will be moved to other camps. Burkhalter, Klink, and Bowman leave the office. Newkirk, Carter, and Kinch come back in, open the safe, and let LeBeau out.

Later in the barracks, Hogan and the men are talking about the conversations. There is talk about moving to a new camp. Hogan tells Kinch to get a message to London. Schultz comes in, and tells Hogan that Klink wants to see him.

In Klink's office, Hogan is talking with Klink about a move to new camps. Hogan says that Bowman looked like a real estate salesman. Klink says that the men are to be moved in 3 days. Hogan has a picture of Klink, and asks for his autograph - something to remember him by. Hogan suggests that Klink will be going into combat. Hogan talks about the 'Iron Eagle' (referring to Klink) dropping his eggs in the snow. Hogan says that Moscow is not the Riviera. Klink says that he is not qualified to fly the new planes. Hogan says that he will pick it up soon enough. He asks Klink if Burkhalter told him the details of the new camp. Just then, Burkhalter comes in. Hogan asks him questions about the move. Hogan asks Burkhalter about the details of the new camp. Burkhalter says that he will find out soon enough. Which camp are they moving to? That has not yet been determined. How will the men be protected from the civilian populace? Not Hogan's concern. Burkhalter wants to know why Hogan is questioning him.

That night, Carter, Newkirk, and LeBeau come out of a tunnel under the water tower, They see Schultz and make a noise to get his attention. Schultz captures them trying to escape. They are taken to Klink's office. Hogan says that this try was not known by the escape committee. Klink tells Schultz to put them in solitary for 30 days. As they are about to leave, Klink looks at their faces and sees that they are grimy, not just dirty. He asks what is on their faces. Klink tells Carter to raise his hand; Carter holds his hand up, and Klink looks at it and sees oil. Carter says that there is plenty of oil down there; Hogan tells him to be quiet. Schultz takes Newkirk, Carter, and LeBeau away; Hogan stays. Hogan tells Klink it is a broken pipeline; Klink does not believe him. Hogan then tells Klink that STALAG 13 was built over an oil field. Hogan tells Klink that an engineer looked at it before being transferred to STALAG 9; he was also a geologist. He tells Klink that there is enough oil down there for 10 millionaires. Klink smiles and talks about 'The Klink and Hogan Oil Company'. Hogan suggests adding Burkhalter's name. Klink asks why. Hogan says that we need to give him a piece of the pie, or else there won't be any.

Klink goes to his quarters, and tells Burkhalter about the oil. Burkhalter says that an oil discovery might upset the entire economy and wants to keep it quiet. Burkhalter says that they do not need Hogan.

The next day, Klink, Burkhalter, and Bowman are in Klink's office. They talk about not building the synthetic fuel plant here. Bowman is holding out; he wants the plant built here.

Hogan talks to London on the radio. He requests a fake bombing mission, Have the B-17s drop leaflets, not bombs, He tells London what the leaflets are to say.

Later, B-17 bombers are seen taking off, and make a bombing run over STALAG 13, dropping the leaflets. The leaflets say that this is a sample of what you will get if you build the synthetic fuel plant there. Burkhalter says that this finishes any plans for building the plant at STALAG 13, security has been broken. Klink suspects Hogan, but Hogan says that he only works here.

At the end, Kogan and Klink are outside of Klink's office. Klink says that Hogan deliberately poured oil to make them think that there was oil underground. Hogan says that he saved Klink, that he would be going east by now. Klink asks about Burkhalter, knowing about the oil. Hogan says that he will not do anything until after the war. Klink asks what happens if Germany wins the war? Hogan says 'Impossible. You can't win a war without oil'.

description: During an operation to send out twenty Allied soldiers, two of them attempt an early escape and are nearly captured.
tags: ['stalag 9', 'shaving', 'tree stump', 'sink', 'telephone call', 'playing cards', 'motorcycle', 'motorcycle with a sidecar', 'overhead camera shot', 'hide and seek', 'splashed with water', 'water truck', 'pretending to sleepwalk', 'german shepherd']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, LeBeau is blackening his face with coal dust from the stove. Hogan wakes up Newkirk and says that we need a diversion. Newkirk, still in his nightclothes, goes 'sleepwalking' in the compound, eyes closed and arms out front, 'sleepwalker' style. He is seen by Schultz, who follows him around a bit, and then sounds the alarm, and the guard dogs are let out. While this is going on, LeBeau sneaks out through the raising fence gate. Three of the dogs go to LeBeau; he chases two of them, Bismarck and Kaiser, away. He then goes out into the woods to dig mushrooms. Shortly later, he is caught by two Americans, Braden and Mills, who at first think that he is a German. He convinces them that he is French, and from STALAG 13. Mills whistles, and other prisoners appear, 18 more, 20 in total.

Later, they are in-processed in the barracks. Corporal Walter Cominski and Sergeant John Walter are two who come up into the barracks. Hogan did not expect 20 to show up at the same time; he tells Kinchloe to radio for a BIG submarine. Hogan wants to outfit them in civilian clothes, just like other escapees. Carter takes pictures of each individual for identity cards, and Newkirk measures them for clothes.

While this is going on, Klink gets a phone call in his office. Twenty prisoners had escaped from STALAG 9. Klink wants to call the Kommandant of STALAG 9, but it is a long distance call to Russia, implying that the kommandant had been transferred to the Russian front after the escape. Schultz brings Hogan into Klink's office for a chat. Klink tells Hogan about the STALAG 9 escape. Hogan puts cigar ashes in the spike of Klink's helmet; Klink does not like that. Klink says that he is watching Hogan, and things have been quiet recently; Klink is thinking that something is up.

That night in the barracks, Braden wakes up Mills; he has a plan to escape in the water truck.

Next day, Hogan asks Kinch about the submarine, Newkirk about the clothes, and LeBeau about the pictures. As they are working the plans, Braden and Mills go to the water truck; Hogan sees them, and wants to stop them. Hogan tells Schultz about two men in the water truck (without naming names). After some discussion, Schultz finally believes him; Schultz and another guard go to the water truck and pull them out. Other prisoners gather around to form a mob to get them out; Braden and Mills get away, and Hogan tells them to go to his office. Two other prisoners, who are not named, come in as Hogan requested, and Hogan pours water on them. Klink appears; he thinks that the two other prisoners are the ones who tried to escape, and gives them 30 days in the cooler. After Klink leaves, Hogan talks to Braden and Mills; After some discussion about their escape attempt, he says that they will move out tonight. LeBeau wants to punch Braden and Mills in the nose for what they tried.

Later, in the barracks, a prisoner is shaving at the sink. Hogan comes in, Newkirk and Carter are playing cards at the table. Hogan asks about the new tunnel entrance. Newkirk wants Hogan to try to find it; if he can't find it, the Germans probably can't. Hogan looks around for the entrance, gives up and asks them where it is. The entrance is under the sink. The prisoner shaving moves aside, and the sink stand hinges over to reveal the new tunnel entrance.

Later, the men to escape are in civilian clothes. Hogan tells LeBeau to get them through the new hole. The men go down the hole, and wait at the other end for clearance to leave. LeBeau opens up the hatch in the tree stump entrance, and sees 2 guards with 2 guard dogs close outside; he quickly closes the hatch and passes the word to Hogan. Hogan says that they will trade the Germans one end of the tunnel for the other. Hogan tells Newkirk and Carter to go out the tunnel, and give themselves up. Hogan tells Braden to wait for two stomps on the floor, and then leave. Carter, Newkirk, and LeBeau go out through the tunnel, and give up to the guards. One guard fires a shot, and searchlights move to the area. The camp goes on alert. Klink goes to a motorcycle sidecar, still getting dressed, putting his uniform coat over his white undershirt, having trouble with his boots. The dogs are let out. Klink goes out the gate on the motorcycle, still trying to put his boots on. Klink arrives at where Newkirk, Carter, and LeBeau were caught. Newkirk says that the tunnel started in Hut 3.

Klink gets back on the motorcycle and goes to Hut 3, still having trouble with his boots. He wants to know what is going on, and stomps his foot twice, trying to get a boot on; that is the signal for Braden to leave. Hogan wants to cancel that order; but the men go out the tunnel without attracting attention of the guards, who are busy with the three 'escapees'. Klink refers to a helicopter; Hogan says that they are waiting for spare parts. Klink says that the prisoners will fill the tunnel that night. Their punishment is hard labor, and then the next day more measures will be taken. Hogan says 'You can't win them all, but you can try'. While this was going on, the escapees got away.

At the end, Hogan is in Klink's outer office with Helga. Newkirk comes in dirty and grimy, says that the tunnel is filled in. Schultz comes in, wants to talk to Klink. Klink comes out, Schultz says that the tunnel is filled in. Klink gives all men 30 days in the cooler. Klink wants Hogan to parade the men and join them in the cooler. Hogan tell him that somebody has to warm up the helicopter.

description: Hogan talks Klink into building an officers' club, whereby a boat can be built to sail away with an escaped British POW and the German gunsight he snagged while escaping.
tags: ['boat', 'riding crop', 'english accent', 'stolen truck', 'schnapps', 'truck', 'party', 'telephone call', 'marching soldiers', 'life raft', 'bombsight', 'weather', 'smoking jacket', 'trailer', 'building a boat', 'boat trailer', 'ship figurehead', 'prussian helmet', 'yacht club', 'boat building']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Hogan and LeBeau are walking through bushes to a road. They are caught by Schultz; LeBeau runs off and comes back. LeBeau says that a truck is coming. The truck comes to a certain location and stops. Captain Michaels comes up, and says that supplies are in back. Hogan, LeBeau, and Michaels go back to camp; Hogan tells Schultz to hide the truck.

In Klink's office, Klink talks to Hogan with Schultz there. Klink refers to 'Captain Michaels', a prisoner at STALAG 5. Klink wants to keep the prisoners busy. Hogan says that the men are kept busy, Schultz agrees. Klink says that Michaels vanished, truck and all. He says that Michaels is in this vicinity, and puts Schultz in charge of finding the truck.

Back in the barracks, Hogan gets a radio message from London. They are to pick up Michaels and 'item'. They can't use the submarine, as there are too many guards outside searching for Michaels. Hogan has an idea.

Hogan goes to Klink's office; he talks to Helga in the outer office. Helga knocks on Klink's door and lets Hogan in. Hogan goes to a standing cabinet with a decanter on top, and gives Klink some schnapps, telling Klink that he looks tired. Klink has been supervising the search for Michaels around the clock. Hogan tells Klink that he has combat fatigue. He tells Klink that they have an officers' club at STALAG 5, and convinces Klink to have one at STALAG 13. Hogan has a design in mind, his decor man is LeBeau.

A few days later, outside, LeBeau is telling the Germans what to do regarding building the 'officers club', which is actually a boat. Schultz asks why they are building a boat, and asks Hogan how to get it out of camp. Klink comes up and starts talking; he orders an officers' club, and gets a boat; he says that they are 60 miles from the North Sea. Hogan butters up Klink regarding the boat.

Kinchloe gets a message on the radio saying that the weather for the week will be bad. The boat has to leave tonight. Klink wants to give a party tomorrow.

Klink goes into his office wearing a yacht club smoking jacket and a captain's hat. He asks Helga how she likes it, and she has 'no words' for it. Klink sings to Helga, but she does not like it. Klink kisses her hand; she tells him that he is really dreaming.

Klink talks to Hogan about the party. Hogan needs Klink's approval to load the boat with caviar and champagne. Klink says it is hard to think of Hogan as the enemy. Hogan gives a reference to General Burkhalter; Klink says that he did not invite Burkhalter. Hogan talks him into inviting Burkhalter. Klink has Helga make a phone call.

Later, Carter goes to Klink's office. He was at STALAG 5 with Kommandant Vogel. He said that Vogel had an officers' club, but Burkhalter said that it was too fancy. Carter has a hard time pronouncing 'Burhhalter', and stumbles 3 times. Klink's officers' club is fancier than Vogel's. Klink decides that he does not want the boat as an officers' club. Klink leaves the office, leaving Carter alone in the office; Carter tries on Klink's pickelhelb helmet. It fits.

Klink goes outside to the boat and talks with Hogan; he wants the ship demolished. LeBeau suggests a fire, but Klink says no. Klink tells Hogan to get rid of the boat. Newkirk asks some questions; Hogan asks Newkirk if someone told him that he makes great officer material; Newkirk is insulted. Klink asks if the boat is seaworthy; Hogan says that it had better be. Klink says to move the boat to water.

Klink brings 10 guards and Sergeant Kristman to get Hogan to move the boat. Hogan wants to get a life raft in there first. Two men of the German squad try to lift it, but can't. Then the whole squad lifts the raft into the boat. Michaels is in the life raft, which makes it so heavy; but the Germans do not know that. Hogan hooks the trailer that the boat is on to a truck. Hogan gets in the truck and starts it. Klink does not want Hogan driving the truck, as he thinks this is an escape attempt, so he orders Hogan out of the truck. He orders Kristman to take the boat to water. One guard gets in the truck and starts towing the boat away at a walking pace; other guards are walking beside the boat, similar to an honor guard escort. They take the boat out the gate.

At the end, coming out of Klink's office, Burkhalter thanks Klink for a dinner of stale sauerbrauten. Burkhalter gets in his car and leaves. Hogan comes into camp driving a truck; he says that this is the one that Michaels stole. Klink tells Schultz to get the dogs to the special detail; he says that Michaels is out there waiting for Klink to capture him.

description: Hogan and his men must destroy a German anti-aircraft artillery unit so that the Allies can send in a bombing raid on Hitler's birthday.
tags: ['lighting a cigarette', 'snowdrift', 'german 88 mm flak gun', 'party music', 'truck', 'birthday party', 'dance', 'chair', 'kiss', 'door', 'girlfriend', 'impersonating a german officer', 'uncredited speaking role', 'party girls', 'negotiating', 'banging fist', 'telephone call', 'anti aircraft gun', 'paratrooper', 'decanting wine', 'party decoration', 'prussian helmet', 'man disguised as a woman', 'encoded message', '2 way radio', 'antenna']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Schultz is guarding the barracks outside the door. Carter comes out, taps Schultz on the shoulder; this scares Schultz. Carter asks Schultz for a light for his cigarette; Schultz looks for a light, gives Carter his rifle, then gives him a light. Schultz does not worry about giving Carter his rifle as it is not loaded. Carter goes back in the barracks; as he closes the door, a pile of snow from the roof falls on Schultz.

Back in the barracks, Hogan gets a message from London. There will be a probing raid, not a full-scale invasion. They need information on troop movements. This is a reconnaissance job. Hogan needs someone with guts, who can move fast. Hogan volunteers LeBeau. LeBeau says that that is how he got married.

Later, LeBeau is dressed up as an old woman, looking at a nearby German camp from the woods. He takes notes of what he sees. He then comes back to camp. Hogan tries to call the submarine with the information, but Kinchloe says that their radio may be shut down because of the impending operation. At Schmeckhausen, 15 miles away, there are 12 guns, all German 88-mm guns. Hogan gets an idea how to get the information out. Hogan says that LeBeau mentioned Adolf Hitler's birthday. Hogan tells Kinch to get a motorcycle with a sidecar, and tells Carter to get two German uniforms.

Hogan, dressed as German Captain Hoganburg, and LeBeau, dressed as his assistant Corporal Hooplemann, go to see artillery Major Keitel in charge of the guns at Schmeckhausen. There is some discussion as to what will be done for Hitler's birthday. Keitel makes a phone call; Kinch and Newkirk intercept the call. Newkirk, impersonating a German officer, asks to speak to Hoganburg; he tells him to bring a case of wine. Hoganburg/Hogan tells Keitel of STALAG 13 nearby. He suggests that they borrow prisoners to do work for the party. On leaving, Hogan tells Keitel that 'Hooplemann' is his wife's brother.

Later, in Klink's outer office, Klink is kissing Helga. He invites Helga to a party. Helga asks where; Hogan says Schmeckhausen. Helga says that there is nothing in Schmeckhausen. Hogan says that there will be a party there. Helga asks who for; Hogan says it is for Hitler's birthday. Helga acts disappointed, and gives a half-hearted salute with her right hand. Hogan convinces her to invite some of her girlfriends to go to Schmeckhausen for the party.

Keitel calls Klink about using prisoners for the party. Hogan is listening in to a part of the conversation at Klink's closed office door. Klink comes out and asks Helga to call Hogan. Hogan is right there, which surprises Klink. Hogan goes into Klink's office and asks for additional hours of light, as it is Hitler's birthday. Hogan asks for 2 hours extra light in the evening; Klink says no, that the prisoners will use the light to build a tunnel. Hogan says that the tunnel is done, but they are building an elevator now. During the discussion, he puts Klink's pickelhelb helmet on Klink's chair while he is not looking. Klink talks about a party in Schmeckhausen, and asks for prisoners to help at the party. After some discussion Hogan deals with Klink for 1 hour of extra light and 2 ball games. Klink says that he will find the tunnel. Hogan leaves. On the way out, he reminds Helga to not forget the girls for the party. They hear Klink scream, apparently as he sits on his spiked helmet.

Later, at the party site, Newkirk tells Schultz that they are finished. There is a Nazi flag draped on the wall. Schultz counts the prisoners going into the truck. As they go into the back of the truck, Carter and others go out the front and come around to be counted again; this messes up Schultz's count.

Hogan, LeBeau, and 6 other prisoners are in German uniform. They go to the party area where Keitel is. Hogan says that he has orders to relieve Keitel, and Keitel is to go to the party. Keitel wants to still be in command at the guns. Helga and another woman in party dresses walk by; Keitel, after watching the girls, changes his mind and goes to the party with the girls. After Keitel leaves, Hogan and the men work on the guns.

Later, back at camp, LeBeau pours Hogan some wine. Hogan, Klink, and Schultz are in Klink's office drinking. LeBeau tells Hogan that the wine is almost vinegar. Klink asks Hogan where prisoners of war get wine. Hogan responds 'Does Macy tell Gimbel?' Hogan, at that time pretending to be partially drunk, tells a joke about a farmer and a farmer's daughter, which falls flat. There will be a roll call in the morning.

Early the next morning, while the party is still going on, there are scenes of planes passing by, landing craft landing troops, and paratroops dropping from planes. An air raid warning is sounded at the party; the men go to the guns. Keitel is taking ranges on the airplanes. He gives a gunner the range of 1500 yards and deflection information, the gunner answers. When they are supposedly on target, Keitel gives the 'fire' command. When six of the guns are fired, a flag pops out of the end of each with 'Happy Birthday Adolph'. Keitel doesn't believe what is happening, bangs a gun with his fist, and says 'schweinhund' several times.

At the end, Keitel and Klink are in Klink's office talking. Hogan and Helga are in the outer office, listening. Klink is arguing with Keitel about the prisoners' involvement with the sabotage of the guns. Klink insists that they did not do it. Keitel tells Klink that the prisoners did a good job at the party, and leaves. Klink goes to the outer office, and tells Hogan that the working party did a good job at the party. Klink then tells Hogan about camp buildings needing cleaning. Hogan denies the requests, and asks for 2 extra hours of light and some bread. He bargains with Klink as Helga watches the back and forth discussion.

description: The Germans have stolen a gold shipment from the French and Hogan must convince Klink to have it moved to the safety of Stalag 13.
tags: ['bricks', 'paint', 'saw', 'termites', 'gold', 'motorcycle', 'drugged', 'clothesline', 'dart', 'flat tire', 'puncturing tire', 'motorcycle with a sidecar', 'winking', 'point of view', 'breaking the fourth wall', 'stolen gold', 'gold theft', 'gold bar']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Schultz and a German guard driver are bringing a truck in to camp. Out of the back jumps a new prisoner, Captain Martin, who was recently shot down. Klink comes out, and berates Schultz for being 2 hours late. Hogan and the men see this, and then go into the barracks. They want to listen in on the conversation. Klink takes Martin into his office.

In Klink's office, it is mentioned that Martin was captured by a farmer, turned over to the Gestapo, and assigned to STALAG 13. Schultz says that he was late because he was held up because of gold bars being shipped to Dusseldorf. There was a brief discussion of the bars being 'stolen' vs. being 'confiscated'.

Hogan and the men are listening on the coffee pot to the conversation. Hogan has heard enough and pulls the plug on the coffee pot; the men know what Klink is going to be saying next. Kinchloe impersonates Klink saying 'No one has ever escaped from STALAG 13' and a few other things. Hogan tells the men that he wants to take the gold out of circulation. Kinch pulls down a map from the side of a bunk, and Hogan looks at it. He has Kinch write up a message to send to London: Approach from the north, avoid anti-aircraft batteries, target the bank. Hogan then says that Klink will be calling for him shortly.

In Klink's office, Klink is dictating a letter to Helga, Schultz comes in and says that Hogan wants to see Klink. Hogan comes in, and asks Martin how he likes it. Before he can answer, Klink interrupts; he talks about the cooler. Hogan then picks up Martins packet, and drops it on the floor. As he picks it up, he puts a paper in it, the message that he had Kinch write up. He also takes out a one-eye kaleidoscope viewer and looks in it. Klink asks what it is. Hogan responds 'You know that picture of Washington crossing the Delaware, well this ain't it'. As he is looking in the viewer, Klink picks up Martin's packet, and reads a message (the one that Hogan put in it). Klink says that the bombing is a diversion, and there was going to be a commando drop to steal the gold. Hogan convinces Klink to call the Gestapo to offer to keep the gold at STALAG 13. Klink dismisses Hogan and Martin.

Later, Hogan and the men are cleaning the porch of Klink's office. Schultz comes by and asks what they are doing. Hogan tells Schultz that they volunteered, they want to tidy up the camp. Klink comes out and asks what is going on. Schultz tries to explain. Klink tells the men to carry on, and goes back into his office. The men keep cleaning, while whistling the Hogan's Heroes theme song. While this is going on, LeBeau is quietly sawing a cut in the brace of one of the steps.

Shortly later, the men are watching Klink's porch from in front of the barracks. Schultz walks down the steps; they do not collapse. LeBeau says that he thought he sawed it through enough. Then Klink comes out of his office, steps on a step, and they collapse. Hogan and the men go to Klink to help him up. Hogan says that termites have eaten through the steps. Carter starts telling a story about an uncle with a wooden leg, and what the termites did to that leg. Hogan interrupts him; he tells Klink that they will re-build the steps. But not with wood; the termites would just eat that through also. Hogan convinces Klink to rebuild the steps with bricks.

A van led by a motorcycle with a sidecar comes into STALAG 13.

Major Krieger, Gestapo, gets out of the sidecar. He thanks Klink for offering STALAG 13 as a site to keep the gold temporarily. Klink tells Schultz to guide the truck behind barracks 5. As it is going back there, LeBeau and Carter start stringing a clothesline, and Schultz backs into it. This stops Schultz and the truck. Newkirk throws a dart from inside the barracks into the truck tire, and the tire pops and goes flat. Krieger wants the flat repaired, but the guards say that with the weight of the gold, they can not jack up the truck. Krieger tells Klink to post a guard while they are fixing the flat. Krieger opens the side door of the truck to get some papers, and closes it. As it is closing, Newkirk puts a plastic marker in front of the latch to keep the door from locking.

That evening, Schultz is taking a coffee pot past the barracks. He is going to give it to the two Gestapo guards guarding the truck. Newkirk and LeBeau stop him and start talking to him. When a spotlight goes by, Schultz covers Newkirk and LeBeau. Newkirk and LeBeau suggest to Schultz that he grab a few gold bars. Schultz says that the gold was 'confiscated' from the Bank of France, it was not 'stolen'. As they are talking, Newkirk puts some pills in the spout of the coffee pot. These turn out to be sleeping pills. After the conversation, Schultz continues on, and goes to the truck with the coffee pot. He talks to the guards in German, and pours them some coffee; they thank him for it. After a few minutes, the sleeping pills take effect, and the guards fall asleep.

Newkirk and Carter take the guards in through the barrack's window, take their uniforms, and put them in bunks, still asleep. Hogan tells Newkirk to remember to open the door of the truck. Newkirk and Carter then stand guard on the truck in Gestapo uniforms. LeBeau goes in the truck, and starts passing boxes of the gold to other prisoners, who form a chain to pass the boxes down into the tunnel. Krieger comes by and asks how things are going. This is night, and Krieger can not see their faces. Newkirk says a few words, supposedly in German, and Krieger leaves. Carter says that he didn't know that Newkirk spoke German; Newkirk says that neither did he, until now.

Down in the tunnel, the gold bricks are taken out of the boxes, and dipped in brick-colored paint, while bricks are dipped in gold-colored paint. LeBeau holds one of each up in front of Hogan and asks him which is real. Hogan says 'Eenig, meeney, miney, .... money' and points to one brick; LeBeau says no, it is the other one. When the work is done, the gold-painted bricks are put in the boxes, and they are passed up through the tunnel, where a chain again passes them out to the truck. When they are all put back, Newkirk and Carter come back in, put the Gestapo uniforms back on the guards, and take the guards out to the truck, where they put them lying against the truck, sleeping, Hogan comes by and wakes one of the guards; Hogan says that he was sleeping on duty, and is lucky an officer didn't catch him. This guard then wakes the other guard, and says that he is lucky an officer didn't catch him.

The next day, the men are re-building the steps with bricks; actually the gold bricks that were dipped in the brick-colored paint. LeBeau says that they are running out of bricks; Hogan tells him to go to the 'bank' and get more 'bricks'. As they are doing this, Krieger, the Gestapo guards, and the truck leave camp.

Klink thanks the men for building the steps. Hogan says that the steps are as good as gold, and the men cheer.

At the end, Klink and Krieger are in Klink's office. Krieger says that the gold is missing and may be at STALAG 13. Klink tells Krieger to search. He says 'If you find any gold, use this rifle to shoot me', and he takes Schultz's rifle. Klink then hands the rifle to Hogan, and Krieger goes to search. Hogan says that he would like to sit this one out.

description: While Hogan detains a German general during an Allied offensive, a Gestapo officer looks into Stalag 13's perfect escape record.
tags: ['pantomime', 'hit on the head', 'drugged', 'champagne', 'sprayed with water', 'flashlight', 'periscope', 'character name in episode title']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Schultz is chasing the men into the barracks from the compound. They want to know what is going on. LeBeau looks out through the sink periscope. A German general with a bunch of medals has arrived. He seems to be an old friend of Klink's, and they hug. Kinchloe tells Hogan that a German general has arrived. The general, General Stoffle of the Africa Korps, and Klink go into Klink's office. Stoffle drinks a toast to Klink, who was two grades ahead of him in school, and now is two grades behind him. Stoffle calls Klink 'Putzi'. Klink says that he arranged a luncheon at the Officers' Club. Stoffle says that the allies would give anything to know where he is. Hogan and the men are listening in on the coffee pot. Hogan tells Kinchloe to radio London on the general's location.

They get a radio message from London back. London wants Hogan to keep the general at STALAG 13 for a while; no suggestions on how.

LeBeau looks out the sink periscope again, and sees Stoffle in the back of his staff car, supposedly sleeping. Hogan wants to bring Stoffle to the barracks, then take him down the tunnel, and take him to England for the duration. Hogan says that they need a diversion; he has Newkirk and Carter to call Schultz to the barracks. Schultz comes into the barracks. Newkirk and Carter have a guessing game with Schultz trying to guess his weight. He ultimately says 295 pounds. While they are doing this, Hogan and LeBeau go to the staff car to get the general. They open the back door, and see a fraulein in the back seat; this is the general's girlfriend. Just then, a Gestapo major comes in through the front gate in his staff car. The fraulein goes to Klink's office; Stoffle wants private quarters for them.

The Gestapo major starts to unload equipment from a truck. He shows Klink a listening device; then a large flashlight which can blind anybody at a certain range, and use the back of it to crack skulls. Hogan comes to Klink's office; he tells the Gestapo that they won't find what they are looking for - the general's girlfriend. Hogan says that the girl has been seen constantly with Himmler. Hogan tells Klink to not let the Gestapo leave early; Klink would surely be implicated. Hogan offers LeBeau to supply food and drink, and entertain them in Klink's quarters. Hogan says that they have to keep the Gestapo busy.

The Gestapo major, Major Zolle, tells two of his men to go to the warehouse. He asks Schultz about a wireless radio; Schultz has a shovel and wires. Klink is nervous; Schultz follows Zolle. Zolle uses the device to find tunnels; he thinks he finds one, and tells Schultz to dig. Schultz digs, and hits something. Zolle leans over it to take a look. Kinch and Carter are watching from beside the barracks. Kinch tells Carter to 'Fire when ready, Gridley;. Carter turns a valve, and water gushes up the 'tunnel' opening, spraying Zolle in the face and all over.

In Klink's quarters, Stoffle and his girlfriend are having a meal, with LeBeau serving. LeBeau puts pills in the general's drink, and gives the two drinks to the general and his girlfriend. Stoffle switches glasses with the girlfriend, and they drink up. She falls asleep; the intention was to have Stoffle fall asleep.

The two Gestapo guards go to a warehouse with Newkirk and Carter. The Gestapo climb up on boxes to inspect a vent, with Carter holding a light. When they get up to the vent, Carter puts the light out, walks out, and pulls a rope which is attached to the boxes. The Gestapo fall, and Newkirk and Carter take some of their equipment.

In the mean time, Zolle finds something with his device, something on the other side of the ceiling. He breaks through the wood ceiling, into the floor of the warehouse above. The Gestapo guards think that someone is escaping, so one of them hits Zolle on the head and knocks him out and down. The guard realizes that it was Zolle after he has done it.

In Klink's quarters, the girlfriend is knocked out on the sofa while the general is pacing. Hogan comes in and silently asks LeBeau what happened. LeBeau tries to explain with gestures that the glasses were switched, and she got knocked out instead of him. Hogan then comes in the room, and asks Stoffle if he is ready for lunch. Stoffle says to bring cars. Hogan tells Stoffle that Himmler is crazy about the girlfriend. Hogan convinces Stoffle to put on a prisoner uniform in order to get out of camp with the Gestapo there. LeBeau says that Stoffle is a size 44 regular.

Zolle and the other Gestapo guards go to the barracks, and he says that the holiday is over. Zolle and another Gestapo approach a prisoner and start talking to him. While he is talking to a prisoner, Hogan tells Schultz about a 'defector', in the back of Klink's car. Klink comes up and asks what is going on. Schultz opens the door, and sees Stoffle in a prisoner uniform. Zille catches the 'defector'; Stoffle insists that he is General Stoffle. Zolle takes Stoffle away. Klink turns to hogan and says that there is something diabolical about Hogan; Hogan says that he knows.

At the end, in Klink's office, Klink says that Hogan will get 30 days in the cooler. Klink says that there was a big offensive in the desert. The allies got through with Stoffle not being there. Hogan says that Klink was lucky; Stoffle would have talked Klink into being a tank commander. Hogan then tells Klink that Klink was brilliant at the way he got rid of the Gestapo. Klink gives Hogan a cigar. and a light; Hogan says 'Danke'.

description: Hogan's latest underground contacts are secretly German spies.
tags: ['fire in an oil drum', 'poker the card game', 'dropping bombs', 'truck', 'dynamite', 'kiss', 'barn', 'trench', 'warehouse', 'shooting', 'sleeping on duty', 'requisition', 'blackmail', 'sabotage', 'plunger', 'fraternizing with the enemy', 'full house', 'four kings', 'explosion', 'detonator', 'tunnel', '2 way radio', 'map', 'archive footage', 'consolidated b 24 liberator', 'whispering']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Schultz, Hogan, LeBeau, Newkirk, and Kinchloe are sitting at a table in the barracks. LeBeau is watching while the rest play poker. Schultz says that he is temporarily out of funds, and asks for forbearance based on his integrity. Hogan hesitates, and asks for information. Schultz tells the men that yesterday, a small bridge was blown up. They continue play; the camera shows Schultz holding a full house. He wants to bet more, but he does not have the money. Hogan asks for some more information. The night before, a barn was set on fire. At the end of the hand, Schultz thinks that won with his full house; Hogan says that he got lucky, and drew two more kings; he has 4 kings, which beats Schultz's full house. Hogan tells Schultz that he is lousy at poker, but a wonderful traitor.

That night, Hogan and LeBeau meet 4 supposedly Underground agents in a barn, 3 men and 1 woman. After talking for a minute, bombs are heard dropping. B-24 bombers are dropping bombs in the area. Hogan says that they are better outside, and takes the woman outside, and they get cozy in a nearby trench.

The next day in Klink's office, a Gestapo captain in a gray uniform visits Klink. This is the same man that was one of the Underground agents that met with Hogan the day before. The captain points out on a map the sabotage that has been happening in the area. He asks Klink what is in the center of the area? STALAG 13. There are partisans operating in the area. He says that he was impersonating an Underground agent and met with some of them last night.. He tells Klink that he will lead the band into a trap. Hogan and the men are listening in on the coffee pot. Hogan recognizes the voice of the Gestapo man as the Underground agent that he met the night before. The Gestapo captain says that the only strategic target in the area that has not been hit yet is a railroad tunnel. Hogan, listening in, asks why they haven't hit it yet. Carter says that they have not gotten to it yet. Hogan says that they are going to blow it up now.

That night, at the barn, Hogan meets the 'Underground agents' again. He says that they will hit STALAG 13. There will be many prisoners running around and tying up troops trying to find them. He asks the Underground leader for dynamite. Hogan and LeBeau leave the barn, the female agent follows them, then talks to Hogan. She talks about the operation; Hogan, knowing that she is in cahoots with the Gestapo, plays hard to get. She suggests that they get out of Germany. She suggests getting close, but Hogan says no, he doesn't want to get close to anybody in the war. She leaves, and goes back into the barn. LeBeau then talks to Hogan a bit.

The next day, in camp, Schultz is guarding a warehouse, but is sleeping by the door. The Gestapo captain comes by and wakes him up. He gives Schultz a requisition for some dynamite and leaves. Hogan comes up to Schultz; Hogan thinks that the Gestapo captain may have recognized him. Schultz wonders about the dynamite, and goes into the warehouse. There he sees LeBeau, Carter, and 4 other unnamed prisoners taking dynamite out of the building through a tunnel. Hogan tells Schultz that some of the dynamite is bad and they are replacing it with some that is underneath. Schultz sees this and says that in war he does not want to take sides, but he wants to report this. Hogan reminds Schultz about the poker game.

In Klink's office, the Gestapo captain tells Klink that the Underground will be attacking STALAG 13 tonight. They will dynamite the guard towers, but the dynamite is not real. He shows Klink a shortwave radio, and tells Klink to listen to the radio; it is to be manned at all times. He then leaves. Hogan comes into Klink's office, and protests the usage of prisoners to load munitions. Klink does not care. He orders all prisoners confined to the barracks tonight. Hogan sees the short wave set, and asks Klink if he is setting up a command post. Klink says that Hogan will see the other side of Klink tonight. Klink coyly gives Hogan permission to peek even though he is confined to barracks. Hogan says that he can't stand the sight of blood, and leaves.

That night, Hogan, Carter, and LeBeau go to the barn where they meet the 'Underground' agents. Hogan talks about a change in plans, they will hit the railroad tunnel instead. The lead 'agent' says that he wants to check the munitions, giving an excuse to leave and call Klink about the change in plans. Hogan leaves the barn, the woman and the other two 'agents' follow. The lead 'agent' calls Klink on the radio, but can't get him. Kinch and Newkirk are on a radio, with Kinch impersonating Klink. They talk with the lead 'agent' about the change in plans.

In Klink's office, Schultz keeps trying to get somebody on the radio but can't. He finally finds what the problem is: wires on the radio have been cut. Klink says that this means that the attackers are already in camp.

In the railroad tunnel, Hogan, Carter, and 3 'agents' are setting charges. Hogan leaves the tunnel and talks to the lead 'agent'. The woman agent goes to Hogan and tells him that he is Gestapo. He pulls a pistol on Hogan, and tells that the charges are fake. He presses the plunger, and blows up the tunnel. He then gets in the truck to leave. At first, it can't start; Carter suggests that he use some choke. The truck starts, and he leaves.

At STALAG 13, Klink, Schultz and 8 guards are waiting by the front gate. They hear a truck approaching. Klink says that they are the attackers, and orders open fire, and they start shooting. After several seconds, the truck crashes. Schultz says that the Gestapo captain is attacking.

Back at the tunnel, Hogan is with the woman 'agent'. He tells her that he will get her out of Germany. Hogan and the woman then kiss.

At the end, in Klink's office, Hogan and Klink are talking. Klink says that a railroad tunnel was blown up last night, and if the prisoners were not confined to barracks, he would suspect Hogan. He says that the Gestapo captain was attacking, and got shot. Hogan convinces Klink that the Gestapo was shot by the saboteurs; Klink eventually agrees. Hogan leaves the office.

description: Sergeant Schultz impersonates Klink in a scheme to get some of his men free from the Gestapo.
tags: ['impersonating an officer', 'truck', 'jail', 'desk', 'impersonating an enemy soldier', 'captured by enemy', 'cheering', 'explosion', 'train wreck', 'detonator']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Newkirk, Carter, LeBeau, and Kinchloe are in the bushes by some railroad tracks waiting for a train to get to the right spot. Kinch is watching, and says '1, 2, 3'; when he gets to 3, Carter pushed the plunger, and there is a big explosion; the train is destroyed. After some cheering, Newkirk, Kinch, and LeBeau ask Carter which way back to camp. Carter does not know; he is lost. Kinch leaves and says that he will climb a tree to see where they are. Just after he leaves, a German patrol of 4 soldiers (1 a corporal) come up behind the others and take them away. Kinch sees this as he comes back.

Back at camp, Kinch comes up the tunnel alone, looking sad. He says nothing to Hogan and shakes his head. Hogan seems to understand.

In the basement of the Gestapo office in town, Newkirk, LeBeau, and Carter are questioned by a Gestapo officer. Carter has the papers for 'Antonio Cavelli', LeBeau the papers for 'Jock MacPherson', and Newkirk the papers for 'Heinrich Hilgenbecker'. The Gestapo officer does not believe them. He tells them that they could be shot. Newkirk says that they can't do that because they were in uniform. The Gestapo officer says that they will be taken to STALAG 4 before being taken to Berlin for further questioning.

In Klink's office, Hogan is talking to Klink and asks for movies in return for the prisoners performing Work. Klink does not know what to do and wants to call Berlin for further information. Klink then looks out the window and sees the men working; Hogan says that it is a mark of 'good faith'. Klink tries to get Berlin on the phone, but he hears a General Kinchmeyer (actually Kinchloe) on the line. He thinks that the phone lines have been crossed, so he hangs up. After hearing the attempted phone call, Hogan does not look well; he says that it is 'the old ticker'.

The next day at roll call, Schultz counts the prisoners, and there are 3 missing. Schultz wishes that there were 4 missing; him being the fourth. Hogan tells Schultz to report all present; he does so, reluctantly.

Shortly later in the barracks, Hogan explains to Schultz that Newkirk, Carter, and LeBeau were out for a walk and were grabbed by the Gestapo. Hogan says that if Schultz reports it, he could by shot, or sent to the Russian front. Kinch says 'Or both'. Schultz thinks aloud how they could do that, and then says that they could do it. Hogan convinces Schultz to go to STALAG 4 as an officer to get them back. Schultz says no, leaves the barracks, and 10 seconds later, comes back in, saying he will do it.
