Kinch measures Schultz for a uniform; neck 19, waist 52. Schultz says the other measurements are the same as his waist. Schultz then says that he does not have the courage, and leaves. Hogan asks Kinch how much material is needed for the uniform for Schultz. Kinch says 'How may inches are in an acre?'

Later, outside Klink's office, Klink leaves the office and the guard comes to attention. Schultz is standing out front; Hogan comes up and gives him a cigarette. Kinch then gives Schultz some chocolate bars. Klink sees them give Schultz these things, and comes up to him, asking why he took those things. Klink tells Schultz to put himself on report, takes them from Schultz, and puts them in his coat and leaves. Hogan comes up to Schultz and says that if he gets on report, it becomes a part of his record. When the Gestapo adds information from the boys who were captured, Schultz goes to the Russian front. Essentially, Hogan is blackmailing Schultz.

In the barracks, Hogan is collecting money for a 'widow'. After hearing some of the conversation, Schultz thinks that it is his widow that they are collecting for, so he tries to give the money back.

Shortly later, Schultz comes out of Hogan's office in an officer's uniform. Hogan shows him what to say and how to act, using Kinch acting as the other 'kommandant'. Schultz practices, but gets it wrong. He has more practice, and he drops the monocle, and it shatters. More practice, and Schultz gets meaner. Hogan thinks he comes close.

In the compound, Hogan and Kinch make final plans for the operation. Schultz and Hogan take a truck to STALAG 4 to get the men out. Schultz is dressed as a Colonel, and Hogan as his aide, a captain.

When they get there, they go into Major Bernsdorf's office, the Kommandant of STALAG 4. Bernsdorf says that it is an honor to meet the famous Colonel Klink, and offers refreshments; Schultz drinks some schnapps, but Hogan tells him that time is limited. Schultz has Hogan give Bernsdorf the names of the prisoners he wants. Bernsdorf says that he has no authority to release those prisoners; they are there by orders of the Gestapo. Schultz demands to release the prisoners at once; Bernsdorf denies the request. Just then, there is a phone call from 'General Kinchmeyer' from the Gestapo (actually Kinchloe impersonating a general, sitting at Klink's desk making the phone call). He tells Bernsdorf to release the 3 prisoners. Bernsdorf says that he has no written authorization. 'Kinchmeyer' says release them or suffer the consequences, and hangs up. Bernsdorf has the 3 men brought to outside his office. Schultz says to put them in the truck. Carter says 'Isn't that that terrible Colonel Schultz from STALAG 13?' Hogan says 'No, that is the terrible Colonel Klink from STALAG 13'. Schultz wants to have somebody shot and sent to the Russian front. While Schultz is talking, Hogan says that Sergeant Schultz is waiting; Schultz gets the subtle message that he has to leave. All of them go into the truck. When they get into the truck, LeBeau says that Schultz did a good job at the impersonation. Schultz did not hear him; he has fainted. Hogan drives off back to STALAG 13.

At the end, back at camp, the Gestapo officer is there, inspecting the men at roll call. He says that an officer stating he was Klink came to STALAG 4 and took the prisoners. Klink says that no one in the camp left last night. The Gestapo says that the investigation will continue. After he leaves, Hogan says to Klink that the description he gave fits Schultz. Klink laughs 'Schultz an officer?' and walks off. Hogan suggests that Schultz go on a diet, just in case, Hogan then tells the men to fall out.

description: To get an Italian officer to defect, the Heroes use pizza to tempt him.
tags: ['motorcycle with sidecar', 'wounded soldier', 'submarine', 'rifle', 'santa lucia song', 'staff car', 'supreme allied headquarters', 'telephone call', 'newark new jersey', 'pizza', 'encoded message', 'aerial bombardment', 'archive footage', 'defector', 'volleyball', 'north american b 25 mitchell', "chef's hat", 'crepe suzette', 'breaking the fourth wall', 'italian soldier']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Le Beau is scrambling eggs, with the others in the barracks. Carter sounds an alarm that Klink is coming. The men quickly stash the food and the preparation equipment. Klink tells Hogan and the men that they are going to have a visitor, a Major Bonacelli, who runs an Italian POW camp near Capezio, Italy. He is going to study Klink's methods of running a camp.

Later, Hogan, using the call sign 'Goldilocks' calls 'Mama Bear', a submarine, asking for information. The submarine officer says that their G-2 says that their is friction between the Germans and the Italians. There is going to be a landing near Capezio, and they want information on the German dispositions in the area.

Major Bonacelli is in a staff car with a Corporal driver going to STALAG 13. Bonacellil wants to go to Switzerland instead; the driver objects. Bonacelli pulls a pistol to try to get the driver to drive. Just then, there is a bombing raid. Several bombs drop nearby. The driver runs off into the woods. Just then, a motorcycle with a sidecar appears, Corporal Langenscheidt is in the side car. Langenscheidt says that he is the escort to STALAG 13, and asks where the driver is. Bonacelli gives an excuse that the driver ran away.

Back at the camp, some of the prisoners are playing volleyball. They coax Schultz to participate; Schultz hands his rifle to Newkirk, and starts hitting the ball. Just then Klink brings Bonacelli to meet Hogan. Bonacelli sees Newkirk with Schultz's rifle, and asks if it is policy to let prisoners carry guns. Schultz says that the rifle is not loaded; Bonacellil says that their rifles are always loaded. Langenscheidt then comes to Klink asking what to have for dinner. Bonacelli mentions some Italian foods; Klink says potato soup, names some other potato dishes, and sauerkraut. After Langenscheidt, Klink, and Bonacelli leave, Hogan says that there is a way to get to Bonacelli: food. He asks the men there if any of them knows a recipe for pizza. When they say no, Hogan asks them to ask other prisoners in the camp if they have a recipe for pizza. The men come back, not finding any. A prisoner, Garlotti, says that his father runs a pizza parlor in Newark, New Jersey, and has a recipe for pizza.

Hogan gets back on the radio, calling the submarine. He asks to put a phone call through to Garlotti's Pizzeria in Newark. The submarine officer questions this. He then calls London on the submarine radio, and makes the same request. The sergeant handling the radio talks to the supervisor, Captain Henderson, about this. Captain Henderson in London questions what is going on. When the submarine officer says that it is for 'Goldilocks', Henderson says that he should have known. Henderson then calls Garlotti's Pizzeria in Newark, He tells the owner that his son is fine, and asks for the recipe for pizza; the elder Garlotti gives it to him. Henderson relays the ingredients and instructions to the sergeant, who relays it to the submarine over the radio, who then relays it to Hogan on the other radio, who has Kinchloe write it down. Hogan then asks for the words to the song Santa Lucia. The submarine officer, sergeant, and Henderson in turn say 'Santa Lucia?' The elder Garlotti then starts singing Santa Lucia. Hogan apparently writes the words down.

Later, Bonacelli and Schultz are walking in the camp at night, Schultz asks Bonacelli if he enjoyed dinner. Bonacelli says that he couldn't eat it. They then hear prisoners singing Santa Lucia in the barracks. Bonacelli says that he wants to 'inspect the barracks, alone'. He enters the barracks and smells pizza. After some talking, Hogan has LeBeau bring out a pizza. Hogan asks Bonacelli how many pizzas might be made for the Germans, at two pizzas per soldier. Bonacelli says 106,000. A place is then rolled out on a table, and Bonacelli starts eating the pizza with wine. He asks where they got the recipe from, and is told a pizzeria in Newark. He says that he is going to go to Newark. Hogan says that that would be after the war; Bonacelli says no, during the war. He says that he does not want to go back to Italy and fight for the Germans, he wants to go to Switzerland. Hogan then asks Bonacelli to be an agent for them in Capezia. Bonacelli agrees, but he has to have the recipe for the pizza.

After he is finished with the pizza, Bonacelli and Hogan go out into the yard. Just then a motorcycle with a sidecar brings the wounded driver that ran away in the bombing raid in as a passenger. The driver confronts Bonacelli in front of Klink's office, and says he is a traitor. Klink puts Bonacelli in the cooler.

Hogan tunnels into the cooler to get Bonacelli, Bonacelli is surprised as Hogan lifts up the hatch through the hay covering the floor. He tells Bonacelli that some prisoners will 'escape' and Bonacelli will recapture them; that will get him out of the cooler. Bonacelli does not know what is happening, but follows Hogan down the tunnel.

Klink calls Berlin regarding Bonacelli being a traitor, talking to an un-named general on the phone. While he is talking, Schultz comes in and tells Klink that 10 prisoners have escaped, 11 if the Italian is included. Klink sends out an alarm, and has the guards out looking for them. After looking, Langenscheidt comes back and tells Klink that he saw no sign of the prisoners. The dog that was with him found nothing; Klink asks the dog 'You call yourself a German Shepherd?' and tells the dog that he couldn't find a can of dog food. The dog objects to the insult, and starts snarling at Klink.

Hogan and the other 'escaped' prisoners are waiting outside the camp; they can't find Bonacelli. Bonacelli finally appears, and Hogan tells him that he will march the prisoners back to camp. The prisoners then march through the gate in a column of twos whistling the Hogan's Heroes theme song. Hogan is leading the left column, Kinchloe the right column, with Carter, Newkirk, LeBeau, and 5 un-named 'extras'. Bonacelli says that he has found the prisoners. Hogan says that they had no chance, as Bonacelli is Klink's star pupil. Klink tells the prisoners that they will all get the cooler; Hogan marches the prisoners away, whistling.

At the end, Klink sends for Hogan. Klink got a letter from Bonaceili from Italy, stating that the prisoners there are working 16 hours a day making pizzas. The are currently working on 110,000, and can expect to get to 120,000. Hogan does some fast calculations in the air (divide by 2 to get the numbers of troops). Hogan then tells Klink 'Don't say the Italians aren't with you all the way.'

description: Hogan has a mission to move a mobile anti-aircraft artillery battery, but Klink's new tough second-in-command is impeding the Heroes.
tags: ['parachute', 'staff car', 'filing cabinet', 'personnel file', 'jacket', 'interrogation', 'escape', 'roll call', 'clothes rack', 'executive officer', 'coat', 'liquor', 'corporal', 'major', 'general', 'sergeant', 'colonel', 'map', 'pretending to be sick', 'periscope', 'whistling', 'board game', 'detonator cap', 'paratrooper', 'archive footage', 'c 119 flying boxcar']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Newkirk and Carter are out of the camp at night. They signal a plane. A parachute comes out of the middle of 3 C-119 aircraft flying over. They go get who jumped out.

Shortly later, in the tunnel, Hogan is talking, with Kinchloe on the radio talking to a submarine. Kinch is getting news, as well as mission information. The St. Louis Browns are in first place, and the bank is going to foreclose on Mary Noble. Hogan says don't tell Carter about Mary Noble. Kinch also says that the German 43rd Mobile anti-aircraft battery is at Kaiserhof. Planes are going to raid factories at that city, and they want the 43rd knocked off. Explosives are on the way. The man who jumped from the plane, Lynch, brought the explosives. When asked about the detonators, Lynch says that the explosives and detonators are always kept separate. Hogan takes Lynch's jacket, puts it on a table, rips it open, and takes out the detonators. Lynch is surprised that he was also carrying the detonators as well as the explosives.

Later, in the barracks, Hogan is talking with the men about the mission. Carter and Newkirk are in German uniforms. Carter is complaining that his does not fit. Newkirk is wearing one chevron pointing down, a Gefreiter, or Lance Corporal; Carter is a private. Hogan says to plant the explosives in the recoil mechanism. Kinchloe is watching the door; he says that Schultz is coming. Carter hides underneath blankets in a bunk, Newkirk hides behind a clothes rack, Hogan and LeBeau pretend to play a board game, with the back of the map as the game board. Schultz sees Carter in bed; Hogan says that Carter is lazy. Schultz then finds Newkirk hiding behind a clothing rack; Newkirk says that he is in a German uniform. Schultz laughs and does not believe him. Schultz tells Hogan that Klink wants to see him.

In Klink's office, Major Kuehn has arrived; he is to be Klink's new executive officer. He is temporarily second in command. Hogan comes to Klink's office and meets Kuehn. Kuehn has doubled the guards and taken more security precautions. Hogan asks why, as there have been no escapes from camp. Kuehn says that there were 293 attempts; Hogan says 291, don't give him credit for the 2 guards. Kuehs says that his uncle is Field Marshall Karl von Streicher, which brings some fear to Klink. Klink at first objected to doubling the guard as Kuehn did not notify him, but after he hears who Kuehn's uncle is, Klink 'makes the decision' to double the guard around the perimeter. Kuehn leave Klink's office. Hogan does not like Kuehn, and he can see that Klink does not either. So he gives Klink 3 choices, none of them Klink likes.

That night, down in the tunnel, Newkirk and Carter come back down panting. They say that the woods are crawling with Germans and they are lucky to get back. Hogan has Kinch radio the sub. He wants to put off the party, but the radio says 'No'. Hogan then tells Lynch to fall out in roll call; he has an idea of what he is going to do.

At roll call the next morning, Schultz counts 15, as there should be. Hogan quietly points out to Schultz that someone is going into Klink's car. Schultz goes to the car and catches Lynch. Lynch says that he was shot down and got in the car, he did not know where it was going. Klink wants to interrogate Lynch; Kuehn says that it is up to the executive officer to interrogate prisoners. Schultz takes Lynch away. Hogan tells the men that that was the first step. Newkirk asks what is the next step. Hogan says that he will have to think about it.

In the barracks, Lynch is back. Hogan asks him about the interrogation; Lynch says that he just gave name, rank, and serial number.

In Klink's office, Klink and Kuehn are talking about the interrogation. Hogan comes in and wants to keep the light on late, because of the celebration. Hogan talks about Kaiserhof and the 43rd Group. Hogan opens the door, and tells Helga that if she is going out, to stay out of Hammelburg. Hogan leaves.

Klink wants to call the 43rd to tell them to move to Hammelburg. Kuehn says that Hogan wanted Klink to believe it. Klink says that he was just testing Kuehn.

As the next step in the plan, Hogan has the men assemble out front of the barracks, by the side so Kuehn can overhear them. First Hogan says that whoever stole Newkirk's watch, forget it. He stole it back. Then he says that tomorrow, the day our Red Cross packages arrive, the packages may be detained. He does not give details. Kuehn is around the corner of the building, listening.

Later, Klink talks with Kuehn about his uncle, and what he is going to be saying to his uncle. Kuehn comes to attention and says that his loyalty rests with Klink, his commanding officer. Kuehn asks Klink about the route that the truck carrying the packages takes to STALAG 13. Klink says that it starts from the southwest, goes through 3 cities, and then comes to Hammelburg. Kuehn is up to something. He suggests that Klink check gate security; the commanding officer is required to check the gate security daily. Klink tells Kuehn to his face that he has confidence in him. After Klink leaves the office, he says that he does not trust that man.

Kuehn calls General Burkhalter on the phone; he has some information to give him. He suggests moving the 43rd to Hammelburg because of an impending raid.

Hogan overhears this on the coffee pot. He tells Kinch to radio the submarine that it is OK for Kaiserhof.

The next day, outside of Klink's office, Hogan talks to Kuehn about the upcoming visit of General Burkhalter. Klink wants to know why he was not informed of the visit; as the kommandant he needs to be informed of all general officer visits. Kuehn hints that Burkhalter may be bringing a visitor with him, hinting that it may be his uncle, the field marshall.

Burkhalter comes to camp; Klink greets him. He just tells Klink that he has some here to see Kuehn. Kuehn asks if the operation was a success. Burkhalter says that it was a success - for the allies. They bombed Kaiserhof instead of Hammelburg. Kuehn is shocked. Hogan says that the prisoners voted to make him an honorary prisoner; Burkhalter wants to make that official. Burkhalter then says that his uncle the field marshall was on an inspection tour, which took him to the chemical works as Kaiserhof.

At the end, Hogan is in Klink's office looking through files. He is apparently looking for Lynch's file. Lynch is gone; Klink says that his record is ruined. Hogan says that he came in in the back of a staff car, he went out in the back of a staff car. Klink looks for Lynch's file, but can't find it. Klink says that he admires Hogan's spirit. Hogan pours a glass of schnapps and drinks it, while Klink looks miffed at him.

description: A new prisoner in a corporal's uniform turns out to be a general with a mission for Hogan.
tags: ['homing beacon', 'motorcycle', 'bronx cheer', 'truck', 'trash barrel', 'guard tower', 'flat tire', 'towel', 'porch', 'camera', 'knot', 'knife', 'cigarette', 'machine gun', 'tire jack', 'puncturing tire', 'champagne', 'climbing a ladder', 'distraction', 'swimsuit', 'radio broadcast', 'starting a fire']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Schultz brings Hogan to Klink's office. Schultz tries to keep in step with Hogan, but Hogan purposely changes stride to throw Schultz off. In Klink's office, Klink tells Hogan that it is up to Hogan to maintain discipline. He tells Hogan that he was disrespected by the men at roll call this morning.- he gives a 'Bronx cheer'. Hogan convinces Klink that the Bronx cheer is a sign of respect, Klink says that a new prisoner, Corporal Walter Tillman, serial number 3634422, will be arriving tomorrow. Hogan gives Klink a Bronx Cheer as he leaves the office. Klink seems pleased, and he smiles.

A truck then pulls into camp. A new prisoner, Corporal Walter Tillman, gets out of the back with two guards. He tells Hogan that he was with the 602nd Engineers, 82nd Airborne Division, captured at Normandy. In the barracks, there is a 'discussion' between Tillman, Newkirk, and others, specifically Tillman will not let Newkirk have his pack of cigarettes. Hogan tells Tillman to go take a shower. Hogan does not like Tillman's attitude, so he wants to get Klink to transfer him to STALAG 18.

Hogan needs to convince Klink to transfer Tillman. Newkirk, LeBeau, and Kinchloe toss some papers into a trans barrel outside of Klink's office Hogan lights a cigarette and tosses it into the trash barrel, setting it on fire. The men scream about the fire, and then put it out. Klink wants to know what is going on, so he calls Hogan into his office. Klink questions Hogan about the incident. Hogan pretends to not give information, while actually giving information. Hogan convinces Klink that it was Tillman who did it; Tillman is a fire bug and needs to go. Klink refers to STALAG 18, and says that the Kommandant of STALAG 18 is Himmler's barber's brother-in-law.

Back in the barracks, Hogan catches Tillman going through stuff in Hogan's office. Hogan is slightly angry and wants to know what is going on. He was apparently looking for listening devices. Tillman then tells Hogan that he actually General Tillman Walters, Signal Corps. There is a message that will be coming in from the BBC in 3 minutes that should explain everything. Hogan leaves to go below and get the message.

Kinchloe copies a message from the BBC, and decodes it: 'General with you; has vital mission. Give full and complete support.' Walters then tells Hogan of his mission. They will let the Germans build a plant, then bomb it just before it starts operating. He tells Hogan that he has to put a radar homing device in the camp. He takes out his packet of cigarettes (the ones that he would not let Newkirk have), dumps out the cigarettes that have been cut down to butts at the top, and removes the device that was hidden in the bottom. This is a radar homing device. Hogan goes along with the plan. Then he realizes that Tillman is being transferred, so he tells Tillman that he is being transferred to STALAG 18 because he is supposedly an arsonist. Hogan now needs to temporarily stall the transfer.

Outside the barracks, Tillman and Hogan, covered by some other prisoners, make measurements on where to put the device. Newkirk brings in a telescope and 50 foot piece of wire. Tillman takes reading on periscope on Newkirk's back. Carter has a 50 foot line attached to his leg, LeBeau has the reel for the line. He walks off in a certain direction, dragging the line behind him. Hogan tells him which direction to move until he gets the correct bearing. LeBeau has the reel for the line; he starts to reel the line in. He pulls too hard, and pulls on Carter's leg; Carter tries to walk back with the line tugging on his leg. Schultz comes to the group of prisoners to take Tillman to STALAG 18, For some reason, the truck will not start. (Apparently, one of the prisoners did something to the truck.) They will have to use a motorcycle to get Tillman to STALAG 18; Schultz has to go check out a motorcycle. While he is doing that, Tillman makes the final plot on where the transmitter has to go: It has to go on top of a guard tower just outside the front gate, on the extreme left edge. Hogan thinks of a plan to get it there.

Hogan tells LeBeau to get a camera; it does not matter if it has film or not. Hogan then goes to Klink's office and talks to Helga. He flatters her and tells her that she is 'star' material, she need to be a movie star. He says that Hollywood producers want pictures, so he wants to have pictures taken of her. He also asks her to wear a swim suit because Hollywood producers want more than 'bones'. Helga smiles, with big hopes.

She goes out front onto the porch of the office and LeBeau starts taking pictures. She opens up the shawl over her shoulders and reveals a nice swimsuit. This gets the attention of the guard in the guard tower. While this has the guard's attention, Hogan quietly climbs the guard tower and plants the device on a corner; he looks back at Tillman, who motions him to move it a few inches one way, so he does so. He climbs back down quietly. The guard thinks that he hears something, but he sees nothing, and goes back to looking at Helga.

Back in the barracks, Hogan toasts to mission success, just before Tillman has to leave for STALAG 18. While the men are talking, Hogan finds a knot in the line. LeBeau says that the line broke, so he tied a knot in it. This is important because that means that the line is 6 inches short. They need to move the device 6 inches to the left to be in the correct location. Tillman calculates that this could be vital as the distance from the previous transmitter is far enough away so that the desired bombing point will be 2000 yards (over a mile) off. Hogan has to think quick on how to move the device; he can't climb the tower again, so he will have to do it some other way.

Out in the compound, Hogan asks Newkirk if he has his 'pencil sharpener'; Newkirk takes out a large knife. Hogan tells him to flatten a tire on a staff car that is parked just outside the gate. Newkirk throws the knife into the tire, and the tire goes flat. Hogan the yells at Newkirk for doing that. Hogan convinces Klink to have Newkirk change the tire. Hogan and Newkirk go outside the gate with Schultz to change the tire. Schultz tells a guard to let them do it. Instead of putting the tire jack under the car, Hogan puts it under a leg of the guard tower, and starts jacking it up. The guard feels some movement, but Carter, LeBeau, Kinch, and five other prisoners are standing in the compound and tilt one way to make the guard think that he is not seeing things.

Just then, many planes are heard flying overhead. Seconds later, big explosions are heard in the distance. Hogan has successfully moved the device by 6 inches, and the proposed target has been successfully hit.

description: In a plot to get to an airplane with a silent engine, Hogan gets Klink to believe that he is psychic.
tags: ['propeller', 'aide', 'staff car', 'smoke', 'book', 'trash barrel', 'fire', 'bunk', 'listening device', 'wires', 'coffee pot', 'noise', 'extrasensory perception', 'silent airplane', 'smiling', 'sketching a portrait', 'walkie talkie', 'cigar smoking', 'shell game', 'playing dominos']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Klink is on the phone in his office talking to General Burkhalter. They are talking about a top secret project. Burkhalter wants to be sure that no one overhears them, so Klink opens the door to his office, looks out, and sees only Helga sitting at her desk. Hogan and Kinchloe are listening to the conversation in Hogan's office on the coffee pot. Suddenly, there seem to be loose connections and they can not hear what is being said.

Just then, Schultz comes to the barracks for an inspection. Newkirk, Carter, and LeBeau are playing a shell game at the table, with 4 other un-named prisoners watching. After watching two games, Schultz decides to play. He bets, Newkirk shuffles the shells, and Schultz picks the wrong shell.

Klink comes to the barracks, sees the game, and wants to know what is going on. While this is going on, Kinch is trying to fix the wires to the listening device in Klink's office; Hogan comes out of his office to see what is happening. Klink wants the men to be punished for gambling. Klink picks up one of the shells and says that this is gambling; Hogan says that this is not gambling. Hogan says that they were conducting experiments in ESP, extra-sensory perception. A German named von Tillerman wrote a book on it; Klink did not recognize the name or have the book. Hogan says that all of the great German leaders had ESP: Bismarck, Frederick the Great, and stumbled on a third name. Klink said Hitler? Hogan replied, yes, that was it. Hogan asks Klink to do a shell game. Newkirk shuffles the shells, and Klink picks right the first time. He then picks right the second time. Hogan then asks Klink to guess what number he has written on a pad of paper. Hogan picks up a pad of paper, and when Klink was not looking, gave it to Kinch. Klink puts his fingers to his forehead, concentrating; he guesses 8, no 9. Hogan shows the paper (that Kinch wrote after Klink spoke) that has an 8 crossed off and a 9 written.

Later, in Klink's office, Klink tells Hogan that all men are confined to barracks. This has nothing to do with the gambling. There are security concerns, top secret. Hogan goes into the outer office and talks to Helga. He tries to get information from her on the top secret project; she does not know anything. He sees a book from a von Tillerman on ESP sitting on her desk, one that Klink ordered.

Back in the barracks, Kinch says that the wires to the bug are burned out and need to be replaced. He can't fix it unless he runs another line. They can't do that at this time, so Hogan has another idea. He wants to plant a walkie-talkie where they can hear the conversation in Klink's office.

General Burkhalter comes to Klink's office. Klink offers cigars and brandy. Burkhalter says that this is official business, not a social visit. So Klink offers him some official cigars and official brandy. Burkhalter accepts.

Back in the barracks, Newkirk is finishing painting Klink's name on a satchel. Hogan puts the walkie-talkie in the satchel, and puts it underneath the mattress of an upper bunk. Schultz comes in and announces a barracks inspection. Newkirk is drawing a picture of Carter, with his hair parted on the wrong side. Schultz looks in several bunks and finds nothing. He looks under the mattress in one bunk, and finds a briefcase with Klink's name on it. Schultz wants to report this, the prisoners having stolen the briefcase. Hogan starts telling Schultz a sob story; LeBeau gets behind Schultz and starts playing a sad song on the harmonica. Hogan tells about his poor upbringing, and needing money for a relative's surgery. Schultz starts crying, and says that he is not going to report this. Schultz asked where they finally got the money from; Hogan says 'the bank'.

In Klink's office, Klink is talking with Burkhalter. Schultz opens the door with the briefcase and interrupts. Klink tells him to leave and he puts the briefcase down, and leaves without saying much. The conversation continues. This is a top secret project; a new airplane is arriving that will change the course of the war and may even win the war. Then Klink gets a phone call - there is a plane circling. They don't hear anything, as this is a 'silent plane'. Hogan and the men are listening in on the walkie-talkie. Hogan and the men look out the barracks door; they see a plane flying nearby. What is so special about it? It's what you don't hear; there is no noise coming from the plane. Hogan pauses, then comes up with a plan; they can wait until dark.

That night, Hogan and the men come up the outside tunnel, which happens to be near where the plane is parked outside the gate. They sneak around a bit, and then take the engine out of the plane. They take it down into the tunnel, take pictures and measurements of it, and take it apart. When looking at it, Hogan sees that the 'secret' is that gas is vaporized in a series of baffle chambers, like putting cotton in your ears.

The pilot of the plane and inventor of the engine, Herr Kinzler, is talking in Klink's office with Klink and Burkhalter. Burkhalter asks about security. Klink and Burkhalter go outside and walk towards the plane. Klink says that he has given the guards orders to shoot anyone who goes near the plane. Anyone? Yes, anyone. Burkhalter stops, and then runs back behind a small guard shack. Burkhalter asks Klink to rescind that order before they get any closer.

Down in the tunnel, the motor is being put back together. One pipe does not fit right; Hogan hits it with a hammer, and the pipe goes into a hole. Hogan says that force is the only things that Germans understand.

At the plane, Burkhalter and Klink are discussing security. Klink says that nothing will happen. Then he looks into an opening in the side of the plane, and does not see an engine. He tries to cover for this with Burkhalter.

Klink goes to Hogan, and talks with him about the missing engine. Hogan tells Klink to use his ESP to try to find the engine. Klink puts his fingers to his forehead and concentrates. He sees Burkhalter testing him.

Klink and Hogan go outside to where the plane is. Klink uses his ESP again to find the engine. It is black, no white. He pulls a bush back saying it is right here. There is nothing under the bush. Hogan then looks in the opening in the side of the plane, and says that it would be crowded with two engines in there. Klink looks, and sees the engine back in its place. He is puzzled as to what is going on.

The next day, just inside the compound, Burkhalter is talking with 3 other generals and an aide in a staff car. The other generals are here to see the demonstration of the silent engine. The engine starts, and makes a lot of grumbling noises, pops, and bangs. This is not the silent engine that was to be demonstrated. One of the generals gives a sign to the aide to drive off, and the staff car leaves, without any of them saying anything. Hogan says, in a British accent 'By jove, I don't think he's got it'.

At the end, at roll call, Klink is talking to the prisoners 'so you call yourselves soldiers'. Newkirk says no, we are prisoners. Klink says that the confinement to barracks is over. Klink shows Hogan von Tillerman's book on ESP. Hogan says that the book must be scarce, maybe the only one left. The Nazis are burning von Tillerman's books in Berlin. Klink turns around, tosses the book into a burning trash barrel, and walks off.

description: An African prince comes to Stalag 13 who is negotiating with the Germans for the rights in his country to build a submarine base and Hogan replaces him with Kinchloe.
tags: ['submarine', 'fake mustache', 'look alike', 'dual role', 'trunk of money', 'staff car', 'back seat', 'fez', 'money', 'telephone call', 'aircraft shot down', 'messerschmitt bf 110 fighter bomber', 'wife', 'royalty', 'reference to detroit', 'reference to cleveland ohio', 'reference to toledo ohio', 'counterfeit money', 'german money', 'tunnel entrance', 'wine', 'impersonating an enemy soldier', 'passionate kiss', 'negotiation', 'facial scar', 'champagne', "shaving off one's mustache", 'airplane shot down', 'archive footage', 'betting', 'parachute', 'body double']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Hogan and the men are in the barracks, with about 15 other men waiting to escape. These men are putting on civilian clothes and getting pictures. There is one delay: money. The old money, which the team has been counterfeiting, has been called in, and new money has been issued. They need the new money before the men can be sent off. Carter is watching the door; he sees Schultz and announces that Schultz is coming. Hogan has the escaping men go down into the tunnel, fast. Carter steps outside the barracks to try to stall Schultz while the men go down. He can't quite stall long enough; Schultz forces his way in just in time to see the last go down the tunnel, and the entrance close. He is astounded by what is going on, and sees nothing. Hogan wants to change new money for old. Schultz asks how much. Hogan tells LeBeau to show him the money. LeBeau opens up a suitcase that is completely full of old money in baled bills. Just then, they hear planes passing nearby. Allied fighters shoot down a German plane. Schultz lost a bet with Newkirk, so he starts to give him money; Newkirk notices that these are all old bills.

Later, in Klink's office, Klink is talking to an African Prince, Prince Makabana. It was his plane that was shot down and he had to bail out. The Prince states that this was an undignified way of coming to Germany. Klink offers his staff car to continue his trip to Berlin. The prince does not like that. A train perhaps? The prince dismisses the idea. Then Hogan comes in, and protests things that are being done. Klink introduces Hogan to Prince Makabana. The Prince says that the Allies will do anything to get the prince to abort his mission. Hogan is trying to get information out of the Prince. He first says that the Germans want to have an air base in his country. No. Air base, I meant submarine base. The Prince gets mad at Klink for betraying the mission; Klink knows nothing about the mission. Hogan leaves. Hogan seems to recognize that the prince looks similar to Kinchloe.

In the barracks, the men are dressing Kinch up as the prince. Kinch says that he was from Detroit and worked with the phone company; he knows nothing about being a prince. Hogan says that Kinch can pose as the prince, but he has to get rid of the mustache. Kinch objects; Newkirk and Carter try to hold him down while LeBeau tries to shave it off.

Outside of Klink's office, Klink takes the prince to his staff car. Newkirk and Carter are dressed up as German soldiers, in the front seat of the car. Kinch is hidden in the back seat. The prince gets in the back; he sees Kinch dressed as him and is surprised at what is going on. Klink tells the driver to drive on. But the car doesn't move. Kinch, as the prince, gets out and says that he changed his mind. Instead of Prince Makabana going to Berlin, let Berlin come to Prince Makabana. He tells Klink to tell them to bring negotiating papers, in other-words, money. Hogan comes up; Prince/Kinch says that he recognizes Hogan, that they went to school together. Hogan 'recognizes' him, and says that back then he had a mustache; Prince/Kinch says 'Don't remind me'. Prince/Kinch says that Hogan will stay with him. He says that Klink is to move his things out of his quarters and move Hogan's in. Prince/Kinch and Hogan walk into the building talking like old friends, such as what they did at the Notre Dame game.

In Klink's quarters, Hogan, LeBeau, and Kinch are talking. Kinch and LeBeau argue about wine, LeBeau pours some for the 'prince'. Klink comes in, and sees that his best wine is being used. He says that he talked to Berlin, and Count von Sickle will be coming tomorrow. And he has a surprise: the Prince's wife will be coming along with von Sickle. Klink leaves. Kinch is worried. He asks Hogan what to do now. Hogan says 'You're the Prince'.

The next day, in Klink's quarters, Klink, Hogan, and von Sickle are there with Kinch/Prince. The Princess comes in and gets close to Kinch/Prince. She recognized that this is not her husband, and takes his hand to lead him into the next room. When the door is closed, she asks him who he is. Kinch says that he is trying to make a deal with the Allies. He asks her what side she is on. She replies 'My own'. Kinch tells her to go ahead and blow the whistle. She may or may not do so.

Meanwhile in Klink's office, von Sickle says that they are wasting time. Kinch/Prince, Klink, Hogan, and Princess Yawanda are also in the room. The submarines are waiting to get into port, and aircraft are waiting to take off with supplies. Hogan asks about job security if Germany loses; von Sickle says that Germany will not lose. Von Sickle offers 400,000 Marks; Hogan asks for 600,000. Von Sickle says 500,000 as that is all he brought with him. All new money. The deal is made. Von Sickle asks the Prince to make the phone call. Hogan asks if he knows the Prince's native language' and suggests the Princess make the call instead. She picks up the phone and makes the call.

Later, back in the barracks, the men are in civilian clothes waiting for the money so they can escape. Hogan says that when they get the message that the submarines were clobbered, to call the main gate to open it up. The real Prince protests what is going on, and demands to be released; LeBeau pushes him back down the tunnel.

Schultz is walking guard outside Klink's quarters where the Prince and Princess are staying. The Prince/Kinch and Princess come out. Schultz says that he has orders that the Prince and Princess do not leave without orders from Klink. Kinch/Prince gets mad at Schultz. The staff car comes up, again with Newkirk and Carter in German uniforms in the front seat. Kinch/Prince and Princess Yawanda get in the back seat. They talk while Kinch takes his outfit off. She says that she originally was from Cleveland; Kinch says that he is from Detroit. He will meet her halfway, in Toledo, after the war. Kinch presses his mustache back on.

In Klink's office, Klink and von Sickle are waiting for a phone call. The phone rings, Helga answers, and gives it to von Sickle. Von Sickle is waiting for the message that the subs are in port. Instead, the message is that the subs were met by destroyers and sunk, and the planes were shot down. Von Sickle is to be shot.

At the car, Kinch and the Princess are kissing in the back seat; Hogan interrupts. Kinch leaves through the opposite side door and sneaks around. He tells Schultz that he saw the Prince walking 'over there', and points in one direction. Schultz looks in the car and sees just the Princess. The car leaves, with Carter (in the German uniform) driving. Klink comes out saying 'Stop that car'. The car is out the gate before it can be stopped. Hogan asks Kinch about Toldeo. Kinch says that after the war, it could be quite a spot.

At the end, in the barracks, von Sickle is also dressed up like the others trying to escape, in civilian clothes. He says that this is not enough money to get to Switzerland. The real Prince is also there, and says that his subjects will take revenge. Hogan says he doesn't think so, the way he double-crossed the Germans.

Outside, Klink asks Hogan what she saw in him. Hogan says that she just has a particular taste in men.

description: Klink helps an old friend by assisting Hogan in the theft of the plans for an assassination on the Fuehrer.
tags: ['nitro', 'nitroglycerin', 'parachute drop', 'parachute jump', 'night parachute drop', 'drill', 'satchel', 'party', 'dust', "doctor's bag", 'burning a document', 'singing harmony', 'champagne', 'floor plan', 'parachute', 'c 119 flying boxcar', 'arrest', 'key', 'reference to irving berlin', 'safecracking', 'safecracker', 'safe deposit box key', 'hotel safe']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Hogan comes to Klink's office and requests favors on behalf of the men. While they are discussing this, Major Kronman appears, and asks Schultz where to find Klink. He asks Schultz to hide the car out of site, and Schultz suggests behind the barracks. Kronman says that he is on a special mission, and Schultz says that he says nothing.

In Klink's office, Schultz tells Klink that a Major Kronman has arrived, and Klink has trouble remembering him. Then Major Hans Kronman, an old classmate of Klink, enters Klink's office. They took military training together in Potsdam, and were in the same class. Kronman is amazed that Klink made colonel, and Klink is amazed that Kronman is still a major, two ranks below Klink. While they are having small talk with Hogan listening in, Gestapo Captain Gunther and two Gestapo guards come into Klink's office and arrest Kronman, Gunther says that Kronman is part of the conspiracy to assassinate Hitler. As he is being taken away, Kronman gives Hogan a key to a safe deposit box. Klink feigns that he does not know Kronman.

Back in the barracks, Hogan tells the men what has happened. He shows them the key, marked 'Hammelburg Hof number 9'. When asked why Kronman did not give Klink the key, Hogan says that at this point, one person a German does not trust is another German. They guess that this is to a safety deposit box in a hotel by that name. While they are discussing this, Kinch comes up from the tunnel with a message from London stating that Kronman's identity was confirmed, and Hogan is to give him what help he needs. Hogan suggests that they raid the hotel box, and make it look like a burglary. Newkirk says that the safe deposit boxes at hotels are usually in a safe, and he suggests blowing the safe, but nitro makes a mess; they need a safe-cracker. Hogan asks Kinch if there are any safe-crackers among the prisoners. Kinch says that there are mechanics, pool hustlers, and used car salesmen, but no safe-crackers (they do not say that Newkirk is a safe-cracker). Newkirk suggests someone named Alfie the Artiste, a famous safe-cracker from England, be called in to do the job. Hogan has Kinch call London about Alfie. They get a message back saying that they found him, in prison, which does not surprise Newkirk.

Hogan sees Klink in the compound, and asks for favors again, and again Klink denies them. Hogan then shows Klink the key to the box. They go to Klink's office to discuss matters. Hogan gives Klink the key without him realizing it. They talk about Kronman and what Kronman wanted to talk to Klink about, referring to the conspiracy that the Gestapo arrested Kronman for. Hogan convinces Klink that the Gestapo may think that he may be involved. Klink asks Hogan for help with the problem. Hogan offers help, but Klink thinks that this is a pretense to escape. Hogan gives him his word that there will be no escape. Hogan butters Klink up when Klink asks why he wants to help; he calls Klink the 'Iron Colonel'. He says that if we get a new Kommandant, the men may try to escape, and may get hurt, and he does not want that. Hogan somehow gets the key back, and tells Klink that he may have to ignore some happenings around there. Klink lights a cigarette for Hogan, and they discuss it some more. Hogan ends up pouring a glass of schnapps from Klink's decanter and drinks it.

Later, a man jumps out of a C-119 which is partially painted in international orange. Alfred Burke, also known as Alfie the Artiste, is brought in to the barracks through the tunnel; he asks for some tea. He is then introduced to Hogan, and asks about the mission. Hogan tells Alfie about the key, and the possible safe that the box is in. Alfie starts thinking: Hammelburg, the nearest large city is Dusseldorf; a major safe manufacturer in Dusseldorf is the Sscleswig-Offenbach Safe Company. He sites some specifications of their safe from memory. Newkirk tells the others how good he is. Hogan asks if he needs anything, and Alfie says that like a surgeon, he brought what he needed. He also asks for some tea. Then, Schultz comes in and says that the guards said that they say Newkirk outside the wire. Newkirk says that he was there the whole time. After discussing this, Schultz sees Alfie, and asks his name. He gives it as Burke, Alfred, Private First Class. Schultz says that he is not on the roster, and needs to report this to Klink. Just then, Klink comes to the barracks, and wants to know why Schultz has left his post. Schultz says that he was doing an inspection and has made a discovery. Hogan dangles the key; Klink says that he wants to know nothing, and leaves. Schultz is disappointed that Klink did not want to hear him, and he leaves. Hogan then starts telling the men the plan, where Klink will give a party at the hotel, which will be used as a diversion.

At the party, Klink and Hogan discuss what will happen. Hogan tells Klink to yell 'air raid' at the right time; Klink tries it now, and Hogan has to quiet him down. The Burgermeister comes by and thanks Klink for the party. There are at least 4 other officers, 4 women, and 6 other men at the party. Meanwhile, Kinch and Alfie are outside waiting Hogan to open a window. After he does, Alfie goes in and starts to work on the safe. Carter is a waiter, bringing drinks. Klink takes two. Hogan tells Klink to lay off the juice just in case anything goes wrong. Klink asks what could go wrong. Just then, Captain Gunther and the two Gestapo guards come in. Gunther tells Klink that Kronman was shot. He asks what Hogan is doing there, and Klink responds that this is a reward for providing vital information. Gunther then starts looking around. As he pulls back the curtain to the back room (where Alfie is working), LeBeau, Newkirk, and Carter (all dressed as waiters) start singing a song by Irving Berlin 'This is the Army, Mister Jones'. Not very good singing, but it serves as a distraction. Gunther looks around in the room and sees nothing out of the ordinary; Alfie is hiding on a shelf over the safe where Gunther does not look. As Gunther leaves, Carter suggests another number, and is pulled back behind the curtain. Alfie comes down off the shelf, goes back to work, lights the explosive, and blows the safe. Klink tries to scream 'air raid', but the words barely come out. Newkirk opens the box, gets an envelope, and tosses it to Hogan. When Klink wants to know why he did not get the envelope, Hogan mentions Tinkers to Evers to Chance; Klink is Evers, Hogan is Chance.

At the end, Hogan comes to Klink's office. Klink says that the Gestapo is convinced of his innocence in the conspiracy, and that the bombing was an attempt on his life. Hogan 'sells' the list to Klink, where Klink agrees to have packages delivered on time and extra showers for the men, among other things. Klink then opens the envelope and sees his name at the top of the list, with General Burkhalter, Admiral Metzger, and others on the list. Klink then revokes the extra privileges that he just granted. Hogan suggests that he may have made a copy. Klink is worried that Hogan may try to blackmail him and restores the revoked extra privileges, and tells Hogan to make sure that the men don't use too much water for their showers.

description: Three American women show up at Stalag 13 and Hogan wants to know why.
tags: ['truck', 'rocket', 'curtain', 'high heel shoes', 'tunnel', 'purse', 'reference to the rockettes', "women's underwear", 'nylon stockings', 'scarf', 'feigning illness', 'bottle of wine', 'flowers', 'kiss', 'tunnel entrance', 'tunnel collapse', 'map', 'man dresses as a woman', 'woman dresses as a man', 'switching clothes', 'reference to irving berlin', 'man disguised as a woman']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Schultz brings prisoners into Hogan's barracks. He announces that by order of Kommandant Klink all men from Barracks 3 are to be moved to Barracks 5, which is the barracks where Hogan and the men live. Schultz says that Klink wants room for 3 more prisoners, three Americans on the way to maximum security in Berlin. Gestapo wants to keep them separate.

Hogan goes to Klink's office, and says that he wants to register a complaint of overcrowding. Schultz comes in and says that Captain Heinrich of the Gestapo has arrived with 3 Americans. He also says that the 3 prisoners are women. Klink tells Schultz to show them to Barracks 3. While Klink is talking to Schultz, Hogan takes food off of Klink's plate. Klink does not know how it disappeared.

Back in the barracks, Hogan pulls down a map of the camp compound from the side of a bunk. Hogan tells the men to dig out the tunnel to Barracks 3. Hogan asks for volunteers, and no one volunteers. Hogan then says that he needs another way to see the girls. He says that the new prisoners are women. All of a sudden, all of them volunteer to dig. Hogan asks how long to dig the tunnel, and Newkirk says about an hour and a half. Hogan says that to prevent put-communication, he will talk to the girls.

Apparently, the tunnel is dug quickly. Hogan goes to Barracks 3 through the tunnel, and opens up the hatch in the floor. He almost gets hit on the head by one of the girls by a high-heel shoe as he comes out. They introduce themselves as Charlene Helmsley, Cathy Pruitt, and Ginger Wilson. Hogan asks why the Germans are interested in them. They don't know. They said that they were doing their performance routine for some American infantry when they were attacked; they jumped in a jeep, left, and were surrounded by Germans. They were taken to a shelter where they saw some long thin shells with wings, like torpedoes. Hogan asks how long it took them to get here from there, and they said about 4 hours, on a bumpy road and passing a cathedral. Hogan thinks that they might be rockets. Just then, Newkirk and LeBeau come out of the tunnel, and Hogan tells them to get back in, and they have a short discussion. Schultz then comes into the barracks to do a head count, and brings a bottle of wine. Hogan, Newkirk, LeBeau, and one of the women are hiding behind a curtain. Hogan tosses women's underwear and nylon stockings over the curtain to try to convince Schultz not to look behind the curtain. One of the stockings falls to the floor and Schultz picks it up. While down there, he counts 4 pairs of feet under the curtains. He open up the curtains and sees Hogan, Newkirk, LeBeau, and the girl; he tells the men to get back to the barracks. Then, Klink knocks on the door; Hogan; Schultz, Newkirk, and LeBeau hide behind the curtains. Klink wants to know if the women are doing well; they seem to have a distrust of him, and move away from him. The curtain falls, and Klink sees the others who have been hiding, and wants to know what they are doing there and takes the wine from Schultz. Just then, Capt. Heinrich comes in, and sees Klink holding the wine bottle. He gets angry, and says that he will take the women out tomorrow. He will have an one-flattering report on Klink.

Back in the barracks, Hogan is discussing how to get them out. Kinch gets a radio message stating that they will bomb the rockets tomorrow. Just then, there is an explosion and a tunnel cave in. Newkirk says that the tunnel to Barracks 3 has collapsed, not enough supports holding it up. When thinking about how to get them out. Hogan says that if all else fails, there is always Colonel Klink.

In Klink's office, Klink gives Schultz a list of punishments for the prisoners Newkirk and LeBeau. Hogan says that he should check with Heinrich. Klink says that he is running the place, not Heinrich. After some discussion, Hogan convinces Klink to ship them out tonight, not tomorrow.

That evening, Newkirk walks past Barracks 3 trailing a fuse out of his pants leg, gets stares from the Gestapo guard, and walks to Barracks 5. Carter lights the fuse and lets it run. The guards sees the lit fuse, and sounds an alarm, calls to get a fire hose and extinguisher. Hogan, Newkirk, Carter, and LeBeau go to Barracks 3, and says that they will change places with the girls. He pulls out some wigs, and says that Private Ninowski, the wig-maker, does beautiful work. LeBeau and Newkirk do not want to dress up as women. After some discussion, Hogan, Newkirk, and LeBeau dress as the women in their clothes. The women then put on prisoners' uniforms. Hogan tells Newkirk that he looks good in basic black.

A truck comes to Barracks 3. Newkirk, LeBeau, and finally Hogan get into the back of the truck, assisted by Schultz who recognizes them. Hogan calls Schultz 'Fresh'. Schulotz is dumbfounded and surprised. The truck leaves. On the road, Hogan fakes an illness, Newkirk tells the driver to stop the truck. The truck stops, and the driver gets out and asks what is going on. Hogan hits the driver in the head with a purse, and the other guard is also knocked out. They escape, and make their way back to camp.

Theu come up through the tunnel, to the men and the girls dressed as men, saying that they can go. Kathy, one of the girls, says 'How can we thank you?' and kisses Hogan. Hogan says to leave their names and addresses for after the war.

At the end, Hogan comes to Klink's office and asks for extra rations; it is a holiday, Armistice day, the day when the Americans beat the Germans in World War I. Oops, bad taste. Hogan asks about Heinrich. Klink says that he met with disgrace; he was overpowered by a handbag and the 3 women prisoners escaped. He says that an experimental station with rockets was bombed.

description: As Hogan tries to help a German scientist defect, bumbling Colonel Crittendon interferes again.
tags: ['assassin', 'crossbow', 'reference to robin hood', 'arrow', 'firecracker', 'diversion', 'dinner', 'explosion']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, a staff car comes into STALAG 13, carrying General Burkhalter and a visiting scientist, Dr. Vanetti. Burkhalter tells Klink that 'no one must have any idea' that Vanetti is there. Dr. Vanetti just wants quiet. Burkhalter says that it is quiet here, like a church. He tells Klink that Vanetti is to get quiet. Vanetti has brought along almost everything that he needs; he just needs paper, pencils, and quiet. He knew Fermi, Hatermann, and Szilard. Burkhalter says that Vanetti will be completely safe here.

Back in the barracks, Hogan and the men are listening in to the conversation on the coffee pot. Hogan says that we need to kill him. Vanetti is an atomic scientist. The other three names that were mentioned were also atomic scientists.

Schultz comes in saying that it is garbage day. He tells the men that an assassin, Garreau, was dropped, captured, and taken to STALAG 16. Hogan tells Carter and LeBeau that they are going out tonight. Schultz hears nothing.

That night, Carter and LeBeau bring back the assassin and Crittenden, who was also at STALAG 16. As they near the camp, Crittenden goes the wrong way and is seen by camp guards. The guards start shooting; LeBeau and Carter get back while this is going on. They come in through the outside tunnel, which has a hatch lid and is not a tree stump.

Later in the tunnel, Crittenden offers to do the assassination job. He wants Carter and explosives to help. This is not a good idea. Crittenden then wants to use a crossbow. Hogan reluctantly goes along with it. Hogan will be having dinner with Klink and Vanetti tonight; Crittenden will have one shot. Crittenden asks how he will know Vanetti. Hogan tells him that he knows Klink, he knows Hogan; Vanetti will be the one that he does not know.

Hogan goes to Klink's quarters; Vanetti is having dinner. Klink tries to get rid of Hogan. Carter starts a diversion of firecrackers outside. Klink sounds the alarm and leaves. After Klink leaves, Vanetti wants to talk to Hogan alone. He wants to get to England. He says that all information is in his head, and he can not trust atomic secrets to Hitler. Vanetti got wind of Hogan's operation through the Underground. Vanetti is standing in front of the window; Crittenden is taking aim with the crossbow from the barracks. Hogan tackles Vanetti just as Klink comes back in. A crossbow arrow goes through the open window, through Klink's cap, left of the eagle decoration, and lodges in the office door. Klink is very surprised. Hogan asks Klink if he has angered Robin Hood.

Klink calls Schultz. Klink has the hat in his hand, with the arrow still in the door. Klink asks Hogan how they knew Vanetti was here. Hogan says that they didn't, but everybody knows that Klink is here. He suggests to Klink that it may be the Gestapo. Klink starts to get worried.

Back in the barracks. Hogan tells Crittenden that Vanetti is on our side. Just then, there is an explosion in the tunnel. Carter comes up in a dirty uniform. There is some discussion as to who is in charge and what to do with Crittenden's ideas. Hogan asks what Crittenden would do if he gives Crittenden a direct order; Crittenden says that he would ignore it - he outranks Hogan by date of rank. Crittenden still wants to eliminate Vanetti. Hogan has to do some thinking.

Hogan goes to Klink's office. There are more explosions. Klink says that he discounts the Gestapo theory. Klink wants to know about the explosions; Hogan says that he discounted it.

Back in the barracks, Hogan dresses up Crittenden as a German; he tells him that he will take Vanetti on a ride, and 'let him have it'. Essentially, Hogan is making Crittenden think that he will be going for a ride with Vanetti, and he can eliminate him on the road. Hogan goes out to check the staff car to see if Vanetti is in it, knowing that it will be Klink in the car. Hogan sees Klink in the car, and tells him that Vanetti is in the compound. Hogan puts Crittenden in the staff car with Klink, making Crittenden and Klink think that the other is Vanetti.

Schultz suddenly screams that Vanetti is gone. Hogan starts to tell him why, but Schultz says that he knows nothing.

On the road, the staff car pulls over. Klink thinks that Crittenden is Vanetti, Crittenden thinks that Klink is Vanetti. They are both surprised when neither is the case. Crittenden gets out of the car and runs. Klink tells the guards to go after him, and they start shooting.

Back in the barracks, Hogan tells Vanetti that the guards had blanks. Vanetti starts to leave through the tunnel in the barracks under the bunk. Carter asks Vanetti if our side will ever come up with an atomic bomb. Vanetti says that he hopes not, because it would be too noisy. Vanetti then goes down the tunnel. Hogan says that Crittenden does not have the knack for escaping, that he probably did not get away.

At the end, Hogan, Klink, Burkhalter, and Schultz are looking down into the hole where Vanetti's laboratory used to be. Burkhalter wants to know why Vanetti can be so brainy and yet so dummkoff enough to blow himself up. Hogan wants to talk with Klink and Burkhalter about it.

description: Hogan wants Klink to forget about a promotion so he plays cupid for him and General Burkhalter's sister.
tags: ['recliner', 'record player', 'lamp', 'worcestershire sauce', 'dinner', 'missing in action', 'niece', 'matchmaking', 'rifle', 'teddy bear', 'insomnia', 'periscope', 'marriage', 'champaign', 'invitation to dinner', 'widow']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, Schultz goes into the barracks to turn out the lights. He says that lights go out in 25 seconds. Newkir says 'You woke us up for that?' Newkirk takes Schultz's rifle while he is not looking. Newkirk gives it to LeBeau, and Schultz finds LeBeau hugging it in his bunk. LeBeau says he does not have a teddy bear. Carter is in his bunk, and asks Schultz for a drink of water. Schultz leaves. Then the men go down into the tunnel.

Capt. Ferguson is a shot-down pilot waiting to go to England. He is in the tunnel, in a recliner reading a book and listening to a record player. He needs to go on a mission. The land periscope is near the ladder to the outside exit, the top of the periscope as seen from the outside is covered in plants. Kinch and Hogan look through the periscope, and see Klink patrolling the wire, keeping guards awake so Capt. Ferguson can't escape. Then Hogan sees Klink heading to the barracks, so he hurries the men back to the barracks; they should be asleep in their bunks.

Klink goes to the barracks, turns the lights on. Klink wants to talk to Hogan alone; Hogan invites Klink to Hogan's office. Klink tells Hogan that he (Klink) is a failure, and he can't sleep. Klink has been a colonel longer than anyone in his graduating class; others are generals and field marshals. They talk a bit. General Burkhalter will be coming tomorrow to talk about the future.

General Burkhalter comes to visit STALAG 13, and tells Klink that he disapproves of him, and wants Klink to get a wife. General Burkhalter refers to a Captan Haldman who just made General; he says that Haldman was the idiot of his graduating class. Burkhalter tells Klink to see what marrying into the right family will do. Burkhalter's sister and niece will be visiting. Hogan tells Klink to get some sleep.

Burkhalter, his sister Frau Linkmeyer, and her daughter Lottie come to STALAG 13. Klink says that quarters are prepared, and wants to show them around the camp. Burkhalter says that they just got there, and need to freshen up. Frau Linkmeyer is a homely brunette, and Lottie is a beautiful blonde. Burkhalter asks them what they think of Klink, and Lottie says he looks like a dead fish. After Lottie responds, Burkhalter says that he was asking her mother. Frau Linkmeyer says that she is not a widow; her husband, Otto, is 'missing in action at the Russian front'. Burkhalter says 'Missing in action at the Russian front' means 'widow'.

In Klink's office, Klink tells Hogan that General Burkhalter wants Klink to marry his niece, not knowing that General Burkhalter really wants Klink to marry his sister. Klink asks advice from Hogan on what to do, how to romance Lottie. Hogan tells him that the most important thing is to whisper lies in her ear. Klink won't do it; he has a code of honor.

Frau Linkmeyer comes to Klink's office and wants to talk to Klink alone, but Klink wants Hogan to stay. Burkhalter and Lottie are going around the camp. Frau Linkmeyer asks Klink some questions related to marriage. She asks Klink 'Do you drink or gamble?' Klink answers 'Never'. Who should handle the finances, the husband or the wife? After Klink stumbles, Hogan answers the questions for Klink, and Klink agrees with the answers. Schultz comes in and says that Burkhalter and Lottie are here. Frau Linkmeyer says that they will talk more later, and tells Klink that Lottie does not like Klink. There can not be a marriage without her approval. She leaves the office.

Klink still thinks that it is Lottie he is being fixed up with. Klink wants Lottie to fall in live with Klink, not an 'image'. Hogan gives Klink things to say, still thinking that Lottie is the one that Klink is being set up with. Klink is alone with Gertrude (Frau Linkmeyer), but never alone with Lottie without Gertrude. Klink asks Hogan what to do. Hogan dictates words to Klink. Give her an invitation to dinner.

Hogan delivers a letter from Klink to Lottie. Klink has invited Lottie for dinner, but Lottie thinks that he has invited 'Mama'. Hogan tries to build up Klink by telling Lottie that Klink is a Baron, and talks about his decorations. Lottie is impressed. Hogan tells her not to tell her mother. Lottie then tells Hogan that it is her mother that is going to marry Klink, and that Lottie now approves. Hogan wants the note back.

In Klink's quarters, Hogan is there talking with LeBeau (as the cook) about the dinner set-up. Hogan tells LeBeau that he feels sorry for Klink. Gertrude arrives for dinner, calling him 'Wilhelm'. She tells him to call her 'Gertrude'. She is thinking that Klink wants to marry her. She tells Klink that she was mad about General Burkhalter's matchmaking, but now she got to know him better. She wants to set up 'our own little love nest'. LeBeau gets champagne. Klink asks Schultz to set another place (for Hogan).

At the end, Gertrude asks Klink about a spring wedding. Hogan suggests the wedding be 'tomorrow'. as Klink has volunteered for service at the Russian front. Gertrude gets mad and tells Klink that the engagement is off, and storms out of the room. Klink tells Hogan that he has done him a favor, and what can he do in return. Hogan says 'Just get a good night's sleep'.

description: There seems to be a traitor in the escaped prisoner pipeline and Hogan has to find him by following the escape route.
tags: ['smoke bomb', 'forest', 'recognition code', 'telephone call', 'barmaid', 'farmhouse', '.45 calibre pistol', 'bar', 'truck', 'leather belt', 'fire fighting', 'closet']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, a truck comes in carrying Captain Warren. Warren escaped from STALAG 5, came to STALAG 13 to get to England; Hogan and the men sent him through the normal escape route, and he was caught and brought back to STALAG 13. Klink sentences Warren to 30 days in the cooler, solitary confinement. Hogan tells Schultz that he sounds like Klink; Schultz that insults will get you nowhere. Newkirk offers Schultz a cigarette to distract attention, while he takes a key from Schultz's belt. As Warren is being led away, he tells Hogan that he was knocked out and captured. Hogan says that something is rotten in Denmark.

Back in the barracks, Hogan is talking to the men. He says that he briefly talked to Warren about the escape. Warren made it to the first station, the bar Hauserhof. Then he made it to the second station, a farmhouse. When he got to the third station, he got caught. Hogan says that something is wrong, that there may be a traitor someplace in the pipeline, someone is selling us out. Hogan wants some of the men to travel the route themselves; Hogan says that LeBeau and Newkirk will go with him as bait. Newkirk wants to stay behind, but after some discussion Newkirk and LeBeau 'volunteer'. Hogan has an idea where the men can 'disappear' for some time without much suspicion.

Hogan tells Kinchloe and Carter to make smoke bombs and start a fire in the nearby forest, high up where it can be seen from camp. The next day, after the fire is started in the woods, Hogan goes to Klink's office, and shows Klink the 'forest fire'. Klink panics and calls the officer of the day; Klink wants to send guards to fight the fire. Hogan gets him to hang up and talks him out of sending the guards. After some discussion, Hogan convinces Klink to have some of the prisoners fight the fire. Klink agrees, and he will have Schultz guard them.

Hogan, Carter, Newkirk, LeBeau, Kinch, and Schultz go to the fire site in a truck. Schultz starts thinking that something is fishy. Hogan wants to establish a fire line; Kinch throws more smoke bombs. The smoke and excuse of fighting the fire gives Hogan, Newkirk, and LeBeau the chance to get away for a short time. They go to the first station, the bar, and find 2 girls there, Eva and Margit; one pulls a gun as she is not sure who they are. Hogan says that they are going to Dusseldorf, and Eva responds that they are on the wrong road. Hogan says that this was the correct recognition code. Hogan tells Newkirk to watch the door; Newkirk would rather watch a girl. Hogan asks Eva if she remembers Captain Warren from a short time ago. She says that she does; he tells her that he got captured, and wants to know what happened. Just then, Eva gets a phone call; she asks them to call back. Seems suspicious. Hogan noticed that they used her first name. She tells Hogan that the call was 'Winter Relief', asking for donations, that they call every week. Hogan and Eva talk for a while, and Hogan kisses Eva. She tells Hogan to go to a farmhouse, the second station; no recognition code. LeBeau comes out of the back room, having spent some time with Margit. Newkirk says that he fell in love with a door; Hogan says 'If you have seen one door, you have seen them all'. LeBeau kisses Margit; and Hogan, Newkirk, and LeBeau leave.

The three of them come back to the truck, which is still there. Schultz calls Klink on the 'walkie talkie' to report what is going on. While he is talking, Hogan drives off in the truck. Schultz screams for them to come back.

Hogan, Newkirk, and LeBeau go to the farmhouse. They look at it from a distance, and Hogan tells the others that if he is not back in 10 minutes, go back to camp. Hogan enters the farmhouse with his pistol drawn. He sees an old man, Willy, and his wife inside; they are surprised that he barged in. Willy says that they get instructions from the Hauserhof. Hogan asks about Warren; they remember him, says that they helped him to escape. Willy says that they are Swedish, and the Germans seem to be paying no attention to them. Hogan opens a closet, and finds Gestapo uniforms hanging there. Hogan gets hit over the head with a chair by Willy and is knocked out.

Newkirk and LeBeau storm in to the farmhouse with guns drawn, and find Hogan recovering from the knockout. Willy says that he has to be sure that he is not a spy. Willy says that Eva at the Hauserhof tells them where to send them. Willy gets a phone call, says that there are 'change in plans', to take the south road. Hogan tells Newkirk to call Gestapo headquarters and tell them to go to the Hauserhof, that it a waste of time on the South Road. Newkirk makes the call.

Hogan, Newkirk, and LeBeau go back to the Hauserhof. Hogan and the others are drinking with Eva and Margit, and Hogan toasts 'to the defeat of Germany'. Schultz comes in and sees them; he wants to know what they are doing there. Just then, two Gestapo men, one officer and one enlisted, come in. One asks Schultz his name, and he gives 'Schultz, Hans, STALAG 13, 23789 '. Newkirk tells the Gestapo that the girls tried to divert the Gestapo from the south road. Margit says that they are reporting escaping prisoners. The Gestapo thinks that they might be double agents, and put the girls in their car. Hogan convinces the Gestapo that Schultz captured them trying to escape. They buy the story and leave. As they are leaving, Schultz tells the Gestapo that his serial number is 23781. Hogan, Newkirk, LeBeau, and Schultz drink to Sergeant Schultz, Hero. Hogan asks Schultz 'Have you been to a good fire lately?' They all laugh.

At the end, Hogan and Schultz are in Klink's office. Klink reads them a special communication from General Burkhalter. It is from the Gestapo and commends Schultz for the job that he did, and asks whether Schultz shouldn't be transferred to a combat unit. Hogan mentions about Panzer units at the Russian front; the term 'combat unit' usually means the Russian front. The memo gives Klink discretion to the transfer. Klink says that Schultz is needed here and can't be transferred. Hogan and Schultz leave. When they get outside, Schultz thanks Hogan, and says 'If you ever escape, be a good fellow and take me with you.'

description: Carter receives a Dear John letter and wants to join the rest of the prisoners that escape and go home.
tags: ['dear john letter', 'harmonica', 'microfilm', 'mention of draft board', 'cigarette lighter', 'mail call', 'barmaid', 'bartender', 'identity papers', 'season finale']
synopsis_with_character_names:
At the start, a message from London comes in. There is a cigarette lighter stashed in Klink's car, with microfilm that they want to get to the Germans as a ruse. Hogan tells the men to start a car wash. The next day, Newkirk, Carter, Kinchloe, and LeBeau are washing a car, with Hogan watching. LeBeau is inside the car looking; Kinch says he didn't find it, LeBeau didn't find it, Newkirk didn't find it. Hogan tells them to keep looking. Kinch finally finds it taped under the distributor. The men leave with the car half washed; Klink arrives and asks what is going on. Schultz is taken by surprise and, seeing that the prisoners have left, says that he is washing the car.

Later in the tunnel, Hogan is looking at the microfilm. It has pictures of Endhoven and Schweinfurt; these are close together. If the bombers want to bomb Schweinfurt, they act like they are going to Endhoven, and then make a turn a little way out. Hogan wants the microfilm to get to the Germans. Just then, Schultz come in with a mail call. He calls some names, including Abraham, Adams, Barker, Bartoli, Beauchamp. Kinchloe gets a letter from his draft board; it says that his draft classification is 4F. He says 'Now they tell me'. Carter gets a Dear John letter from his girlfriend, Mary Jane; she is going around with an air raid warden at home. Carter is not happy.

Later, Carter comes to Hogan's office, addresses him and acts formally, salutes, and requests to escape. LeBeau, Kinch, and Newkirk are in the office with him. Hogan says that their orders are to assist prisoners to escape and do sabotage. Hogan asks Carter if he has to be so serious.

Outside later, Carter is washing clothes in a bucket. LeBeau invites Carter to Paris after the war, where they will meet girls. Carter asks LeBeau if he is sure that they are girls that Mary Jane will approve. LeBeau walks away disgusted.

In Klink's office, Hogan tells Helga 'You know what to do'. Carter comes in, Helga comes on to him. Carter politely brushes her off.

In the compound, Hogan is talking to Klink. Klink wants the prisoners to fall in; he wants to talk to the prisoners. Klink says that if any man tries to escape, the whole barracks will be punished. Carter asks if that applies to hardship cases. Klink walks away disgusted.

Later, Carter is talking to Schultz. He tells Schultz that he was going to marry Mary Jane when he gets back. Schultz tells him that women are like war: there is always another one coming around. Schultz asks Carter if he wants to escape. He begs Carter not to escape, because if he does they might send him to the Russian Front. If Carter is caught, Schultz might get a 10 day pass, which he will have to spend with his wife, and he does not want that either.

Hogan has a subtle plan to get Carter to stay. In Hogan's office, Hogan tells Carter that he can go home. Carter then starts planning to leave, he gives LeBeau his harmonica. Carter is in the process of giving away other things when Hogan comes in. Hogan says that London wants the Germans to get the microfilm in 48 hours. He asks for volunteers; at first, nobody volunteers. Hogan finally gets Carter to volunteer; Carter asks if he can go home after, and Hogan gives him his word that he can.

Hogan looks out through the land periscope, and the area is clear. Carter leaves through the tunnel, and goes to a bar in town. He looks around and sits with a soldier, an artillery private (played by William Christopher). Carter says that he is an escaped prisoner, and the soldier might get a promotion. The soldier says that he is on his first leave in a long time, and he doesn't want any complications, and leaves. Carter then goes to another table, where a German army captain, another officer, and 2 women are seated. He tells the captain that he is an escaped prisoner. The officers think that he is a Gestapo agent in disguise. Just then, a Gestapo man in civilian clothes comes in. He asks the two officers for their papers. After looking, he says that the papers are in order. The captain tells the Gestapo officer not to look at Carter's papers, and he may catch one of their own. The Gestapo officer does go to Carter and asks for his papers. Carter gives him his papers, and tells him that he is an escaped prisoner. The Gestapo officer looks at the papers, and says 'Section 9 in Berlin makes excellent fakes'. They then walk away. Mady, the barmaid, comes and talks to Carter. She says that she is Norwegian; she wants to help Carter escape. She tells Carter to go back to camp and get some rest, then she kisses Carter. Carter starts to leave the bar, and the Gestapo officer offers him a ride; Carter accepts.

Later, in camp, Hogan is in Klink's office, with the Gestapo, Carter, and Schultz. The Gestapo says that 'the truth' came out on the way to camp, that Carter is really an escaped prisoner. Klink wants to put him in the cooler. Carter asks for his cigarette lighter; the Gestapo officer thinks something is funny, and looks at it. He finds the microfilm, and says that he has to get it to Berlin. Klink says that Carter has made a fool of him in front of his own command and asks him if he is satisfied. Hogan, says he is satisfied, and asks Carter if he is satisfied. Carter says he is satisfied, and asks Schultz if he is satisfied. Schultz says he is satisfied, and asks Klink if he is satisfied. Klink starts saying 'Yes, I'm ....' then stops mid-sentence.

At the end, in the barracks, Carter thanks Hogan for getting him out of the cooler. Hogan says that the raid was a success. As Carter starts to leave through the tunnel, Hogan says to say hello to Mary Jane. Carter says that he is not going home, he is going to town to see Mady. He quotes what Schultz told him earlier, that women are like wars, there is always another one coming around.
